title: Interpreting the Ooguri-Vafa symplectic form à la Atiyah-Bott

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Gaiotto, Moore, and Neitzke predicted that the hyperkähler Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ should provide a local model for Hitchin moduli spaces near the discriminant locus. To this end, Tulli identified $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ with a certain space of framed Higgs bundles with an irregular singularity. We extend this result by identifying the Ooguri-Vafa holomorphic symplectic form with a regularized version of the Atiyah-Bott form on the associated space of framed connections. We also prove the analogous statement for the corresponding semiflat forms. Finally, restricting to the Hitchin section, we identify a regularized version of Hitchin's $L^{2}$-metric with the Ooguri-Vafa metric.

# 1. INTRODUCTION 

Moduli spaces of Higgs bundles carry an incredibly rich structure, due in large part to the presence of Hitchin's hyperkähler metric $g_{L^{2}}$ [Hit87]. Although $g_{L^{2}}$ is naturally defined, it is highly transcendental, involving solutions to Hitchin's equation (a nonlinear PDE).

A precise conjectural picture of $g_{L^{2}}$ was described in the work of Gaiotto, Moore, and Neitzke [GMN10, GMN13b]. In particular - and of main interest to us in this paper - the local picture near the discriminant locus of the Hitchin base was conjectured to be described by the hyperkähler Ooguri-Vafa metric (originally defined in [OV96]).

The data of a hyperkähler metric can equivalently be formulated in terms of a twistor family of holomorphic symplectic forms $\Omega_{\zeta}$ (see [Hit92a, HKLR87], or [GMN10, Section 3] for a summary).

- In the case of a moduli space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ of Higgs bundles, say for now on a compact Riemann surface $C$ (see Appendix A for more background), the form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {Hit }}$ corresponding to $g_{L^{2}}$ can be studied in terms of flat connections on $C .{ }^{1}$

Given a Higgs bundle $(E, \theta)$ and a harmonic metric $h$ solving Hitchin's equation, there is an associated family of flat connections

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{h}}, \quad \zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

(where $D_{h}$ denotes the Chern connection). For each $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, the nonabelian Hodge correspondence $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}:(E, \theta) \mapsto\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}\right)$ identifies $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ (in complex structure $I_{\zeta}$ ) with the de Rham moduli space $\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{dR}}$ of flat $\operatorname{SL}(2, \mathbb{C})$-connections on $C$ (in its natural complex structure). Furthermore, the form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {Hit }}$ on $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ is identified with the holomorphic symplectic Atiyah-Bott form $[A B 83]$

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{AB}}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=\int_{C} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)
$$

on $\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{dR}}$.

- In the case of the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$, the holomorphic symplectic form can be written

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}(\zeta) \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta), \quad \zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

in terms of certain "electric and magnetic twistor coordinates" $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ [GMN10].
Following the predictions of Gaiotto-Moore-Neitzke, Tulli [Tul19] identified $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ with a moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ of (framed) rank 2 harmonic bundles over $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ with an irregular singularity at $\infty$. Under this correspondence, the twistor coordinates $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ of the holomorphic symplectic form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov }}$ are described in terms of the Stokes data of the irregular connections $\nabla_{\zeta}$.

The question of an $L^{2}$-interpretation of the Ooguri-Vafa metric (or form) was left open in [Tul19]. Unlike the usual moduli spaces of wild Higgs bundles (see e.g. [BB04]), the parabolic weights and residues of the bundles in $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ are allowed to vary, and as a result the naive formulas for $g_{L^{2}}$ and the corresponding Atiyah-Bott form are divergent.

In this paper, we introduce a regularization and gluing procedure to study the hyperkähler structure of $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$. We use this procedure to identify identify the Ooguri-Vafa form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov }}$ with a regularized version of the Atiyah-Bott form on $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$. By further restricting to the Hitchin section we deduce the corresponding statement about metrics, i.e. we identify a regularized version of Hitchin's metric with the Ooguri-Vafa metric. Additionally, we prove the analogous results about the "semiflat" metrics and forms, which also play a role in the conjectural picture of Gaitto-MooreNeitzke.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ We omit discussion of the relevant stability conditions here; all of the Higgs bundles we consider later will be stable.

Our main technique is to study the corresponding framed abelianized connections on the spectral cover $\Sigma \rightarrow C .{ }^{2}$ Below we will give a high-level overview of the argument, followed by a more detailed summary of our results and strategy.
1.1. A schematic guide. We will be interested in three related sets of framed objects (see Figure 1):
(1) $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ - the set of framed harmonic bundles considered in [Tul19], whose moduli space of isomorphism classes is $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$.
(2) $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}$ - a set of framed flat $\mathrm{SL}(2)$-connections on $C=C \mathbb{P}^{1}$, which can be obtained from harmonic bundles in $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ by the nonabelian Hodge correspondence.
(3) $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ - a set of framed "almost-flat" GL(1)-connections on the spectral cover $\Sigma$ of $C$, which can be obtained by abelianizing connections in $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}$.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1. The main sets of framed objects and the maps between them.
Our goal is to compare the following closed 2-forms on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$, which descend to holomorphic symplectic forms on its space of isomorphism classes $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ :
(1) $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {ov }}$ - the Ooguri-Vafa form, interpreted Stokes-theoretically via a form $\Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\text {ov }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}$.
(2) $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg }}$ - the pullback of a regularized version $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ of the Atiyah-Bott form on $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}$.

We will argue that the above forms are in fact equal ${ }^{3}$ via the following commutative diagram, involving two intermediary abelian forms on $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ :
(3) $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ - a "glued symplectic form", pulled back from the Atiyah-Bott form on the torus.
(4) $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$ - a regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form on the spectral cover.

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

There are also semiflat versions of the above spaces and forms, which are simpler and more explicit. We will introduce them in Section 6 and carry out an analogous argument.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ More precisely, the spectral cover $\Sigma$ itself varies along with the nonabelian connections on $C$. However, all of our calculations in the moduli space are local, and nearby $\Sigma$ are diffeomorphic, so we can identify them with a fixed surface when computing variations.
    ${ }^{3}$ up to a factor of $-4 \pi^{2}$, which we suppress here

# 1.2. Detailed summary and strategy. 

1.2.1. Framed bundles. The set $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ of compatibly framed wild harmonic bundles introduced in [Tul19] consists of tuples $(E, \theta, h, g)$ where, roughly:

- $\left.E\right|_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}$ is a holomorphic rank 2 vector bundle equipped with
- a traceless Higgs field $\theta$ such that $\operatorname{det} \theta=-\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$ for some $m \in \mathbb{C},{ }^{4}$ and
- a harmonic metric $h$.
- $g$ is a frame of $E$ near $z=\infty$ with respect to which the Higgs field $\theta$ and holomorphic structure $\tilde{\partial}_{E}$ are of a certain singular form.
(See Section 2.1 for the full definitions.)
Let $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ denote the set of isomorphism classes of $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$. The elements of $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ are parametrized by the value $m \in \mathbb{C}$ describing the simple pole term of the singularity, $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$ describing the parabolic weights, and another $U(1)$-valued parameter describing the framing $g$. (cf. the picture of the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ in Figure 2 below.)

Given $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$, the corresponding flat connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ defined by (1.1) also has an irregular singularity at $z=\infty$, and consequently it undergoes Stokes phenomena. With respect to the frame $g$, it is of the form

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}=d+\left[-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right] H+\text { regular terms }
$$

near $w=1 / z=0$, where $H=\operatorname{diag}(1,-1)$.
Let $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ denote the space of framed connections $(E, \nabla, g)$ which are of the above form.
Definition I (=Definition 4.2). Define a regularized Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ by

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{C_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)-2 \pi \log R \cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)\right]
$$

where $C_{R}:=\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{|w|<R\}$ and, in polar coordinates $w=r e^{i \theta}$ near $w=0$,

$$
\nabla_{i}=\left(\mu_{i}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left(\lambda_{i}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for some diagonal matrices } \mu_{i}, \lambda_{i}
$$

(The "regularization term" $-2 \pi \log R \cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)$ can be explicitly calculated using (1.5).)
We can pull back $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ to a form on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ via $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}:(E, \theta) \mapsto\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}\right)$, and it furthermore descends to the moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$. Slightly abusing notation, we will denote both of these pulledback forms by $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg }}$.
1.2.2. The Ooguri-Vafa space. The Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ is a hyperkähler space of complex dimension 2. Technical details on the construction of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ using the Gibbons-Hawking ansatz can be found in [GW00]; see also the summaries in [GMN10, Tul19]. We include a brief recap in Appendix B, but the most important attributes for our purposes are as follows.

The space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ is a singular torus fibration over a disc $\mathcal{B}$ in $\mathbb{C}$, whose central fibre over 0 is a torus with a node. The other fibres are nonsingular tori parametrized by an electric angle $\theta_{e}$ and magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ (see Figure 2).
Remark $1.1\left(\theta_{m}\right.$ monodromy). The coordinate $\theta_{m}$ is not globally defined; it has monodromy

$$
\theta_{m} \rightarrow \theta_{m}+\theta_{e}-\pi
$$

as we go counterclockwise around $z=0$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ The underlying unframed bundles $(E, \theta, h)$ thereby provide a local model of the Higgs moduli space near the generic part of the discriminant locus, which for SL(2)-Higgs bundles consists of quadratic differentials with one double zero.

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 2. The Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$, regarded as a singular torus fibration over a disc $\mathcal{B} \subset \mathbb{C}$.

Under the correspondence $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ in [Tul19]: ${ }^{5}$

- The angles $\theta_{e}$ and $\theta_{m}$ are expressed in terms of certain explicit quantities involving $m, m^{(3)}$, and the framing $g$.
- The twistor coordinates $\mathcal{X}_{e}(\zeta)$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta)$ of the holomorphic symplectic form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov }}$ are interpreted in terms of the Stokes data of the connections $\nabla_{\zeta}$ (namely the formal monodromy of $\nabla_{\zeta}$ and the non-trivial element of a certain Stokes matrix, respectively).
We will say more about this correspondence below, but at this point we can formulate our main result.

Theorem A (= Theorem 5.3). Under the identification of spaces $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{reg}}
$$

i.e. the Ooguri-Vafa symplectic form coincides with (a multiple of) the regularized Atiyah-Bott form, pulled back to $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$.
1.2.3. Stokes data and abelianization. The interpretation of $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ from [Tul19] can be fully stated in terms of the Stokes data of the connections $\nabla_{\zeta}$ (see Sections 2.2.1 and 2.3), but for our purposes it will be more useful to describe them - especially $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ - in terms of the corresponding abelianized connections $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$.

An SL(2)-Higgs bundle $(E, \theta)$ on a surface $C$ has an associated double cover, its spectral curve

$$
\Sigma=\left\{\lambda \in T^{*} C: \operatorname{det}(\theta-\lambda I)=0\right\} \subseteq T^{*} C
$$

Many of the related geometric objects have simpler GL(1)-versions on $\Sigma$. In particular, flat connections on $C$ can be lifted to abelian connections on $\Sigma$ using a spectral network [GMN13a]. (See Section 3.1 for a detailed review of the relevant material.)

Each connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ coming from $(E, \theta)$ has an associated spectral network $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$, which is a collection of walls ${ }^{6}$ on $C$. In our case, for a connection coming from $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, the topology of the spectral network $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$ depends on the values of $m$ and $\zeta$ (see Figure 3 for an example).

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ More precisely, [Tul19] identifies a subset of $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (consisting of isomorphism classes whose parameter $m$ lies in a sufficiently small disc) with the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}(\Lambda)$, for a certain cutoff $\Lambda \in \mathbb{C}$. See Section 2.3 for more details.
    ${ }^{6}$ with certain labels, as described in Definition 3.3

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 3. One of the two generic topologies for a spectral network $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$ coming from $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, shown here for $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$.

The abelianization procedure uses $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$ to lift $\nabla_{\zeta}$ to an "almost-flat" connection $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ over $\Sigma$. Concretely, $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ can be constructed by choosing a basis of flat sections $\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)$ in each cell of the network, as shown in Figure 4.
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Figure 4. Additional decorations for a spectral network $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$ coming from $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, shown for $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$. The flat sections $\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)$ used for abelianization in each cell are labelled in green. The paths $\gamma_{e}$ and $\gamma_{m}$ on $\Sigma$ are used to interpret $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ as parallel transports of $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$.

The Ooguri-Vafa twistor coordinates can be interpreted Stokes-theoretically in terms of the flat sections $s_{i}$, or equivalently in terms of parallel transports of the abelianized connection $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$.

- $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ is one of the diagonal entries of the formal monodromy of $\nabla_{\zeta}$. It can be calculated by the cross-ratio

$$
\mathcal{X}_{e}(\zeta)=\frac{s_{1} \wedge s_{4}}{s_{3} \wedge s_{4}} \frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{1} \wedge s_{2}}
$$

which corresponds to the parallel transport of $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ around the path $\gamma_{e}$ shown in Figure 4. (Note that (1.10) is the usual formula for a spectral coordinate [GMN14]/Fock-Goncharov coordinate [FG06], and is invariant under rescaling $s_{i} \rightarrow c_{i} s_{i}$.)

- $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ is the off-diagonal entry of one of the Stokes matrices. In order to make gauge-invariant sense of this, the framing $g$ of the bundles $\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}\right)$ is crucial: it allows us to single out a normalization for each section $s_{i}$ by prescribing the asymptotics near the singularity [GMN13b]. Choosing suitably normalized sections (as described in Section 2.2.1), we can calculate $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ by the ratio

$$
\mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta)= \begin{cases}\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}} & \text { if } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0 \\ -\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{4} \wedge s_{2}} & \text { if } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0\end{cases}
$$

which corresponds to a regularized parallel transport of $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ along the open path $\gamma_{m}$ shown in Figure 4. (See the recent paper [ANXZ24] for discussion of spectral coordinates for open paths.)
We can think of these Stokes-theoretic interpretations of $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ as defining a form

$$
\Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\mathrm{ov}}:=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e} \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}
$$

on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, which pulls back to

$$
\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}\right)^{*} \Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\mathrm{ov}}=\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}
$$

on $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{ov}}$ under the identification in [Tul19]. (We discuss this further in Section 2.3.)
In Section 3.2 we explain how the given frame $g$ for $\nabla_{\zeta}$ naturally induces a frame $g^{\mathrm{ab}}$ for $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$. This allows us to define a space $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ of framed abelian connections and a corresponding regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$, analogously to Definition I above. We prove in Section 4.3 that abelianization preserves these forms; that is,

$$
\mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{ab}}=\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}
$$

1.2.4. Gluing and regularization. The next question is how to relate the Ooguri-Vafa form (1.3) to the regularized Atiyah-Bott form.

As motivation, note that if $S$ is a compact surface of genus $g$ with standard homology basis $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{g}, b_{1}, \ldots, b_{g}$, then the logs of the holonomies of flat $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connections along $a_{i}$ and $b_{i}$ are Darboux coordinates for the abelian Atiyah-Bott form:

$$
\int_{S} \delta \nabla \wedge \delta \nabla=\sum_{i=1}^{g} d \log \operatorname{Hol}_{a_{i}} \nabla \wedge d \log \operatorname{Hol}_{b_{i}} \nabla
$$

(This is essentially just a restatement of the Riemann bilinear identity.)
In our case the spectral cover $\Sigma \xrightarrow{\pi} C$ is not compact, and the (non-regularized) Atiyah-Bott form on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ is divergent. To remedy this we instead consider the cut off surface $\Sigma_{R}:=\pi^{-1}\left(C_{R}\right)$, which is topologically a cylinder, and glue the ends to form a torus $T$.

The framed $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connections in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ have a prescribed form near the boundary $\partial \Sigma_{R}$, which does not automatically glue to define a connection on $T$, but we can glue them by making an appropriate gauge transformation $\chi=\chi(\alpha)$ for each connection $\nabla=d+\alpha$. This allows us to pull back the abelian Atiyah-Bott form from $T$ to obtain a "glued symplectic form"

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)=\int_{\Sigma_{\alpha}}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}-d \mathfrak{X}_{1}\right) \wedge\left(\dot{\alpha}_{2}-d \mathfrak{X}_{2}\right)
$$

on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ (which is in fact independent of the cutoff $R \ll 1$ ). We describe this gluing construction in more detail in Section 5.1.

Now we reach the key point - once suitably chosen, the gluing map $\chi$ simultaneously provides the regularization for the other constructions:

- On the one hand, we can rewrite

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)=\int_{\Sigma_{R}} \dot{\alpha}_{1} \wedge \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\int_{d \Sigma_{R}}\left(\dot{X}_{2} \dot{\alpha}_{1}-\dot{X}_{1} \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\dot{X}_{1} d \dot{X}_{2}\right)
$$

We show in Section 5.3.2 that the boundary integral coincides with the regularization term of the regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$ as $R \rightarrow 0$, and consequently

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue }}=\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}
$$

- On the other hand, it follows from the Riemann bilinear identity on the torus that

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)=\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{1} \int_{\gamma_{m, R}}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{2}-d \dot{X}_{2}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{2} \int_{\gamma_{m, R}}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}-d \dot{X}_{1}\right)
$$

(where $\gamma_{m, R}$ denotes the restriction of the open path from Figure 4 to $\Sigma_{R}$ ). When $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ is pulled back to $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$, the integrals $\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}$ correspond to the parallel transport for $\mathcal{X}_{e}$, and we show in Section 5.5 that the integrals $\int_{\gamma_{m, R}}(\dot{\alpha}-d \dot{X})$ calculate the appropriate regularized parallel transports for $\mathcal{X}_{m}$. Consequently

$$
\mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue }}=\Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\mathrm{ov}}
$$

Combining all of these identifications via the commutative diagram (1.4) gives Theorem A.
1.2.5. The semiflat story. Solutions to the abelian Hitchin equation on the spectral cover $\Sigma$ lead to a corresponding semiflat hyperkähler metric $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {sf }}$ on the Higgs moduli space, defined away from the discriminant locus (at which $\Sigma$ fails to be smooth).

This simpler metric is also part of the picture of Hitchin's metric described by Gaiotto-MooreNeitzke: they predicted that $g_{L^{2}}$ exponentially approaches $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {sf }}$ along a ray $(E, t \theta)$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$. Many versions of this statement have now been proved, such as in [DN19] for SL(2)-Higgs bundles on the Hitchin section, [FMSW22] for the parabolic case, and [Fre20] for higher rank.

One could also ask how $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {sf }}$ (or its corresponding holomorphic symplectic form) behaves near the discriminant locus. There are natural semiflat versions of all of the constructions described above, such as a semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov,sf }}$, and a regularized Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg,sf }}$ for the "semiflat connections"

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\text {sf }}=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h_{s t}}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{h_{s t}}}
$$

However, the argument in [Tul19] does not prove that the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa magnetic coordinate is given by the Stokes data of the semiflat connections. Our task is now reversed:

- Before, we started with a Stokes-theoretic interpretation of the (non-explicit) magnetic coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}$, but had to develop the gluing procedure to study the corresponding integral.
- Now, we can follow essentially the same gluing procedure, but still need to match up the Stokes-theoretic integral with the explicit formula for $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {sf }}$.

The formula for the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ (and hence $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {sf }}$ ) under the correspondence $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ involves an integral of the Chern connection $D_{h}$. In the semiflat setting it is more natural to consider a "shifted angle" $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ defined in terms of the semiflat Chern connection $D_{h_{s t}}$, leading to a corresponding shifted form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov,shift }}$ (see Definition 6.15). Adapting our previous argument to this setting, we obtain the following analogue of Theorem A.
Theorem B (=Theorem 6.17). Under the identification of spaces $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov,shift }}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg,sf }}
$$

i.e. the shifted semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form coincides with the regularized semiflat Atiyah-Bott form, pulled back to $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$.

The angles $\theta_{m}$ and $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ are not obviously the same in general, but we prove in Section 7 that they both vanish on a suitable framed version of the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$. Here $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ consists of bundles $E=K_{\mathrm{C}}^{-1 / 2} \oplus K_{\mathrm{C}}^{1 / 2}$ with Higgs field

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2} & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad m \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

and a specific choice of framing and parabolic weights (see Definition 7.15 for the details). This Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ exhibits a natural notion of self-duality, which we use to calculate $\theta_{m}$ and $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$.
Theorem C (=Theorem 7.1). Restricted to the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\left.\theta_{m}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}} \equiv 0 \equiv \theta_{m}^{\text {shift }} \mid_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}
$$

Consequently

$$
\left.\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}=-\left.\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{sf}}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}
$$

i.e. the (usual) semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form coincides with the regularized semiflat Atiyah-Bott form.

We leave analysis of the difference $\theta_{m}-\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ away from the Hitchin section as an interesting question for future work.

The other natural next step is to translate our results from the symplectic forms to their corresponding metrics. On the Hitchin section, the $L^{2}$-metric can be written down more explicitly and the complex structure $I$ is easy to understand. In Section 8 we use these explicit descriptions to define a regularized metric $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg }}$ and deduce the analogue of Theorem A.

Theorem D (=Theorem 8.3). On the Hitchin section parametrized by quadratic differentials $\phi(z)=$ $\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$ for $m \in \mathbb{C}$,

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg }}=4 \pi^{2} \cdot g^{\mathrm{ov}}
$$

i.e. the regularized version of Hitchin's metric coincides with the Ooguri-Vafa metric.

The same is also true of the corresponding semiflat metrics.
Off the Hitchin section (i.e. on the rest of the space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ ), it is less clear how the complex structure should act on variations of the parabolic weights or framing. We leave these considerations for future work.

More broadly, it would be interesting to extend our techniques to study larger classes of hyperkähler structures, such as for other wild Higgs moduli spaces (e.g. with multiple poles or in higher rank), or for Poisson-Lie groups (cf. [ANXZ24]).
1.3. Organization of the paper. In Section 2 we introduce the main spaces under consideration and recall the relevant background. In Section 3 we review the abelianization procedure and describe how it extends to framed bundles. In Section 4 we introduce a regularized version of the Atiyah-Bott form and show that it is preserved by abelianization. In Section 5 we describe a construction for a glued symplectic form on the space of abelianized connections, and use it to show that the Ooguri-Vafa form coincides with the regularized Atiyah-Bott form.

The next sections are focused on the analogous semiflat story. In Section 6 we apply our earlier arguments from Sections 2 to 5 to this modified setting. In Section 7 we introduce a framed Hitchin section on which we further study the Ooguri-Vafa magnetic angle.

In Section 8 we use our main results about the Ooguri-Vafa and Atiyah-Bott symplectic forms to describe the metric on the Hitchin section.

The appendices contain some more technical background and calculations.

# 2. GENERAL BACKGROUND AND SETUP 

In this section we give an overview of the main objects and spaces that will appear throughout the text. We will relegate some of the other technical background to the later sections and introduce additional tools as they become relevant.
2.1. Framed harmonic bundles. First, we recall the spaces of Higgs bundles studied in [Tul19]. For consistency we will use the same notation and conventions.

Definition 2.1 (Harmonic bundles in $\mathcal{H}$ ). Let $\mathcal{H}$ denote the set of rank 2 wild $^{7}$ harmonic bundles $\left(E, \delta_{E}, \theta, h\right)$ over $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}$ such that $\operatorname{tr} \theta=0$ and $\operatorname{det} \theta=-\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$ for some $m \in \mathbb{C}$.

Recall that "wild harmonic" means:

- $\left(E, \delta_{E}\right)$ is a holomorphic vector bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}$.
- the Higgs field $\theta$ is an $\operatorname{End}(E)$-valued 1-form with $\partial_{E} \theta=0$.
- the harmonic metric $h$ is a hermitian metric satisfying Hitchin's equation

$$
F_{D_{h}}+\left[\theta, \theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right]=0
$$

where $D_{h}$ is the Chern connection for $\left(\delta_{E}, h\right)$ and $F_{D_{h}}$ is its curvature.

- (wildness): there is a holomorphic coordinate $w$ in a neighbourhood $U$ of $\infty$ and a decomposition

$$
\left.\left(E, \delta_{E}, \theta\right)\right|_{U}=\bigoplus_{a \in \mathcal{I}}\left(E_{a}, \delta_{E_{a}}, \theta_{a}\right)
$$

where $\mathcal{I} \subset w^{-1} \mathbb{C}\left[w^{-1}\right]$ is the set of irregular types and each $\theta_{a}-d a \cdot \operatorname{id}_{E_{a}}$ has at worst a simple pole.

Definition 2.2 (Framed harmonic bundles in $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ ). Let $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ denote the set of compatibly framed harmonic bundles $\left(E, \delta_{E}, \theta, h, g\right)$ where:

- $\left.\left(E, \delta_{E}, \theta, h\right)\right|_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}} \in \mathcal{H}$.
- $(E, h)$ is an $\mathrm{SU}(2)$-bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ (i.e. a unitary extension of the above bundle over $\infty$ ). ${ }^{8}$
- $g$ is an $\mathrm{SU}(2)$-frame of $E_{\infty}$ that extends to an $\mathrm{SU}(2)$-frame in a neighbourhood of $z=\infty$ with respect to which

$$
\begin{gathered}
\theta=-H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m H \frac{d w}{w}+\text { regular terms, } \\
\delta_{E}=\hat{\partial}-\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}+\text { regular terms for some } m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

Here and throughout, $w=1 / z$ and $H=\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\right)$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{7}$ We will only work with unramified wild objects.
    ${ }^{8}$ This also means that $(E, h)$ comes with a volume form trivializing $\operatorname{det} E$, but this won't play much of a role for us.

For brevity we will usually omit $\tilde{\partial}_{E}$ from the notation, and write $(E, \theta, h) \in \mathcal{H}$ for the underlying wild harmonic bundle and $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {tr }}$ for the framed bundle. (Note that the former is a bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}$ while the latter is a bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$.) We will sometimes also omit $h$ when it is not relevant.
Remark 2.3 (Parabolic interpretation of $m^{(3)}$ ). The bundles $(E, \theta, h) \in \mathcal{H}$ naturally carry a filtered structure, defined in terms of growth rates with respect to the harmonic metric $h$. This in turn induces a parabolic structure with weights in $\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$. (We review these definitions in Appendix C.1.) The parameter $m^{(3)}$ describes the parabolic weights:

- If $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)$, then the parabolic weights are $\pm m^{(3)}$, associated to the $\theta$-eigenlines near $z=\infty$ with respective eigenvalues $\pm(z+m / z+\ldots) d z= \pm\left(-1 / w^{3}-m / w+\ldots\right) d w$.
- If $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$, then the parabolic weight is $\frac{1}{2}$ with multiplicity 2 , associated to the trivial filtration near $\infty$.
Definition 2.4 (Sets of isomorphism classes).
(i) Let $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ denote the set of isomorphism classes of $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$.
(ii) For fixed $m \in \mathbb{C}$ and $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$, let $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}\left(m, m^{(3)}\right) \subseteq \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ consist of the classes of framed Higgs bundles whose singularity is described by the parameters $m$ and $m^{(3)}$ in (2.2) and (2.3) respectively.

Proposition 2.5 ( $U(1)$-action, [Tul19, Proposition 4.1 \& Lemmas 4.3 and 4.4]). For $g=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$, let $e^{i \theta} \cdot g:=\left(e^{i \theta} e_{1}, e^{-i \theta} e_{2}\right)$. Then

$$
e^{i \theta} \cdot[(E, \theta, g)]:=\left[\left(E, \theta, e^{i \frac{\theta}{2}} \cdot g\right)\right]
$$

defines a $U(1)$-action on $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$.
(1) For $m \neq 0$ and any $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$, the set $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}\left(m, m^{(3)}\right)$ is a $U(1)$-torsor under this action.
(2) For $m=0$, the set $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}\left(0, m^{(3)}\right)$ is a $U(1)$-torsor if $m^{(3)} \neq 0$ and a single point if $m^{(3)}=0$.
(cf. the picture of the Ooguri-Vafa space in Figure 2.)

In Appendix C. 2 we discuss explicit constructions of compatibly framed bundles, but this will not come into play until Section 6.
2.2. Framed connections. For each $(E, \theta, h) \in \mathcal{H}$ and $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, there is a corresponding flat connection

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}:=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{h}}
$$

(Flatness of $\nabla_{\zeta}$ is equivalent to $h$ satisfying Hitchin's equation (2.1).) This defines the nonabelian Hodge map $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}:(E, \theta) \mapsto\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}\right)$.

If we start with a framed harmonic bundle $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$, then with respect to the (extension of the) frame $g$ in a neighbourhood of $w=0$, the Chern connection is of the form

$$
D_{h}=d+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)+\text { regular terms }
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla_{\zeta}= & d+\left[\zeta^{-1}\left(-\frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m \frac{d w}{w}\right)+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)+\zeta\left(-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\bar{m} \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)\right] H \\
& + \text { regular terms } \\
= & d+\left[-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right] H \\
& + \text { regular terms. }
\end{aligned}
$$

These framed connections will be our primary objects of interest, so we will give a name to the corresponding space.
Definition 2.6 (Framed flat bundles in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ ). For fixed $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, let $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ denote the set of $\zeta$-compatibly framed flat bundles $(E, \nabla, g)$ where:

- $E$ is a rank 2 holomorphic vector bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$, with parabolic weights at $z=\infty$ described by the parameter $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$ as in Remark 2.3.
- $\nabla$ is a flat (complex) connection on $E$ with irregular singularity at $\infty$, of the form (2.8) with respect to the framing $g$ near $\infty$.
Say that $(E, \nabla, g) \cong\left(E^{\prime}, \nabla^{\prime}, g^{\prime}\right)$ if there is a bundle isomorphism $E \xrightarrow{\sim} E^{\prime}$ preserving the additional structure, and let $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ denote the set of isomorphism classes of $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$.

To summarize, Table 1 lists the main spaces of objects and their isomorphism classes introduced so far (cf. Figure 1).

![table_0](table_0)

TABLE 1. Spaces of framed bundles over $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$.

Remark 2.7 ( $\zeta$-compatible framings). The terminology above is nonstandard; our notion of a $\zeta$ compatible framing is just a translation of the definition of a compatible framing for a harmonic bundle under the nonabelian Hodge map $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}$.

There is already a more common notion of compatible framing in the Stokes theory of meromorphic connections (see e.g. [Boa01]), where it means that the leading coefficient of the singular part of the connection is diagonal. ${ }^{9}$ In our case it will be more convenient to work in the $C^{\infty}$ setting, but the needed results from the classical Stokes theory carry over, as we discuss in Appendix D.

By construction, the nonabelian Hodge formula (2.5) for $\nabla_{\zeta}$ defines a map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}: \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}} & \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}} \\
(E, \theta, h, g) & \mapsto\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which descends to a map of moduli spaces

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}: \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}} \\
& {[(E, \theta, h, g)] \mapsto\left[\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

Throughout the paper we will use $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}$ to pull back various symplectic forms from the space $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}\right)$ to $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ (resp. $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ ).

Remark 2.8 (Moduli space expectations). In [Tul19], the moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ of isomorphism classes in $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ is really just defined as a set - it later obtains an induced hyperkähler structure from the identification with the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$, but we do not have a direct gauge-theoretic construction of the moduli space. (The parabolic weights and residues of the bundles in $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ are allowed to vary, unlike the usual spaces of wild Higgs bundles in [BB04]. However, the associated moduli space $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ of connections is similar to the "extended moduli spaces" in [Boa01], where the

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ This is the definition used in [Tul19], in which it is shown how to obtain such a compatible frame $\tau$ from $g$. We summarize the relevant details in Appendix D.1.

formal type of the connections is not fixed. ${ }^{10}$ It would be interesting to compare these constructions and their respective symplectic forms.)

We will assume in the following calculations that our moduli spaces have the "obvious" tangent spaces, i.e. that variations of elements in $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ or $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ can be represented by endomorphism-valued 1-forms which are of the appropriate framed form near $z=\infty$, modulo the action of gauge transformations which approach the identity near $\infty$ and preserve the framed form.

We also expect (but will not prove or need) that other features of the usual wild nonabelian Hodge correspondence [BB04] hold, e.g. that $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ gives a homeomorphism of moduli spaces $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }} \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ which is a diffeomorphism away from the discriminant locus $m=0$.

At this point we can define the regularized Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$, as in Definition I. We will return to this and study its properties in Section 4.
2.2.1. Conventions for Stokes data. Given $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, we can consider the classical Stokes data of the corresponding irregular connection $\nabla_{\zeta} \cdot{ }^{11}$ We briefly summarize some of the key points below.

The connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has four anti-Stokes rays $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{4}$ and four Stokes rays, corresponding in this case to directions in the $w$-plane where $\zeta^{-1} w^{-2}$ is real resp. imaginary. With these naming conventions, the anti-Stokes rays are the asymptotic directions of the relevant spectral network (described in Section 3), and flat sections exchange dominance when crossing a Stokes ray.

Let Sect $_{i}$ denote the sector bounded by the anti-Stokes rays $r_{i}$ and $r_{i+1}$, and let $\widehat{\text { Sect }}_{i}$ denote the extended sector bounded by the adjacent Stokes rays (see Figure 5). There is a canonical way of diagonalizing $\nabla_{\zeta}$ in each extended sector near $w=0$, which allows us (after choosing a branch of the logarithm) to define a corresponding sectorial frame of flat sections.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 5. A sector $\mathrm{Sect}_{1}$ and extended sector $\widehat{\mathrm{Sect}}_{1}$ in a neighbourhood of $w=0$ (shown here for $\zeta=m<0$ ). The solid labelled rays are anti-Stokes rays, and the dotted rays are Stokes rays.

Remark 2.9 (Labelling conventions). The formulas for the Stokes data depend on the labelling of the rays and the choice of logarithm branch. We will follow the same conventions as in [Tul19, Section 3.4.4], which depend on the parameters $\zeta, m \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. In that paper, these choices were

All of the relevant Stokes data can be defined in terms of $\left(E_{a}, \nabla_{\zeta}, \tau_{a, \zeta}\right)$, and is independent of the choice of $a$.

essential for determining the jumps of the Stokes data as $\zeta$ varies. For us, the exact details will not be as important, except to make sure our constructions match up with [Tul19].

Briefly: for $\zeta=m$, we denote the anti-Stokes ray in the direction $w=e^{-\frac{1}{2} i \arg (m)}$ by $r_{1}$ and number the others counterclockwise. As $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*} \backslash\left\{\zeta^{-1} m i<0\right\}$ varies from $\zeta=m$, the rays (and choice of logarithm branch) also vary continuously.

The Ooguri-Vafa magnetic coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov }}(\zeta)$, interpreted Stokes-theoretically in (2.23) below, has jumps at its boundary rays $\left\{ \pm \zeta^{-1} m i<0\right\}$.

More importantly for our application, the sectorial frames can be described by their asymptotics.

Proposition 2.10 (Sectorial asymptotics, cf. [Tul19, Lemmas 3.5 and 3.6]). In each extended sector $\widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$ there exists a frame of flat sections $\Phi_{i}$ uniquely characterized by the following asymptotic condition:

If we write $\Phi_{i}=g \cdot M_{i}$ with respect to the original compatible frame $g$, then the matrix $M_{i}$ satisfies

$$
M_{i} \cdot e^{A_{0}(w) H} \rightarrow 1 \quad \text { as } w \rightarrow 0 \text { in } \widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}
$$

where

$$
A_{0}(w):=\frac{1}{2} \zeta^{-1} w^{-2}+\frac{1}{2} \zeta \bar{w}^{-2}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \log w-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \log \bar{w}
$$

Remark 2.11. In fact, the uniqueness part only uses that the asymptotics (2.11) hold as $w \rightarrow 0$ in a neighbourhood of the Stokes ray inside Sect ${ }_{i}$ (cf. the proof of [Tul19, Lemma 3.6]).

The Stokes matrix $S_{i}$ is defined as the transition matrix from $\Phi_{i}$ to $\Phi_{i+1}$ on $\widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i} \cap \widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i+1}$. For $i=4$, we interpret $\Phi_{5}:=\Phi_{1} \cdot M_{0}$, where

$$
M_{0}=\exp \left(-2 \pi i\left(-\zeta^{-1} m+m^{(3)}+\zeta \bar{m}\right) H\right)
$$

is the formal monodromy of $\nabla_{\zeta}$.
We will write the frames of flat sections in each sector as

$$
\Phi_{1}=\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right), \quad \Phi_{2}=\left(s_{3}, s_{2}\right), \quad \Phi_{3}=\left(s_{3}, s_{4}\right), \quad \Phi_{4}=\left(s_{1}, s_{4}\right)
$$

![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Figure 7. Labelling for the frames of flat sections $\Phi_{i}$ in each sector Sect ${ }_{i}$.
so that $s_{i}$ is exponentially decreasing along the $i$ th anti-Stokes ray $r_{i}$ (see Figure 7 and cf. the spectral networks in Figure 13). Then the Stokes matrices $S_{1}, S_{3}$ are lower-triangular and $S_{2}, S_{4}$ are upper-triangular.

In particular, we will denote

$$
S_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
a & 1
\end{array}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad S_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & b \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

so that we have the relations

$$
s_{3}=s_{1}+a s_{2} \quad \text { and } \quad s_{4}=s_{2}+b s_{3}
$$

which we can rewrite as

$$
a=\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}} \quad \text { and } \quad b=\frac{s_{4} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}}
$$

We emphasize that everything described above depends on $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, including the sectors, frames of flat sections, and Stokes matrix elements $a=a(\zeta)$ and $b=b(\zeta)$.
2.3. Correspondence with the Ooguri-Vafa space. Here we will summarize the main aspects of the correspondence between $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{tr}}$ and the Ooguri-Vafa space from [Tul19].

Let $\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\Lambda)$ denote the Ooguri-Vafa space with cutoff $\Lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. As described in Section 1.2.2, $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}(\Lambda)$ is a singular torus fibration over a neighbourhood $\mathcal{B}_{\Lambda}$ of the origin in $\mathbb{C}$, the size of which depends on $|\Lambda|$. The fibres over nonzero $z \in \mathcal{B}_{\Lambda}$ are tori parametrized by an electric angle $\theta_{e}$ and magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$. The central fibre over $z=0$ is a torus with a node, where the circle corresponding to $\theta_{m}$ degenerates to a point (again see Figure 2).

We will describe the hyperkähler structure of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}(\Lambda)$ via the electric and magnetic twistor coordinates $\mathcal{X}_{e}^{\text {ov }}, \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov }}$ [GMN10] for its holomorphic symplectic form

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\zeta) \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\zeta), \quad \zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

Explicitly, $\mathcal{X}_{e}^{\text {ov }}$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{X}_{e}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\zeta)=\exp \left(\zeta^{-1} \pi z+i \theta_{e}+\pi \zeta \bar{z}\right)
$$

and $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov }}$ has the semiflat approximation

$$
\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}(\zeta)=\exp \left(\zeta^{-1} \frac{z \log (z / \Lambda)-z}{2 i}+i \theta_{m}-\zeta \frac{\bar{z} \log (\bar{z} / \bar{\Lambda})-\bar{z}}{2 i}\right)
$$

(These coordinates define the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\zeta) \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}(\zeta)
$$

which we will study further starting in Section 6.1.3.) The full magnetic coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov }}$ is given by an "instanton correction" $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov }}=\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov,st }} \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov,inst }}$, involving an integral formula which we will not need to explicitly describe here.

Let $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}(\Lambda) \subseteq \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ consist of the isomorphism classes of framed Higgs bundles in $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ for which $-2 i m \in \mathcal{B}_{\Lambda}$. [Tul19] identifies the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}(\Lambda=4 i)$ with $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}(\Lambda=4 i)$ via the correspondence in Table 2.

![table_1](table_1)

Table 2. Partial dictionary between $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ and $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ parameters from [Tul19]. The formula for $\theta_{m}$ involves slightly more technical setup, so we postpone it to Section 6.1.3. Until then, we will work directly with the twistor coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ instead.

This correspondence makes $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}(4 i)$ into a hyperkähler space, with twistor coordinates given by

$$
\mathcal{X}_{e}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\zeta) \leftrightarrow \mathcal{X}_{e}(\zeta)=\exp \left(-2 \pi i\left(\zeta^{-1} m-m^{(3)}-\bar{m} \zeta\right)\right)
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\mathrm{ov}}(\zeta) \leftrightarrow \mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta)= \begin{cases}a(\zeta) & \text { if } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0 \\ -1 / b(\zeta) & \text { if } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0\end{cases}
$$

where $a(\zeta)$ and $b(\zeta)$ are the Stokes matrices elements associated to $\nabla_{\zeta}$ as in Section 2.2.1. Note that $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ also has a Stokes-theoretic interpretation, as one of the diagonal entries of the formal monodromy (2.13) of $\nabla_{\zeta}$.
Remark 2.12. Although the above identification for $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ can be seen directly from (2.19) using Table 2, the identification for $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ is very nontrivial - it was proved in [Tul19] by matching up the asymptotics and jumps of the Stokes data (as $\zeta \rightarrow 0, \infty$ and at $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)=0$, respectively) with those of the Ooguri-Vafa magnetic coordinate.

Let us introduce some notation to spell out the identifications (2.22) and (2.23) a bit more carefully. We will think of $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ (without superscripts) as functions on the space $\mathcal{A}_{e}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, where they assign to each connection its Stokes data as described above. These functions define a corresponding form

$$
\Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\mathrm{ov}}:=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e} \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}
$$

on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$. The pulled-back functions $\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}\right)^{*} \mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}\right)^{*} \mathcal{X}_{m}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ are isomorphism invariant and hence descend to the moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, where they coincide with the corresponding OoguriVafa coordinates $\mathcal{X}_{e}^{\text {ov }}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {ov }}$ under the identification $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{fr}}$. Consequently we can write

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}=\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}\right)^{*} \Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\mathrm{ov}}
$$

for the induced form on $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{ov}}$, as in (1.4).

tables.table_0:
|  | framed harmonic bundles | framed connections |
| :-- | :--: | :--: |
| sets of objects | $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ | $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ |
| moduli spaces | $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ | $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ |

sections.text:
# 3. Abelianization and framing 

In the last section we established our setup in terms of framed flat $\mathrm{SL}(2)$-connections $\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)$ on the base curve $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$. In this section we explain how to abelianize this data; that is, how to lift the relevant structures (particularly the framing) to corresponding rank 1 objects on the spectral cover $\Sigma$ of $C$.

3.1. Review of spectral networks and abelianization. We start by briefly recalling some of the main definitions and constructions involving spectral networks [GMN13a], especially pertaining to the abelianization of flat connections. We mostly follow the approach and exposition of [HN16]; see also [GMN13b, HRS21] for additional discussion of the relevant irregular singularity case. Many of the definitions below admit generalizations (e.g. to higher rank), but we will just describe what is needed for our application.
3.1.1. WKB spectral networks (in rank 2). Fix a compact Riemann surface $C$ and a meromorphic quadratic differential $\phi_{2}$ on $C$ (i.e. a meromorphic section of $K_{C}^{\geq 2}$, the square of the canonical bundle).

Assume that all of the zeros of $\phi_{2}$ are simple, and that $\phi_{2}$ has at least one pole. We will refer to the poles $p_{i}$ of $\phi_{2}$ as punctures of $C$.
Definition 3.1 (Spectral curve). The spectral curve defined by $\phi_{2}$ is

$$
\Sigma_{\phi_{2}}:=\left\{\lambda \in T^{*} C: \lambda^{2}-\phi_{2}=0\right\} \subseteq T^{*} C
$$

Note that $\Sigma=\Sigma_{\phi_{2}}$ is smooth since $\phi_{2}$ has only simple zeros. The projection $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow C$ is a double cover branched at the zeros of $\phi_{2}$, and $\Sigma$ has punctures lying over the $p_{i}$.

Fix a phase $\vartheta \in \mathbb{R} / 2 \pi \mathbb{Z}$.
Definition 3.2 ( $\vartheta$-trajectories). A $\vartheta$-trajectory of $\phi_{2}$ is a curve $\gamma$ on $C$ such that

$$
e^{-2 i \vartheta} \phi_{2}\left(v^{2}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}
$$

for all nonzero tangent vectors $v$ along $\gamma$.
The $\vartheta$-trajectories constitute the leaves of a singular foliation $\mathcal{F}_{\phi_{2}}^{\vartheta}$ on $C$. (For $\vartheta=0$ this is the classical "horizontal foliation" defined by $\phi_{2}$.) Both endpoints of a generic trajectory are at punctures of $C$. In particular, around each pole of order $k>2$, each trajectory is asymptotic to one of $k-2$ distinguished tangent directions. We will call these anti-Stokes directions, for reasons to be justified below.

A trajectory is called critical if (at least) one of its endpoints is at a branch point. There are three critical trajectories emanating from each branch point (see Figure 8). The union of the critical leaves is the critical graph $\mathrm{CG}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$. In the current setting, the relevant spectral network $\mathcal{W}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$ is given by $\operatorname{CG}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$ along with some additional labels.
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Figure 8. The three critical leaves emanating from a branch point, labelled as in Definition 3.3. The dashed orange line denotes a branch cut.

Definition 3.3 (Spectral network). The (WKB) spectral network $\mathcal{W}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$ is the following collection of oriented labelled paths on $C$, called walls:

- Each leaf of $\mathrm{CG}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$ is a wall, oriented away from the branch point. (In particular, the network can contain "double walls" arising from a critical trajectory which has both of its endpoints on branch points, i.e. a saddle connection.)
- Each wall $w$ is labelled with an ordering of the sheets of $\Sigma$ over $w$. After choosing branch cuts on $C$ and labelling the sheets of $\Sigma$ by $k=1,2$, we write the label as either " 12 " or " 21 ", determined as follows:

- The two sheets of $\Sigma$ correspond to the two square roots $\lambda_{k}$ of $\phi_{2}$. If $v$ is a positively oriented tangent vector along $w$, then by (3.2),

$$
e^{-i \vartheta} \lambda_{k}(v) \in \mathbb{R}_{\neq 0}
$$

- Let $k_{ \pm}$denote the appropriate index so that $e^{-i \vartheta} \lambda_{k_{ \pm}}(v) \in \mathbb{R}_{ \pm}$. Then label $w$ by " $k_{-} k_{+}$".

Example 3.4. We will be interested in the quadratic differential $\phi_{2}=\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$ on $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$, with $m \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. Three examples of the corresponding network $\mathcal{W}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$ (when $m<0$ ) are shown in Figure 9, plotted using the Mathematica notebook swn-plotter.nb [Nei]. ${ }^{12}$

Note that $\phi_{2}$ has a pole of order $k=6$ at $z=\infty$, where there are 4 anti-Stokes directions to which trajectories are asymptotic. The network has a double wall at the phases $\vartheta=\arg (m)+\pi / 2$ and $\vartheta=\arg (m)+3 \pi / 2$.
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)
(a) $\vartheta=(\pi / 2)^{-}$
![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)
(b) $\vartheta=\pi / 2$
![img-11.jpeg](img-11.jpeg)
(c) $\vartheta=(\pi / 2)^{+}$

Figure 9. The spectral network $\mathcal{W}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)$ with $\phi_{2}=\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$, shown here for $m<0$ and for phases $\vartheta$ before, at, and after the "critical phase" $\vartheta_{c}=\arg (m)+\pi / 2$. (The orientations of the walls are omitted.)
3.1.2. Spectral networks and nonabelian Hodge. Given a (possibly singular) SL(2)-Higgs bundle ( $E, \theta$ ) with harmonic metric $h$, we can consider the corresponding one-parameter family of flat connections

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{h}}, \quad \zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

We will associate to $(E, \theta, h)$ the spectral network

$$
\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}(\theta):=\mathcal{W}\left(\phi_{2}, \vartheta\right)
$$

where

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\phi_{2}=-\operatorname{det} \theta \\
\vartheta=\arg (\zeta)
\end{array}\right.
$$

With these choices:

- The spectral curve $\Sigma_{\phi_{2}}$ coincides with the Higgs spectral curve

$$
\Sigma_{\theta}:=\left\{\lambda \in T^{*} C: \operatorname{det}(\theta-\lambda I)=0\right\} \subseteq T^{*} C
$$

- The anti-Stokes rays of the network at each puncture coincide with the anti-Stokes rays of the connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ [GMN13b].
(This choice of network is also relevant for studying the WKB asymptotics of $\nabla_{\zeta}$ as $\zeta \rightarrow 0$, as discussed in [GMN13a, GMN13b].)

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{12}$ Due to differing sign conventions, these are obtained by using the quadratic differential $-\phi_{2}$ in the code.

Example 3.5. For $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$, the associated quadratic differential is $\phi_{2}=\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$, so the corresponding spectral network $\mathcal{W}=\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}(\theta)$ is one of those described in Example 3.4, i.e. it topologically looks like one of the networks in Figure 9.
3.1.3. Abelianization. Spectral networks can be used to lift nonabelian connections on the base surface to abelian connections on its cover. We continue to follow the presentation of [HN16]. As above, let $C$ be a compact Riemann surface with a spectral cover $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow C$ and a spectral network $\mathcal{W}$ (both arising from the same quadratic differential $\phi_{2}$ ). For simplicity we assume that $\mathcal{W}$ has no double walls. Let $\Sigma^{\prime}$ denote $\Sigma$ with the branch points removed.

Definition 3.6 (Abelianization via $\mathcal{W}$-pairs). A $\mathcal{W}$-pair is a tuple $\left(E, \nabla ; \mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}} ; \iota\right)$ where:

- $(E, \nabla)$ is a flat $\mathrm{SL}(2)$-bundle over $C$,
- $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ is a flat $\mathbb{C}^{+}$-bundle over $\Sigma^{\prime}$, and
- $\left.\iota: E\right|_{C \backslash \mathcal{W}} \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{*} \mathcal{L}\left|{ }_{C \backslash \mathcal{W}}\right.$ is an isomorphism, such that
(i) $\iota$ takes $\nabla$ to $\pi_{*} \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$,
(ii) at a wall $w$ of type $i j, \iota$ jumps by an automorphism

$$
S_{w}=\mathbb{1}+e_{w}
$$

of $\pi_{*} \mathcal{L} \cong \mathcal{L}_{1} \oplus \mathcal{L}_{2}$, where $e_{w}: \mathcal{L}_{i} \rightarrow \mathcal{L}_{j}$ (and the subscripts indicate the corresponding sheets of $\Sigma$ ).
In this case we call $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ an abelianization of $(E, \nabla)$, and $(E, \nabla)$ a nonabelianization of $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$.
More concretely, finding an abelianization of $(E, \nabla)$ amounts to specifying a basis of sections $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$ in each cell of $C \backslash \mathcal{W}$ which "diagonalize $\nabla$ " (that is, have $\nabla s_{i}=d_{i} s_{i}$ for some closed 1forms $d_{i}$ ) and have appropriate jumps at the walls of $\mathcal{W}$. For instance, condition (ii) says that on the two sides of a wall $w$ of type 21 , there are bases $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$ and $\left(s_{1}^{\prime}, s_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ related by

$$
s_{1}^{\prime}=s_{1} \quad \text { and } \quad s_{2}^{\prime}=s_{2}+\alpha s_{1}
$$

for some function $\alpha$, i.e the jump $S_{w}$ is unipotent and upper-triangular with respect to the trivialization $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$.

One consequence of the form of these jumps is that any abelianized connection $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ has holonomy -1 around the branch points of $\Sigma$; such a connection is called almost-flat. Another consequence is that any connection $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ satisfying Definition 3.6 but only defined over $\Sigma^{\prime} \backslash \pi^{-1}(\mathcal{W})$ automatically extends over the walls $\pi^{-1}(\mathcal{W})$. Therefore to construct an abelianization of $(E, \nabla)$ it suffices to provide an appropriate basis of $E$ in each cell of $C \backslash \mathcal{W}$.
3.1.4. Constructions and computations. Given $(E, \nabla)$ and $\mathcal{W}$, the choice of an abelianization $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ is generally not unique. This can be rectified by specifying an additional decoration called a " $\mathcal{W}$ framing". Roughly this is a choice of $\nabla$-invariant line subbundle at each puncture. We will explain how this works for irregular singularities, which is the only case we will encounter.

Construction 3.7 ( $\mathcal{W}$-framing with irregular punctures, cf. [GMN13b, Section 8]).
(1) Consider an infinitesimal circle around each singularity $p$ of order $k>2$, with $k-2$ marked points $q_{i}$ corresponding to the anti-Stokes directions of the foliation at $p .{ }^{13}$ Each wall ending at $p$ is asymptotic to one of the directions; we think of it as ending at the corresponding marked point. (See Figure 10.)

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{13}$ More precisely we could define the marked points on the real blow-up of $C$ at $p$, but we will be informal - this is ultimately just a labelling procedure.

![img-12.jpeg](img-12.jpeg)

Figure 10. Marked points for a pole of order $k=5$ at $p=\infty$. The dotted circle should be thought of as an infinitesimal circle around $\infty$.
(2) Choose a $\nabla$-invariant line subbundle $\ell_{i}$ of $E$ near each marked point ${ }^{14} q_{i}$. At any point $z \in C$ that can be joined to $q_{i}$ without crossing any walls, let $\ell_{i}(z)$ denote the parallel transport of $\ell_{i}$ to $E_{z}$. Assume that if two points $q_{i}$ and $q_{j}$ can be connected to a common point $z$ without crossing any walls, then $\ell_{i}(z) \neq \ell_{j}(z)$ (this holds generically).
(3) Choose sections $s_{i}$ such that $s_{i}(z) \in \ell_{i}(z)$.
(4) Each cell (without branch cuts) has trajectories of type 21 going into one point $q_{i}$, and trajectories of type 12 going into some $q_{j}$. Assign the basis $\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)$ to this cell, as shown in Figure 11.
![img-13.jpeg](img-13.jpeg)

Figure 11. $\mathcal{W}$-framing in a single cell. We make a choice of line subbundles $\ell_{i}$ near each marked point $q_{i}$, and the basis $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$ is chosen so that $s_{i}(z) \in \ell_{i}(z)$.
(4') If there are branch cuts, the notation is adjusted in the natural way (see Figure 12).
We can omit the labels 12 and 21 once we have specified a $\mathcal{W}$-framing, since they are determined by the labelling conventions.

The connection $\nabla$ is diagonal with respect to the basis $\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)$ in each cell. By construction, it can be viewed as the pushforward of a connection $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ on the line bundle $\mathcal{L}$ defined by $\ell_{i}$ and $\ell_{j}$ on the two sheets of $\Sigma$. By appropriately rescaling the sections

$$
s_{i}(z) \rightarrow \tilde{s}_{i}(z):=c_{i}(z) s_{i}(z)
$$

we can ensure they have the required unipotent jumps across walls to define $\iota$, but we can compute parallel transport even without rescaling.
Lemma 3.8 (Parallel transport formulas). Suppose $\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)$ and $\left(s_{k}, s_{j}\right)$ are sections diagonalizing $\nabla$ on either side of a wall $w$ of type 12, and view them as sections of the abelianized line bundle $\mathcal{L}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{14}$ or regular puncture, if there are any

![img-14.jpeg](img-14.jpeg)

Figure 12. $\mathcal{W}$-framing for the network from Figure 10. The order of the labelled sections is swapped upon crossing a branch cut.

Then the $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$-parallel transports of $s_{i}$ and $s_{j}$ across $w$ are given by

$$
s_{i} \mapsto \frac{s_{i} \wedge s_{j}}{s_{k} \wedge s_{j}} s_{k}
$$

and

$$
s_{j} \mapsto s_{j}
$$

Proof. From the triangular form of the jumps; see [HN16, Section 8.3].
As a useful mnemonic, note that the section $s_{i}$ associated to a puncture $q_{i}$ does not jump when crossing a wall going into $q_{i}$.
Remark 3.9 (Canonical decoration). When $\mathcal{W}=\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}(\theta)$ corresponds to an irregular connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$, there is a canonical "small flat section" $s_{i}$ near each $q_{i}$ which exponentially decays along the corresponding anti-Stokes ray [GMN13b]. We will use these sections as our decorations.
Example 3.10. The canonical $\mathcal{W}$-framing for a spectral network coming from $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ is shown in Figure 13, depending on the values of $m$ and $\zeta$. (The network has a double wall if $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)=0$, in which case it can be resolved into either of the ones shown.)
![img-15.jpeg](img-15.jpeg)

Figure 13. $\mathcal{W}$-framings for the two generic topologies of a spectral network $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$ coming from $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$. The canonical flat sections used for abelianization in each cell are labelled in green.

3.2. Framing near the punctures. Let $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$. Given a Higgs bundle $(E, \theta) \in \mathcal{H}$ with parameter $m \neq 0$, let

$$
\Sigma:=\left\{\lambda \in T^{*} C: \operatorname{det}(\theta-\lambda I)=0\right\} \subseteq T^{*} C
$$

be its spectral curve, with projection $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow C$. More explicitly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma & =\left\{\lambda \in T^{*} C: \lambda^{2}+\operatorname{det} \theta=0\right\} \\
& =\left\{\left(z \in C, s \in T_{z}^{*} C\right): s^{2}-\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}=0\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the notation of Section 3.1.1, $\Sigma=\Sigma_{\phi_{2}}$ for the quadratic differential $\phi_{2}=-\operatorname{det} \theta=\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$.
Note that $\Sigma$ is a branched double cover of $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ with two branch points at $z= \pm \sqrt{-2 m}$ and no ramification at $z=\infty$; consequently it has genus zero with two punctures lying over $\infty$. Let $\Sigma^{\prime}$ denote $\Sigma$ with the two branch points removed.

Remark 3.11 (Punctures and compactification). For notational purposes, we will refer to the two punctures of $\Sigma$ as $\infty_{-}$and $\infty_{+}$. We will not work directly with a compactification $\bar{\Sigma}=\Sigma \cup\left\{\infty_{ \pm}\right\}$, however; when we say "near $\infty_{ \pm}$", we just mean in the corresponding punctured neighbourhood on $\Sigma$.

Fix $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ and consider the flat connection $\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}\right)$ with associated spectral network $\mathcal{W}=$ $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}(\theta)$, as shown in Figure 13. The abelianization procedure uses $\mathcal{W}$ to define a rank 1 connection $\left(\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=\mathrm{ab}\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}\right)$ over the spectral cover $\Sigma$. The resulting connection $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ is almost-flat, i.e. it is flat on $\Sigma^{\prime}$ but has holonomy -1 around the branch points $b_{ \pm}=( \pm \sqrt{-2 m}, 0) \in \Sigma$.

Our first goal is to extend the abelianization correspondence to framed bundles, that is, to explain how abelianization of a framed connection $(E, \nabla, g)$ induces a framing upstairs for $\left(\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ near the punctures $\infty_{ \pm}$. We will show that there exists a natural frame $g_{\zeta, \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ with respect to which $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ is given by the diagonal entries of the singular part of $\nabla_{\zeta}$, so that $\left(\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{\zeta, \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ belongs to the following space of connections.
Definition 3.12 (Framed abelian bundles in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ ). For fixed $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, let $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ denote the set of framed almost-flat bundles $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ where:

- $\mathcal{L}$ is a holomorphic line bundle over $\Sigma$.
- $\nabla^{\text {ab }}$ is an almost-flat (complex) connection on $\mathcal{L}$ with irregular singularities at $\infty_{ \pm}$, of the form

$$
\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d \pm \pi^{*}\left[\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}+\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}+\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}+\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right]
$$

with respect to the framing $g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ near $\infty_{ \pm}$.
Say that $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \cong\left(\mathcal{L}^{\prime}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}, \prime}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}, \prime}\right)$ if there is a bundle isomorphism $\mathcal{L} \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{L}^{\prime}$ preserving the additional structure, and let $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ denote the set of isomorphism classes of $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$.

Remark 3.13 (Rigidity of framed form). This definition is more rigid than Definition 2.6 for the space $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ of nonabelian framed connections, in the following sense:

- For $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$, the framed form (2.8) of the connections $\nabla$ specified the singular terms, but allowed for unspecified regular terms. A gauge transformation approaching the identity near the puncture could still modify these regular terms.
- For $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$, we are fully specifying the form of $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$, i.e. specifying the singular terms and requiring that there are no additional regular terms. A gauge transformation preserving the framed form must therefore be identically equal to 1 near the punctures.

The abelianization construction requires a specification of flat sections $\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)$ in each cell of $\mathcal{W}$ (again see Figure 13). More generally we can look for a frame $\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right)$ in each cell with respect to which $\nabla$ is diagonal. We will use these formulations interchangeably: given a frame $\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right)$ with respect to which $\nabla$ is of the form

$$
\nabla=d+d Q+\Lambda \frac{d w}{w}+\Lambda^{\prime} \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}
$$

where $Q, \Lambda, \Lambda^{\prime}$ are diagonal, a corresponding frame of flat sections is given by

$$
\left(s_{i}, s_{j}\right)=\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right) \cdot w^{-\Lambda} \bar{w}^{-\Lambda^{\prime}} e^{-Q}
$$

and vice versa.
For now we will restrict our focus to a neighbourhood of the puncture. We assume for notational concreteness that $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$, but the argument for the other case is the same. Label the "big cells" near $w=0$ by $\mathcal{C}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{C}_{4}$, and label the two components of the "small cell" by $\mathcal{C}_{s, 1}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{s, 3}$, as shown in Figure 14a. We can choose the frames in each cell using a slight modification of the classical Stokes theory.
![img-16.jpeg](img-16.jpeg)
(a) Cells near $z=\infty$
![img-17.jpeg](img-17.jpeg)
(b) Choice of frames near $w=0$

Figure 14. The spectral network $\mathcal{W}$ in a neighbourhood of $w=0$, shown here for $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$. The walls are asymptotic to the anti-Stokes rays, which are labelled as in Figure 5. The indicated frames $\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right)$ diagonalize $\nabla$ in each cell (cf. Figure 13); those labelled in green can be obtained by restricting the sectorial frames from the classical theory.

Proposition 3.14 (Sectorial asymptotic existence in terms of $g$ ). In a neighbourhood of $w=0$ in each extended sector $\widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$, there is an invertible matrix $\widehat{\Sigma}_{i}$ of smooth functions such that $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has the diagonal form

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}=d+\left[-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right] H
$$

with respect to the sectorial frame $g \cdot \widehat{\Sigma}_{i}$.
Furthermore, each $\widehat{\Sigma}_{i} \rightarrow \mathbb{1}$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ in $\widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$.
Proof. See Appendix D.2.

We can thereby obtain the desired frames $\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right),\left(f_{3}, f_{2}\right),\left(f_{3}, f_{4}\right),\left(f_{1}, f_{4}\right)$ in the big cells by restricting each of the sectorial frames $g \cdot \check{\Sigma}_{i}$ from Sect $_{i}$ to $\mathcal{C}_{i}$. The corresponding flat sections $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right),\left(s_{3}, s_{2}\right),\left(s_{3}, s_{4}\right),\left(s_{1}, s_{4}\right)$ are the restrictions of the sectorially-defined sections $\Phi_{i}$ from the classical theory.

In fact, $f_{1}$ is also defined in the small cell $\mathcal{C}_{s, 1}$, so it only remains to extend $f_{3}$ to this region (and likewise with 1 and 3 swapped; i.e. we must describe the $f_{i}$ labelled in red in Figure 14b). To this end, we can analytically continue the corresponding flat section $s_{3}$ from $\mathcal{C}_{3}$ to $\mathcal{C}_{s, 1}$ (counterclockwise, say) using the differential equation $\nabla s_{3}=0$. The fact that $s_{1}$ and $s_{3}$ form a basis follows from the nonvanishing of Stokes data [Tul19, Proposition 3.11], i.e. that the Stokes matrix element $a$ is nonzero when $m \neq 0$. We can then get the desired frame $\left(f_{1}, f_{3}\right)$ from $\left(s_{1}, s_{3}\right)$ by using (3.16) with

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
Q=\frac{1}{2}\left(\zeta^{-1} w^{-2}+\zeta \bar{w}^{-2}\right) H \\
\Lambda=-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) H \\
\Lambda^{\prime}=-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) H
\end{array}\right.
$$

To summarize, we have chosen frames $\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right)$ in a neighbourhood of $w=0$ in each cell with respect to which the connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has the diagonal form (3.17). By construction, these frames glue together to give sections of the abelianized bundle near the punctures.
Corollary 3.15 (Induced frame for $\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ ). In a neighbourhood of each puncture $\infty_{ \pm}$of $\Sigma$, there exists a frame $g_{\zeta, \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ for $\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ with respect to which

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}=d \pm \pi^{*}\left[\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}+\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}+\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}+\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right]
$$

This gives us the desired framed abelianization map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{ab}: \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}} & \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}} \\
\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right) & \mapsto\left(\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{\zeta, \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which descends to a map of moduli spaces

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{ab}: \mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}} & \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}} \\
{\left[\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)\right] } & \mapsto\left[\left(\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{\zeta, \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 3.16 (Abelian moduli space expectations). Analogously to Remark 2.8 about $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, we will carry out calculations for $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ using the "obvious tangent spaces", and we expect (but will not prove or need) that ab gives an isomorphism of moduli spaces $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}} \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$.
3.3. Interlude: extending frames. Soon we will want to extend the frames $g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ of the bundles $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ from neighbourhoods of the punctures $\infty_{ \pm}$to the rest of $\Sigma$. We will address this problem here in slightly more generality.

Let $S=\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\left\{p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right\}$ be an $m$-punctured sphere, and let $L$ be a complex line bundle over $S$ with a flat $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connection $\nabla$. Choose a trivialization $\tau_{i}$ of $L$ in a neighbourhood $U_{i}$ of each puncture, and let $\alpha_{i}$ denote the corresponding connection form of $\nabla$. Let $\gamma_{i}$ be a counterclockwise loop around $p_{i}$ in $U_{i}$ (see Figure 15).

Lemma 3.17 (Global extension condition). The local trivializations $\tau_{i}$ extend to a global trivialization $\tau$ of $L$ if and only if

$$
\sum_{i} \int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha_{i}=0
$$

![img-18.jpeg](img-18.jpeg)

Figure 15. An $m$-punctured sphere $S$. Each puncture $p_{i}$ is surrounded by a loop $\gamma_{i}$, and a neighbourhood $U_{i}$ in which we have a fixed trivialization $\tau_{i}$ of the line bundle $L$ over $S$.

Proof. Any closed 1-form $\alpha$ which is defined on all of $S$ (e.g. the connection form of $\nabla$ with respect to a global trivialization) must satisfy

$$
\sum_{i} \int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha=0
$$

by Stokes' theorem, so the condition (3.22) is certainly necessary in order for the $\tau_{i}$ to extend.
Conversely, given local trivializations satisfying (3.22), we can produce an extension as follows. Begin by choosing an arbitrary global trivialization $\tau^{(0)}$ of $L$ on $S$ (which exists since $L$ is a complex line bundle over a punctured surface), and let $\alpha^{(0)} \in \Omega^{1}(S)$ be the corresponding connection form of $\nabla$. We want to find a gauge transformation $g: S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that $\nabla$ is of the desired form with respect to $g \tau^{(0)}$; that is, such that

$$
\left.\left(\alpha^{(0)}+d \log g\right)\right|_{U_{i}}=\alpha_{i} \quad \text { for each } i
$$

We split this up in two steps.
Step 1 (matching up the integrals): there is a gauge transformation $g^{(1)}: S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that $\alpha^{(1)}:=\alpha^{(0)}+d \log g^{(1)}$ satisfies

$$
\int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha^{(1)}=\int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha_{i} \quad \text { for each } i
$$

For this we can explicitly take

$$
g^{(1)}(z)=\prod_{i=1}^{m}\left(z-p_{i}\right)^{n_{i}}
$$

where

$$
n_{i}:=\frac{1}{2 \pi i}\left(\int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha_{i}-\int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha^{(0)}\right) \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

Note that $\sum n_{i}=0$ since both $\sum \int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha_{i}=0$ (by assumption) and $\sum \int_{\gamma_{i}} \alpha^{(0)}=0$ (since $\alpha^{(0)}$ is a globally defined closed 1-form), so $g^{(1)}$ indeed maps $S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$.

Step 2 (matching up the connection forms): there is a gauge transformation $g^{(2)}: S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that $\alpha^{(2)}:=\alpha^{(1)}+d \log g^{(2)}$ satisfies

$$
\left.\left.\alpha^{(2)}\right|_{U_{i}}=\alpha_{i} \quad \text { for each } i\right.
$$

Indeed, in each $U_{i}$ we can define

$$
