\left.g^{(2)}(z)\right|_{U_{i}}=\exp \left(\int_{\alpha}^{z} \alpha_{i}-\alpha^{(1)}\right)
$$

for some choice of basepoint $* \in U_{i}$. Then

$$
\int_{\gamma_{i}} d \log g^{(2)}=\int_{\gamma_{i}}\left(\alpha_{i}-\alpha^{(1)}\right)=0
$$

by (3.23). But on the other hand

$$
\int_{\gamma_{i}} d \log g^{(2)}=2 \pi i \cdot \operatorname{wind}_{0}\left(g^{(2)}\left(\gamma_{i}\right)\right)
$$

and so $g^{(2)}\left(\gamma_{i}\right) \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}$ has winding number zero around the origin for each $i$. Hence we can choose an extension of $g^{(2)}$ from the $U_{i}$ to all of $S$.

Combining these, the frame $\tau:=g^{(1)} g^{(2)} \tau^{(0)}$ gives us the desired global extension of the $\tau_{i}$.
Now we will apply this to the bundles $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ over the spectral curve $\Sigma$. In this case, by definition, we have trivializations $g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ near $\infty_{ \pm}$with respect to which $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ is of the prescribed form (3.14). We can further prescribe trivializations at the branch points $b_{ \pm} \in \Sigma$ (around which $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ has holonomy -1 ), as long as the condition (3.22) of the above lemma is still satisfied.

Corollary 3.18 (Global frame for $\mathcal{L}$ ). Given $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$, the frame $g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ extends to a global frame $g^{\mathrm{ab}}$ for $\mathcal{L}$ with respect to which:
(1) near each puncture $\infty_{ \pm}$,

$$
\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d \pm \pi^{*}\left[\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}+\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}+\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}+\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right]
$$

(2) near each branch point $b_{ \pm}$,

$$
\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d \pm \frac{d t_{ \pm}}{2 t_{ \pm}}
$$

where $t_{ \pm}$is a (fixed) coordinate for $\Sigma$ centred at $b_{ \pm}$.
Remark 3.19. For an abelianized bundle $\left(\mathcal{L}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{\zeta, \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=\operatorname{ab}\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)$, we can extend the frames $\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right)$ in each cell of the spectral network from a neighbourhood of $w=0$ to the entire cell by pushing down the extended frame $g^{\mathrm{ab}}$. By construction these frames diagonalize $\nabla_{\zeta}$ in the entire cell. However, we emphasize that we only have an explicit formula for the connection form near $w=0$.

# 4. REGULARIZED ATIYAH-BOTt FORMS 

We have now defined our main objects of study: the framed connections $(E, \nabla, g) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ over $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ and their abelianizations $\left(\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ over the spectral cover $\Sigma$. In this section we will define a regularized version of the Atiyah-Bott form on each of these spaces of connections, and show that it is preserved by abelianization.

The fact that abelianization preserves the standard Atiyah-Bott form is discussed in [GMN13a, Section 10.4] for connections on a closed surface with vanishing variations near the punctures, in which case the usual Atiyah-Bott formulas converge. In our case, the integrals

$$
\int_{C} \nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{\Sigma} \nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}
$$

are (logarithmically) divergent when the parameters $m$ and $m^{(3)}$ are allowed to vary, so we will need to incorporate a regularization term.

Remark 4.1 (Generalizations). The framed connections in $\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ have fixed higher-order singular terms, while their first-order singular part (i.e. the coefficients of $\frac{d w}{w}$ and $\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}$ ) can vary. Many of the definitions in this section would make sense more generally for similar spaces of connections (and on other punctured Riemann surfaces), but for simplicity we will just focus on the two relevant cases.
4.1. On the base curve. To start, we will restate the definition of $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ (cf. Definition I).

Let $C_{R}:=\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{|w|<R\}$, and write

$$
\mathfrak{h}:=\mathbb{C} \cdot H=\left\{\left(\begin{array}{cc}
a & 0 \\
0 & -a
\end{array}\right): a \in \mathbb{C}\right\} \subset \mathfrak{s l}(2, \mathbb{C})
$$

Recall that the framed connections $(E, \nabla, \underset{\varepsilon}{ })$ : $\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ are of the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla= & d-\zeta^{-1} H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta H \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) H \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) H \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}} \\
& + \text { regular terms }
\end{aligned}
$$

near $w=0$, and so their variations can be written

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \dot{\nabla}=-\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}-\frac{1}{2} \dot{m}^{(3)}\right) H \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \dot{\bar{m}}+\frac{1}{2} \dot{m}^{(3)}\right) H \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}+\text { regular terms } \\
& =-i\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}-\dot{m}^{(3)}-\zeta \bar{m}\right) H d \theta-\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}+\zeta \dot{\bar{m}}\right) H \frac{d r}{r}+\text { regular terms }
\end{aligned}
$$

in polar coordinates $w=r e^{i \theta}$. This is of the form

$$
\dot{\nabla}=(\mu+\mathcal{O}(r)) d \theta+(\lambda+\mathcal{O}(r)) \frac{d r}{r}
$$

for some $\mu, \lambda \in \mathfrak{h}$, namely

$$
\mu=-i\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}-\dot{m}^{(3)}-\zeta \bar{m}\right) H \quad \text { and } \quad \lambda=-\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}+\zeta \bar{m}\right) H
$$

Definition 4.2 (Regularized form). Define a regularized Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ by

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)=\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{C_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1} \wedge \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{R}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)
$$

and

$$
\dot{\nabla}_{i}=\left(\mu_{i}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left(\lambda_{i}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for some } \mu_{i}, \lambda_{i} \in \mathfrak{h}
$$

in polar coordinates $w=r e^{i \theta}$ near $w=0$.
Remark 4.3 (Regularization term). Using the coefficients (4.6), we can explicitly calculate the regularization term

$$
\begin{aligned}
-2 \pi \log R \cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)=-4 \pi i \log R[ & \left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{1}-\dot{m}_{1}^{(3)}-\zeta \dot{\bar{m}}_{1}\right)\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{2}+\zeta \dot{\bar{m}}_{2}\right) \\
& \left.-\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{2}-\dot{m}_{2}^{(3)}-\zeta \bar{m}_{2}\right)\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{1}+\zeta \bar{m}_{1}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 4.4 (L. Jeffrey form). A similar bilinear form appears in [lef94, Definition 3.2], under the identification of her half-open cylinder $[0, \infty) \times S^{1}$ with the punctured disc $\Delta^{\times}$via $(t, s) \mapsto e^{-t+2 \pi i s}$.

The form $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ has the following basic properties.
Lemma 4.5 (Convergence). For any variations $\dot{\nabla}_{1}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}$, the limit defining $\Omega^{\text {reg }}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)$ is convergent.

Proof. Fix a sufficiently small radius $R_{0}$ so that the framed form (4.4) holds for $|w|<R_{0}$. Consider the annulus $A_{R}:=\left\{R \leq|w| \leq R_{0}\right\}$, and split up

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=\underbrace{\int_{C_{R_{0}}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)}_{\text {finite }}+\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{A_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)-2 \pi \log R \cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)\right]
$$

Since

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1} \wedge \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)=\left[-\operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)+\mathcal{O}(r)\right] \frac{d r}{r} \wedge d \theta
$$

it follows that

$$
\int_{A_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)=2 \pi\left(\log R-\log R_{0}\right) \cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)+\mathcal{O}(1)
$$

and so the regularization term of $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ cancels out the divergent term as $R \rightarrow 0$.
Lemma 4.6 (Gauge invariance). $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ descends to a form on the moduli space $\mathcal{M}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}$.
Proof. Let $\mathcal{G}$ denote the group of gauge transformations $g: C \rightarrow \mathrm{GL}_{2}(\mathrm{C})$ which approach the identity near $w=0$ and preserve the framed form (4.2) of the connections $\nabla \in \mathcal{A}^{\text {fr }}$. We must show that $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ is basic with respect to the action of $\mathcal{G}$; that is, that:
(i) $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ is $\mathcal{G}$-invariant, and
(ii) $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ vanishes on vertical tangent vectors (i.e. along gauge orbits).

The first statement is just conjugation-invariance of the trace. For the second statement, the integral term of $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ vanishes along vertical tangent vectors by the usual Atiyah-Bott argument using Stokes' theorem (and the fact that $g \rightarrow$ id as $R \rightarrow 0$ ). The regularization term also vanishes because variations in the gauge direction have $\mu=\lambda=0$, since the gauge transformations preserve (4.2).

We will let $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg }}$ denote the form on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ obtained by pulling back $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ via $\mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}: \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, as well as the induced form on the moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (see Figure 16).
![img-19.jpeg](img-19.jpeg)

Figure 16. Forms induced by the regularized Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}$.

# 4.2. On the spectral cover. There is a natural analogue of Definition 4.2 for the abelianized connections on the spectral cover $\Sigma$, where now the regularization term involves contributions from both of the punctures $\infty_{ \pm}$. 

Write $\Sigma_{R}:=\pi^{-1}\left(C_{R}\right)$, where $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow C$ is the spectral cover.
Definition 4.7 (Regularized abelian form). Define a regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ by

$$
\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{\Sigma_{R}} \dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=2\left(\mu_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}-\mu_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

and

$$
\nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}=\left( \pm \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left( \pm \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for some } \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}} \in \mathbb{C}
$$

in polar coordinates $(r, \theta)$ centred at each puncture $\infty_{\mp} .^{15}$
Remark 4.8. Because of the rigid prescribed framed form (3.14) of the connections $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}} \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ (cf. Remark 3.13), their variations are exactly of the form

$$
\nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}= \pm \mu^{\mathrm{ab}} d \theta \pm \lambda^{\mathrm{ab}} \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for some } \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}} \in \mathbb{C}
$$

i.e. the $\mathcal{O}(r)$ terms in (4.13) are actually zero. This will not be needed for the arguments below, however, and the more general definition will carry over to the semiflat setting in Section 6.3.

The values $\mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ and $\lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ for the abelianized variations $\nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ are just the diagonal entries of $\mu_{i}$ and $\lambda_{i}$ for $\nabla_{i}$, that is,

$$
\mu_{i}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}},-\mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \lambda_{i}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}},-\lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

and so

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{2}-\mu_{2} \lambda_{1}\right)=2\left(\mu_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}-\mu_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

Corollary 4.9 (Abelianization preserves regularization terms).

$$
\mathcal{R}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=\mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

i.e. $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ and $\Omega^{\text {reg }}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)$ have the same regularization terms, namely given by (4.10).
4.3. Regularization and abelianization. Now we show that as expected, abelianization preserves the regularized forms. (This is equality (1.14) in the schematic commutative diagram (1.4).)

Proposition 4.10 ("Abelianization is a symplectomorphism"). As forms on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$,

$$
\mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}=\Omega^{\text {reg }}
$$

i.e.

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

By Corollary 4.9, the regularization terms appearing in both of the forms are the same, so we only need to compare the two integrals

$$
\int_{\mathbb{C}_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{\Sigma_{R}} \nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}
$$

which are regularized as $R \rightarrow 0$. This boils down to a local calculation as argued in [GMN13a, Section 10.4]. The main idea is that the Stokes jump upon crossing a wall of the spectral network should be thought of as contributing an off-diagonal (delta function valued) term to the variations, whose product with the other diagonal terms is traceless.

For completeness we include a slightly expanded version of their proof below. We will not say anything fundamentally new, but will emphasize how some of the details fit in with our setup and "smooth out the delta function" to remain in the $C^{\infty}$ setting.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{15}$ More generally we could define $\mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=\left(\mu_{1}^{+} \lambda_{2}^{+}-\mu_{2}^{+} \lambda_{1}^{+}\right)+\left(\mu_{1}^{-} \lambda_{2}^{-}-\mu_{2}^{-} \lambda_{1}^{-}\right)$for variations of the form $\nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}=\left(\mu_{i}^{ \pm}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left(\lambda_{i}^{ \pm}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r}$ near $\infty_{ \pm}$.

Proof. If the variations $\dot{\nabla}_{i}$ have support $V$ away from the walls of the spectral network $\mathcal{W}$, then $\nabla_{i}=\left.\pi_{*} \nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$, and so $\left.\operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)\right|_{V}$ is just the sum of $\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ on the two sheets of $\pi^{-1}(V)$.

Suppose the support of a variation, say $\nabla_{1}$, intersects $\mathcal{W}$. We can assume the gauge has been chosen so that $\nabla_{1}$ vanishes near the branch points, so it suffices to consider the intersection with a single wall $w$. For simplicity, choose coordinates $(x, y)$ on $C$ so that the wall is at $y=0$.

Let $f=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)$ and $f^{\prime}=\left(f_{1}^{\prime}, f_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ be frames below and above the wall (see Figure 17) which diagonalize

$$
\nabla=d+\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\beta^{-} & \\
& \beta^{+}
\end{array}\right)
$$

They are related by $f^{\prime}=f \cdot S$ for a unipotent and (without loss of generality) upper-diagonal Stokes matrix

$$
S=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & \alpha \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

In order to obtain a single frame with which to compute variations of $\nabla$, we interpolate between $f$ and $f^{\prime}$ as follows. Let $\bar{w}$ be a thickening of the wall $w$ to some region $-\varepsilon<y<\varepsilon$ inside of which the Stokes matrix element $\alpha$ is defined. Let $\eta$ be a smooth cutoff function with

$$
\eta(x, y)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { for } y<-\varepsilon \\ 1 & \text { for } y>\varepsilon\end{cases}
$$

Then the frame $\bar{f}:=f \cdot \bar{S}$, where

$$
\bar{S}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & \eta \alpha \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

smoothly interpolates between $f$ and $f^{\prime}$.
![img-20.jpeg](img-20.jpeg)

Figure 17. Here the support $V$ of the variations intersects a wall $w$ of the spectral network. The frames $f$ and $f^{\prime}$ are used for abelianization on each side of the wall. We interpolate between them using a cutoff function $\eta$ which smoothly goes from 0 to 1 as we move through the thickened wall $\bar{w}$.

With respect to $\bar{f}$ inside $\bar{w}$,

$$
\nabla=d+\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & d(\eta \alpha) \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\beta^{-} & \eta \alpha\left(\beta^{-}-\beta^{+}\right) \\
0 & \beta^{+}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and so variations are of the form

$$
\dot{\nabla}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & * \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\dot{\beta}^{-} & * \\
0 & \dot{\beta}^{+}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Crucially, the off-diagonal term does not contribute to $\operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)$, and we again get

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)=\dot{\beta}_{1}^{-} \wedge \dot{\beta}_{2}^{-}+\dot{\beta}_{1}^{+} \wedge \dot{\beta}_{2}^{+}
$$

the sum of $\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ on the two sheets.

Remark 4.11. To avoid potential confusion, we emphasize that the argument above does not say that

$$
\int_{C_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{\Sigma_{R}} \nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}
$$

are equal at a finite radius $R>0$. In fact, the first integral is not even invariant under gauge transformations that approach the identity near $z=\infty$ (which we utilized in the above proof). In order to obtain a gauge-invariant equality, we really need the full regularized integrals
$\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{C_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)\right]=\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{\Sigma_{R}} \nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)\right]$.

# 5. GLUED SYMPLECTIC FORM 

In the previous section we showed that we can study the regularized Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ via its abelian analogue $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$. To relate this to the Ooguri-Vafa form, we will introduce an intermediary glued symplectic form $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$. Then, using a kind of "glued Riemann bilinear identity" and the geometry of the relevant spectral networks, we will show that $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ are Darboux coordinates for $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$.

This section is dedicated to explaining the construction of $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ and proving the following equalities of forms. (These are respectively (1.18) and (1.20) in the commutative diagram (1.4).)
Proposition 5.1 (Gluing and regularization).

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue }}=\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}
$$

i.e. the glued form $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ coincides with the regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$.

Proposition 5.2 (Gluing and Ooguri-Vafa).

$$
\mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue }}=-4 \pi^{2} \cdot \Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\text {ov }}
$$

i.e. the pullback of the glued form $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ to $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$ coincides with the Ooguri-Vafa form $\Omega_{\text {Stokes }}^{\text {ov }}$.

Combining these with Proposition 4.10, we will obtain our first main result:
Theorem 5.3 (Ooguri-Vafa and regularization). Under the identification of spaces $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{reg}}
$$

i.e. the Ooguri-Vafa symplectic form coincides with the regularized Atiyah-Bott form, pulled back to $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$.
5.1. General gluing construction on a cylinder. First we will describe a general construction for a closed 2 -form on a moduli space of framed flat $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connections on a cylinder. Roughly, it will be induced from the Atiyah-Bott symplectic form on the torus by gluing the ends of the cylinder together and choosing a family of gauge transformations to glue the connections.
(a) topological setup:

Fix a topological cylinder $S$, and let $S_{\text {top }}$ and $S_{\text {bot }}$ denote neighbourhoods of its two boundary components. Choose an orientation-reversing diffeomorphism $\sigma: S_{\text {top }} \xrightarrow{\sim} S_{\text {bot }}$ with which we can glue the ends together to form a torus $T=S / \sigma$.

Let $a$ and $b$ be paths as indicated in Figure 18 (so that their classes form a homology basis for $T$ after gluing), and let $p_{0}$ denote their point of intersection on the top boundary edge.
(b) framed connections:

Identify the space of smooth $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connections on the trivial bundle over $S$ with $\Omega^{1}(S)$. Then consider a space $\mathcal{A}_{S}$ of flat connections, consisting of closed 1-forms $\alpha \in \Omega^{1}(S)$ which

![img-21.jpeg](img-21.jpeg)

Figure 18. A cylinder $S$ with a loop $a$ and a longitudinal path $b$ from $p_{0}$ to $\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)$, glued to a torus $T$ via $\sigma$.
are of some prescribed "framed form" in a neighbourhood of the boundary $\partial S .{ }^{16}$ Let $\mathcal{G}_{S}$ denote the set of gauge transformations $g: S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that $g \equiv 1$ in a neighbourhood of $\partial S$. Then we can define a moduli space $\mathcal{M}_{S}:=\mathcal{A}_{S} / \mathcal{G}_{S}$ of framed flat connections on $S$.

Remark 5.4 (L. Jeffrey moduli spaces). Unlike the standard moduli spaces of connections on a surface with boundary, the boundary holonomies of our connections are not fixed. Our definition of $\mathcal{M}_{S}$ is similar to (an abelian version of) the "extended moduli spaces" of [Jef94], which consist of framed connections whose boundary holonomies are allowed to vary, although we will prescribe a slightly different framed form.
(c) gluing data:

Connections on $S$ can be "glued" to $T$ by making suitable gauge transformations.
To construct the space of connections on the torus $T$, note that a 1-form $\beta \in \Omega^{1}(S)$ is pulled back from $\Omega^{1}(T)$ if and only if $\left.\beta\right|_{\text {top }}=\sigma^{*} \beta \mid{ }_{\text {top }}$, so we can write

$$
\mathcal{A}_{T}:=\left\{\beta \in \Omega^{1}(S): d \beta=\left.0, \beta\right|_{\text {top }}=\sigma^{*} \beta \mid_{\text {top }}\right\}
$$

Similarly, let $\mathcal{G}_{T}$ be the set of gauge transformations $g: S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$ with $\left.g\right|_{\text {top }}=\sigma^{*} g \mid$ top. Then $\mathcal{M}_{T}:=\mathcal{A}_{T} / \mathcal{G}_{T}$ is the (usual) moduli space of flat $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connections on the torus.

Given a connection form $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{S}$ (not necessarily in $\mathcal{A}_{T}$ ), choose a smooth gauge transformation $g=e^{\chi}: S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that

$$
\left.(\alpha-d \chi)\right|_{\text {top }}=\sigma^{*}(\alpha-d \chi) \mid \text { top }
$$

(We emphasize that such a gauge transformation $g$ is generally nontrivial on $\partial S$.) Then $\alpha-d \chi \in \mathcal{A}_{T}$, i.e. we can regard $\alpha-d \chi$ as a connection form on $T$.

Remark 5.5 ( $\chi$-dependence). The following gluing construction will depend on the choice of $\chi$, but only in a neighbourhood of $\partial S$. Indeed, $g=e^{\chi}$ extends from $\partial S$ to $S$ if $\chi$ satisfies the winding number compatibility condition

$$
\int_{a} d \chi=\int_{a} \sigma^{*} d \chi
$$

(cf. the proof of Lemma 3.17), and any two such extensions will be gauge equivalent by a map in $\mathcal{G}_{T}$. Therefore it will be enough to just specify $\left.\chi\right|_{\text {top }}$ and $\left.\chi\right|_{\text {bot }}$ satisfying (5.5).

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{16}$ Soon we will specify precise boundary conditions, but for now we are just interested in the formal setup.

Now suppose we have a smoothly varying family of such maps $\chi=\chi(\alpha)$ for each $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{S}$, and package them into a "connection gluing map"

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Gamma_{\chi}: \mathcal{A}_{S} & \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{T} \\
\alpha & \mapsto \alpha-d \chi
\end{aligned}
$$

Assume further that the choice of $\chi$ is gauge invariant in the sense that $\chi(\alpha)=\chi\left(\alpha^{\prime}\right)$ when $\alpha$ and $\alpha^{\prime}$ are gauge equivalent. ${ }^{17}$ Then it follows that $\Gamma_{\chi}$ descends to a map of moduli spaces

$$
\widetilde{\Gamma}_{\chi}: \mathcal{M}_{S} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{T}
$$

Remark 5.6 (Symmetric gluing). We could, for instance, choose $\chi$ so that

$$
d \chi=\frac{\alpha-\sigma^{*} \alpha}{2}
$$

on both the top and bottom of $S$. This satisfies the gluing condition (5.4), with

$$
\sigma^{*}(\alpha-d \chi)=\frac{\alpha+\sigma^{*} \alpha}{2}=\alpha-d \chi
$$

and the compatibility condition (5.5), with

$$
\int_{a} d \chi=0=\int_{a} \sigma^{*} d \chi
$$

(since $\int_{a} \alpha=\int_{a} \sigma^{*} \alpha$ ). We will call (5.8) the symmetric gluing condition, since the formula is the same on both boundary components.

Recall that the moduli space $\mathcal{M}_{T}$ of flat $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-connections on the torus carries the abelian AtiyahBott symplectic form $\widehat{\Omega}_{T}^{\mathrm{AB}}$, induced from the form

$$
\Omega_{T}^{\mathrm{AB}}\left(\dot{\beta}_{1}, \dot{\beta}_{2}\right)=\int_{T} \dot{\beta}_{1} \wedge \dot{\beta}_{2}
$$

on $\mathcal{A}_{T}$, where $\dot{\beta}_{i}$ are variations of $\beta \in \mathcal{A}_{T}$. The desired glued form on $S$ will be obtained by pulling back the Atiyah-Bott form via $\Gamma_{\chi}$.

Definition 5.7 (Glued form). Define a glued form on $\mathcal{A}_{S}$ by

$$
\omega_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}:=\left(\Gamma_{\chi}\right)^{*} \Omega_{T}^{\mathrm{AB}}
$$

i.e.

$$
\omega_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)=\int_{S}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}-d \dot{\chi}_{1}\right) \wedge\left(\dot{\alpha}_{2}-d \dot{\chi}_{2}\right)
$$

where $\dot{\alpha}_{i}$ are variations of $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{S}$ and $\dot{\chi}_{i}$ are the corresponding induced variations of $\chi(\alpha)$.
The glued form on $\mathcal{A}_{S}$ descends to a form

$$
\widetilde{\omega}_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}=\left(\widetilde{\Gamma}_{\chi}\right)^{*} \widetilde{\Omega}_{T}^{\mathrm{AB}}
$$

on the moduli space $\mathcal{M}_{S}$. Abusing notation, we will denote both forms by $\omega_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}$ (see Figure 19).
The upshot of this construction is that $\omega_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}$ can be computed using the following expressions, which can be thought of as a kind of "Riemann bilinear identity on the cylinder" with correction terms involving $\chi$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{17}$ In practice this is not a restrictive assumption: if $\alpha$ and $\alpha^{\prime}$ are gauge equivalent on $S$, then they agree in a neighbourhood of $\partial S$, and so the condition will automatically be satisfied if the choice of $\chi(\alpha)\left|{ }_{d S}\right.$ depends only on $\left.\alpha\right|_{d S}$.

![img-22.jpeg](img-22.jpeg)

Figure 19. Forms induced by the abelian Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega_{T}^{\mathrm{AB}}$ on the torus $T$.
Proposition 5.8 (Glued bilinear identity).

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right) & =\int_{S} \dot{\alpha}_{1} \wedge \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\int_{\partial S}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2} \dot{\alpha}_{1}-\dot{\chi}_{1} \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\dot{\chi}_{1} d \dot{\chi}_{2}\right) \\
& =\int_{a} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{2}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)-\int_{a} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\left(\dot{\chi}_{1}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{1}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. The first expression is obtained by directly expanding (5.11) and using Stokes' theorem, along with the fact that the $\dot{\alpha}_{i}$ are closed.

The second is obtained by viewing $\dot{\alpha}_{i}-d \dot{\chi}_{i}$ as forms on the torus $T$ and applying the usual Riemann bilinear identity

$$
\omega_{S, \chi}^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)=\int_{a}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}-d \dot{\chi}_{1}\right) \int_{b}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{2}-d \dot{\chi}_{2}\right)-\int_{a}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{2}-d \dot{\chi}_{2}\right) \int_{b}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}-d \dot{\chi}_{1}\right)
$$

(this also uses closedness of the $\dot{\alpha}_{i}$ ). Viewing the individual components as forms on $S$ again, $\int_{a} d \dot{\chi}_{i}=0$ and $\int_{b} d \dot{\chi}_{i}=\dot{\chi}_{i}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)-\dot{\chi}_{i}\left(p_{0}\right)$, so the result follows.
Remark 5.9. For our later application, note that the calculations in the above proof only used the fact that the variations $\dot{\alpha}_{i}$ were closed forms, not the stronger condition that the original connection was flat.

Once we further specialize the gluing setup, we will use (5.13) to identify $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ with the regularized Atiyah-Bott form on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$, and interpret (5.14) in terms of the Ooguri-Vafa twistor coordinates $\mathcal{X}_{r}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$.
5.2. Gluing on $\Sigma$ with a cutoff. Fix $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ and consider the abelianized connections in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ (from Definition 3.12). We will apply the preceding gluing construction to a subset of the spectral curve $\Sigma$ obtained by removing two discs around the punctures, namely $\Sigma_{r}:=\Sigma \backslash \pi^{-1}\left(D_{r}\right)$, where $D_{r}=\{|w|<r\} \subseteq \mathbb{C P}^{1}$ (see Figure 20). We will refer to the boundary edge around $\infty_{-}$as the top of $\Sigma_{r}$. Assume that the cutoff radius $r$ is sufficiently small so that the trivializations (3.24) for $\nabla^{\text {ab }}$ hold in neighbourhoods of the top and bottom of $\Sigma_{r}$.

We will explain how to use the gluing construction to obtain the desired form $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$.
Remark 5.10 (Variations of abelianized connections). There are two preliminary technicalities to address regarding variations of elements $\left(\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$.

- The spectral curve $\Sigma \supset \Sigma_{r}$ is itself defined in terms of the parameter $m$, so it varies with $\nabla^{\text {ab }}$. However, the resulting surfaces are diffeomorphic for all nonzero $m$, so we will identify them all with a fixed reference surface. Similarly, we will identify the varying bundles $\mathcal{L}^{\text {ab }}$ over $\Sigma$ with a fixed (trivial) bundle using the global frame $g^{\text {ab }}$ from from Corollary 3.18.
- The general gluing construction was described for flat connections, but $\nabla^{\text {ab }}$ is only almostflat. However, its prescribed connection form $\alpha$ is constant in a neighbourhood of the branch points (see (3.25)), so its variations are zero there, and thus $\dot{\alpha}$ is a closed 1-form

![img-23.jpeg](img-23.jpeg)

Figure 20. The cut off cylinder $\Sigma_{r}$ inside the spectral curve $\Sigma_{r}$ and its projection to $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ in a neighbourhood of $w=0$.
defined on all of $\Sigma_{r}$. The formulas for the glued bilinear identity in Proposition 5.8 therefore still apply (see Remark 5.9).

At first we will consider a slightly more general choice of path $b_{r}$ that winds around the cylinder $\frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi}$ times. (Eventually we will choose a specific basepoint $p_{0}$ and angle $\vartheta$ using the geometry of the relevant spectral network, but the construction makes sense more generally.)

We run the construction from Section 5.1 with the following data:
(a) topological setup:

Fix the cylinder $S=\Sigma_{r} \subseteq \Sigma$. Consider the map $\sigma=\sigma_{\vartheta}: \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma$,

$$
\sigma(w, s)=\left(e^{i \vartheta} \bar{w},-s\right)
$$

which restricts to an orientation-reversing diffeomorphism between neighbourhoods of the top and bottom of $\Sigma_{r}$. Let $\Sigma_{r, \text { top }} \xrightarrow{\sim} \Sigma_{r, \text { bot }}$ be two such neighbourhoods, chosen sufficiently small so that the prescribed framed form (3.24) holds.

As in Figure 20, let $a$ be the boundary loop around $\infty \ldots$ Choose a base point $p_{0}$ along $a$, and let $b_{r}=b_{r}\left(p_{0}, \vartheta\right)$ be the open path from $p_{0}$ to $\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)$, winding around the cylinder $\frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi}$ times in the same direction as $a$ (see Figure 21).
![img-24.jpeg](img-24.jpeg)

Figure 21. Path $b_{r}=b_{r}\left(p_{0}, \vartheta\right)$ winding around $\Sigma_{r}$, with $\vartheta=\pi / 2$.

(b) framed connections:

Consider the space $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr.ab }}$ of connections $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d+\alpha$, trivialized using the frames $g^{\mathrm{ab}}$ from Corollary 3.18 so that near the boundary they have the prescribed form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\alpha\right|_{\text {top }}=\pi^{*}\left[-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right] \\
& \left.\alpha\right|_{\text {bot }}=\pi^{*}\left[\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}+\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}+\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}+\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the allowable gauge transformations in this setting are identically equal to 1 near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ (see Remark 3.13), which is consistent with the general gluing construction.

For notational purposes, let

$$
\alpha_{0}:=-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}
$$

and introduce the sign

$$
\varepsilon:=\left\{\begin{aligned}
+1 & \text { on } \Sigma_{r, \text { top }} \\
-1 & \text { on } \Sigma_{r, \text { bot }}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

so that we can write

$$
\alpha=\varepsilon \cdot \pi^{*} \alpha_{0}
$$

near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$. In what follows we will usually suppress $\pi^{*}$ from the notation.
(c) gluing data:

Explicitly, the symmetric gluing condition (5.8) for $\chi$ becomes

$$
d \chi=\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\left[-\left(\zeta^{-1}+\zeta e^{2 i \vartheta}\right) \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\left(\zeta+\zeta^{-1} e^{-2 i \vartheta}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m+\zeta \bar{m}\right)\left(\frac{d w}{w}+\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)\right]
$$

In order to specify our choice of $\chi$ it will be useful to introduce some more notation:

- Define an antiderivative of $\alpha$ in a neighbourhood of $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ by

$$
A:=\varepsilon \cdot \pi^{*} A_{0}
$$

where
$A_{0}(w)=\frac{1}{2} \zeta^{-1} w^{-2}+\frac{1}{2} \zeta \bar{w}^{-2}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \log w-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \log \bar{w}$.
(Note that $A_{0}$ is the same function (2.12) appearing in the normalization condition for the canonical flat sections $s_{i}$.) Then $d A_{0}=\alpha_{0}$, and so $d A=\alpha$ near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$.

- Let

$$
x_{e}:=-2 \pi i\left(\zeta^{-1} m-m^{(3)}-\zeta \bar{m}\right)
$$

so that

$$
\mathcal{X}_{e}=\exp \left(x_{e}\right)
$$

Then $A_{0}$ has monodromy $A_{0} \rightarrow A_{0}+x_{e}$ around $w=0$.
We will choose the gluing map

$$
\chi=\frac{A-\sigma^{*} A}{2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \cdot \frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi} x_{e}
$$

to satisfy the symmetric condition (5.8). (Note that $\chi$ is single-valued even though $A_{0}$ has monodromy.) The $-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \cdot \frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi} x_{e}$ term was chosen so that the explicit expansion

$$
\chi=\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\zeta^{-1}+\zeta e^{2 i \vartheta}\right) w^{-2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\zeta+\zeta^{-1} e^{-2 i \vartheta}\right) \bar{w}^{-2}-2\left(\zeta^{-1} m+\zeta \bar{m}\right) \log |w|\right]
$$

has no constant term.

Construction 5.11 (Glued form $\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}$ ). For any choice of path $b_{r}=b_{r}\left(p_{0}, \vartheta\right)$ as above, the gluing construction produces a form

$$
\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}:=\omega_{\Sigma_{r}, \chi}^{\text {glue }}
$$

on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ (and its moduli space $\mathcal{M}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{ab}}$ ). According to Proposition 5.8, it can be calculated by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)= & \int_{\Sigma_{r}} \dot{\alpha}_{1} \wedge \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\int_{a \Sigma_{r}}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2} \dot{\alpha}_{1}-\dot{\chi}_{1} \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\dot{\chi}_{1} d \dot{\chi}_{2}\right) \\
= & \int_{a} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{2}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b_{r}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right) \\
& \quad-\int_{a} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\left(\dot{\chi}_{1}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{1}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b_{r}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In Section 5.5 we will specify the correct choice of path $b_{r}$, but first we will discuss how to interpret the above integrals more generally.
5.3. Gluing and regularization. The two formulas (5.27) and (5.28) for $\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}$ can each be thought of as corresponding to a certain kind of regularization, as alluded to in Section 1.2.4.
5.3.1. Regularization for parallel transport. First we will consider the expressions

$$
\int_{b_{r}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha:=\chi\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b_{r}} \alpha
$$

whose variations appear in (5.28).
Using the formula (5.25) for $\chi$ in terms of the antiderivative $A$ of $\alpha$ near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$, we can rewrite

$$
\int_{b_{r}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha=\left(A\left(p_{0}\right)-A\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b_{r}} \alpha\right)-\frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi} x_{e}
$$

It follows that the expressions $\int_{b_{r}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha$ are independent of $r$ (assuming, as always, that $r$ is sufficiently small so that the setup for the gluing construction is defined). This suggests an interpretation of the gluing map as a means of regularizing the divergent integral

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0} \int_{b_{r}} \alpha
$$

and calculating the (log of the) holonomy of the framed connection $\nabla=d+\alpha$ along an open path; cf. the discussion of regularized parallel transports in Section 1.2.3. We will show in Section 5.5 that by choosing $b_{r}$ appropriately we can identify the bracketed expression in (5.30) with the logarithm of the magnetic coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}$.

Taking variations, we see that none of the factors $\left(\dot{\chi}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b_{r}} \dot{\alpha}\right)$ or $\int_{a} \dot{\alpha}$ appearing in the expression (5.28) for $\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}$ depend on $r$.

Corollary 5.12 ( $r$-independence of $\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}$ ). The form $\Omega_{r}^{\text {glue }}$ is independent of $r$.
We will henceforth drop the $r$ subscript and just write $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$.
5.3.2. Regularization for the Atiyah-Bott form. Switching to the other expression (5.27) for $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$, we will now consider the boundary integral

$$
\mathcal{R}_{r}^{X}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right):=\int_{a \Sigma_{r}}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2} \dot{\alpha}_{1}-\dot{\chi}_{1} \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\dot{\chi}_{1} d \dot{\chi}_{2}\right)
$$

Remark 5.13 (Explicit boundary integral). In the current setting, we have explicit closed formulas for $\chi$ and $\alpha$ near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$, so we can directly calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{R}_{r}^{X}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=-4 \pi i \log & r\left[\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{1}-\dot{m}_{1}^{(3)}-\zeta \ddot{m}_{1}\right)\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{2}+\zeta \ddot{m}_{2}\right)\right. \\
& \left.-\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{2}-\dot{m}_{2}^{(3)}-\zeta \dot{m}_{2}\right)\left(\zeta^{-1} \dot{m}_{1}+\zeta \dot{m}_{1}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

This coincides with the regularization term $-2 \pi \log r \cdot \mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)$ of the regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$ (see Corollary 4.9), and so it follows that $\Omega^{\text {glue }}=\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$. This proves Proposition 5.1.

It will be useful for later (and perhaps more enlightening) to give a more general argument in terms of the gluing map (5.25). The same proof will carry over to the semiflat setting in Section 6.4.2.

Alternative proof of Proposition 5.1. First, we can rewrite

$$
\mathcal{R}_{r}^{X}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)=\int_{a}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2} \cdot\left(\dot{\alpha}_{1}+\sigma^{*} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{1} \cdot\left(\dot{\alpha}_{2}+\sigma^{*} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right)\right)
$$

using that $\int_{a \pi}(\cdot)=\int_{a}(\cdot)-\int_{a} \sigma^{*}(\cdot)$ and $\sigma^{*} \chi=-\chi$. If we express the variations in polar coordinates near each puncture $\infty_{ \pm}$(cf. (4.13)) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\alpha}_{i} & =\left( \pm \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left( \pm \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for some } \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}} \in \mathbb{C} \\
& =\varepsilon\left[\left(\mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

then the terms appearing in (5.33) are

$$
\dot{\alpha}_{i}+\sigma^{*} \dot{\alpha}_{i}=2 \varepsilon\left(\mu_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta
$$

and

$$
\dot{\chi}_{i}=\varepsilon\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \log r
$$

We can therefore write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{R}_{r}^{X}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) & =2 \log r \int_{a}\left[\left(\lambda_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right)\left(\mu_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right)-\left(\lambda_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right)\left(\mu_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right)\right] d \theta \\
& =-2 \pi \log r \cdot\left[2\left(\mu_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}-\mu_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)+\mathcal{O}(r)\right] \\
& =-2 \pi \log r \cdot\left[\mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)+\mathcal{O}(r)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

using the general definition (4.12) of $\mathcal{R}^{\text {ab }}$. But on the other hand we know that

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \int_{\Sigma_{r}} \dot{\alpha}_{1} \wedge \dot{\alpha}_{2}+\mathcal{R}_{r}^{X}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

is $r$-independent, so it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega^{\text {glue }}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right) & =\lim _{r \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{\Sigma_{r}} \dot{\alpha}_{1} \wedge \dot{\alpha}_{2}-2 \pi \log r \cdot \mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)\right] \\
& =\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{ab}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

5.4. Interpreting the electric twistor coordinate. Now we return to the question of interpreting $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ in terms of the integrals

$$
\int_{a} \alpha \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{b_{r}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha=\chi\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{b_{r}} \alpha
$$

We will start with the electric twistor coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ as a quick sanity check. Using the expression (5.16) for $\left.\alpha\right|_{\text {top }}$, we can directly compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{a} \alpha & =\int_{a}\left(-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right) \\
& =2 \pi i\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\zeta \bar{m}-m^{(3)}\right) \\
& =-x_{e}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is consistent with the interpretation of $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ in terms of the formal monodromy of $\nabla_{\zeta}$ [Tul19].
We will henceforth call $a=\gamma_{e}$, so that we have the following integral interpretation of $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ as a holonomy along $\gamma_{e}$.

Proposition 5.14 ( $\gamma_{e}$ integral). For a connection $\nabla \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ with abelianization $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d+\alpha$,

$$
\exp \left(-\int_{\gamma_{e}} \alpha\right)=\mathcal{X}_{e}(\nabla)
$$

# 5.5. Interpreting the magnetic twistor coordinate. 

5.5.1. Choice of path $\gamma_{m}$. In order to relate

$$
\int_{b_{r}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha
$$

to the magnetic coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}$, the desired path $\gamma_{m}=b_{r}\left(p_{0}, \vartheta\right)$ will be described in terms of the spectral network on the cut off double cover $\Sigma_{r}$, as shown in Figure 22 below.
![img-25.jpeg](img-25.jpeg)
(a) $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$
![img-26.jpeg](img-26.jpeg)
(b) $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0$

Figure 22. The relevant paths $\gamma_{e}, \gamma_{m}$ and spectral network $\mathcal{W}_{\zeta}$ on the cut off double cover $\Sigma_{r}$, with four points $p_{i}^{t}$ or $p_{i}^{b}$ lying on the indicated sheets and anti-Stokes rays.

Recall that $\gamma_{e}=a$ is the boundary loop around $\infty_{-}$, i.e. the circle $|w|=r$ on the top sheet. Define the four points

$$
p_{1}^{t}, p_{2}^{b}, p_{3}^{t}, p_{4}^{b} \in \partial \Sigma_{r}
$$

that lie on the anti-Stokes ray indicated by their subscripts and the sheet indicated by their superscripts. (We will sometimes omit the superscripts if we do not need to emphasize them.)

Take $\gamma_{m}$ to be a path from $p_{3}^{t}$ to $p_{2}^{b}$ that winds around the branch point in the triangle 123 (cf. [GMN13b, Section 9.4.3]). We will choose the gluing angle $\vartheta$ so that the map $\sigma(w, s)=\left(e^{i \vartheta} \bar{w},-s\right)$ sends the basepoint

$$
p_{0}:=p_{3}^{t}
$$

to $p_{2}^{b}$ (see Figure 23).
![img-27.jpeg](img-27.jpeg)

Figure 23. We choose the gluing angle $\vartheta$ so that the orientation-reversing map $\sigma(w, s)=\left(e^{i \vartheta} \bar{w},-s\right)$ sends the basepoint $p_{3}^{t}$ to $p_{2}^{b}$. This is illustrated above in $z$ coordinates (when $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$ ).

With such a choice of $p_{0}$ and $\theta$ we will now study the integral

$$
\int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha=\chi\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha
$$

Remark 5.15 (Variations of spectral network and gluing angle). As we vary the parameter $m$, the spectral network also varies, and hence so do the boundary points $p_{i}$ and gluing angle $\vartheta$. However, the topology of this picture does not change for nearby $m$, and hence we will treat this data as fixed when computing variations of the connection $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ (cf. Remark 5.10).
5.5.2. Regularized holonomies along $\gamma_{m}$. We will prove that $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ has the following integral interpretation (cf. Proposition 5.14 for $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ ).

Proposition 5.16 ( $\gamma_{m}$ glued integral). For a connection $\nabla \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {tr }}$ with abelianization $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d+\alpha$,

$$
\exp \left(-\int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi} \alpha\right)=\mathcal{X}_{m}(\nabla) \cdot\left(\mathcal{X}_{e}(\nabla)\right)^{\frac{\sigma}{2 \pi}}
$$

For our current choice of path $\gamma_{m}=b_{r}\left(p_{3}^{t}, \theta\right)$, (5.30) says that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\exp \left(-\int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg}, x} \alpha\right) & =\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha+\frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi} x_{e}\right) \\
& =\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right) \cdot\left(\mathcal{X}_{e}\right)^{\frac{d}{2 \pi}}
\end{aligned}
$$

so it suffices to prove the following:
Lemma 5.17 ( $\mathcal{X}_{m}$ as regularized holonomy).

$$
\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right)=\mathcal{X}_{m}
$$

We will use the interpretation (2.23) of the magnetic twistor coordinate from [Tul19]:

$$
\mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta)= \begin{cases}a(\zeta) \equiv \frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}} & \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0 \\ -\frac{1}{b(\zeta)} \equiv-\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{4} \wedge s_{2}} & \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0\end{cases}
$$

The sectorial sections $s_{i}$ can be described in terms of the abelianized bundle over the spectral cover. Write $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d+\alpha$ with respect to the global frame $g^{\mathrm{ab}}$ of Corollary 3.18. Near each of the marked boundary points $p_{i}$ we can define a flat section $\hat{s}_{i}$ of $\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ with respect to $g^{\mathrm{ab}}$ by

$$
\hat{s}_{i}(q)=c_{i} \exp \left(-\int_{p_{i}}^{q} \alpha\right)
$$

where $c_{i}$ is a constant depending on $p_{i}$ (and therefore also the cutoff radius $r$ ).
Lemma 5.18 (Normalization for upstairs sections). If we choose the constants

$$
c_{i}=\exp \left(-A\left(p_{i}\right)\right)
$$

in (5.43), then the pushforward of $\hat{s}_{i}$ to the extended sector $\widehat{\mathrm{Sect}}_{i}$ coincides with the section $s_{i}$.
Proof. The pushed-forward sections have no jumps and are $\nabla$-flat by the abelianization construction, so we must only check that they have the right asymptotics (2.11) with respect to the original frame $g$.

For each $i$, let $t_{i}$ denote the pushed-forward section $\pi_{*}\left(\hat{s}_{i}\right)$ and let $\vec{t}_{i}$ denote its vector representation with respect to the frame $g$, so that $t_{i}=g \cdot \vec{t}_{i}$. In the cases $i=1$ and 2 (the others are analogous), we must verify that

$$
\vec{t}_{1}(w) \cdot e^{A_{0}(w)} \rightarrow\binom{1}{0} \quad \text { as } w \rightarrow 0 \text { in } \widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{1}
$$

and

$$
\vec{t}_{2}(w) \cdot e^{-A_{0}(w)} \rightarrow\binom{0}{1} \quad \text { as } w \rightarrow 0 \text { in } \widehat{\operatorname{Sect}}_{2}
$$

By Remark 2.11, it suffices to verify these asymptotics as $w \rightarrow 0$ in the "big cells" $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}$ shown in Figure 14.

We have an explicit antiderivative $A$ for $\alpha$ in a neighbourhood of $\infty_{-}$(containing $p_{1}^{t}$ ), so we can write

$$
\hat{s}_{1}(q)=c_{1} \exp \left(-\int_{p_{1}^{t}}^{q} \alpha\right)=c_{1} \exp \left(A\left(p_{1}^{t}\right)-A(q)\right)
$$

for $q$ near $p_{1}^{t}$. If we choose $c_{1}=\exp \left(-A\left(p_{1}^{t}\right)\right)$, the pushed-forward section will be of the form

$$
t_{1}(w)=f_{1} \cdot \exp \left(-A_{0}(w)\right)
$$

for $w=\pi(q)$ near 0 , where $f_{1}$ is part of the frame used for abelianization in $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ (see Figure 14b).
To calculate the asymptotics in terms of the original frame $g$, recall that by Proposition 3.14 we can write

$$
\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)=g \cdot \dot{\Sigma}_{1}
$$

where $\dot{\Sigma}_{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{1}$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ in $\widetilde{\operatorname{Sect}}_{1}$. Let $\tilde{\sigma}_{1}$ denote the first column of $\dot{\Sigma}_{1}$. Then

$$
t_{1}(w)=g \cdot \underbrace{\tilde{\sigma}_{1} \exp \left(-A_{0}(w)\right)}_{\tilde{t}_{1}(w)}
$$

and so

$$
\tilde{t}_{1}(w) \cdot e^{A_{0}(w)}=\tilde{\sigma}_{1}(w) \rightarrow\binom{1}{0}
$$

as required by (5.45).
The argument for $\hat{s}_{2}$ is the same, except that

$$
t_{2}(w)=f_{2} \cdot \exp \left(A_{0}(w)\right)
$$

due to the flipped signs on the bottom sheet (see (5.22)).
We will use these normalizations of the sections to relate the magnetic coordinate to the desired regularized integral. The formula for $\hat{s}_{i}$ extends to define a (multivalued) flat section of $\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{ab}}$ on the rest of $\Sigma^{\prime} \supset \Sigma_{r}$, i.e. the punctured surface minus the branch points ${ }^{18}$, which can be used to compute parallel transports.

The Stokes matrix element

$$
a(\zeta)=\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}}
$$

is naturally described in terms of parallel transport along $\gamma_{m}$ when $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$. It will be useful to introduce a related path $\gamma_{m}^{\prime}$ from $p_{4}^{b}$ to $p_{3}^{\prime}$, winding around the same branch point as $\gamma_{m}$ (see Figure 24), in order to describe

$$
b(\zeta)=\frac{s_{4} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}}
$$

when $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0$.
Lemma 5.19 (Ratios as regularized parallel transport). For any choice of normalization constants $c_{i}$ and corresponding sections $s_{i}$,

$$
\frac{c_{3}}{c_{2}} \exp \left(-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right)=\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}} \quad \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0
$$

and

$$
\frac{c_{4}}{c_{3}} \exp \left(-\int_{\gamma_{m}^{\prime}} \alpha\right)=\frac{s_{4} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}} \quad \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0
$$

Proof. For the first case, consider the parallel transport of $\hat{s}_{3}\left(p_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ to $p_{2}^{b}$ along the path $\gamma_{m}$. Since $\hat{s}_{3}$ is flat, we can directly use its definition (5.43) to write the resulting vector as

$$
\hat{s}_{3}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)=c_{3} \exp \left(-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right)
$$

On the other hand, the transported vector can also be written as

$$
\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}} \cdot \underbrace{\hat{s}_{2}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)}_{c_{2}}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{18}$ The value of $\hat{s}_{i}$ depends on the choice of path going around a branch point, since $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}$ is almost-flat.

![img-28.jpeg](img-28.jpeg)

Figure 24. $\gamma_{m}$ is related to a path $\gamma_{m}^{\prime}$, which can be used to compute $b(\zeta)$ when $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0$.
by the parallel transport formula in Lemma 3.8, since $\gamma_{m}$ crosses the wall of the network from the $\left(s_{1}, s_{3}\right)$ cell to the $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)$ cell. Setting these equal gives (5.47). The other argument is identical.

Corollary 5.20. If we choose the normalization constants $c_{i}=\exp \left(-A\left(p_{i}\right)\right)$ as in Lemma 5.18, then

$$
\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right)=\frac{s_{3} \wedge s_{1}}{s_{2} \wedge s_{1}} \equiv a(\zeta) \quad \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0
$$

and

$$
\exp \left(-A\left(p_{4}^{b}\right)+A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}^{\prime}} \alpha\right)=\frac{s_{4} \wedge s_{2}}{s_{3} \wedge s_{2}} \equiv b(\zeta) \quad \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0
$$

To express the second case (5.50) in terms of $\gamma_{m}$, note that the concatenation

$$
\gamma_{m}^{\prime}+\gamma_{m}+\delta
$$

is homotopic to a small loop around the branch point, where $\delta$ is the path from $p_{2}^{b}$ to $p_{4}^{b}$ along $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ shown in Figure 24. Therefore

$$
\exp \left(\int_{\gamma_{m}^{\prime}+\gamma_{m}+\delta} \alpha\right)=-1
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right) & =-\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{b}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{t}\right)+\int_{\delta} \alpha+\int_{\gamma_{m}^{\prime}} \alpha\right) \\
& =-\exp \left(A\left(p_{4}^{b}\right)-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}^{\prime}} \alpha\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{b(\zeta)} \quad \text { when } \operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)<0
\end{aligned}
$$

We conclude that

$$
\exp \left(-A\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+A\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha\right)=\mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta)
$$

in both cases, proving Lemma 5.17 and hence also Proposition 5.16.

5.6. Summary of twistor interpretations and completing the proof. Propositions 5.14 and 5.16 say that for a connection $\nabla \in \mathcal{A}_{\mathrm{s}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ with abelianization $\nabla^{\mathrm{ab}}=d+\alpha$,

$$
\int_{\gamma_{e}} \alpha=-\log \mathcal{X}_{e}(\nabla) \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

and

$$
\chi\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha=-\log \mathcal{X}_{m}(\nabla)-\frac{\theta}{2 \pi} \log \mathcal{X}_{e}(\nabla) \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

Taking variations, we see that the corresponding integrals appearing in the expression (5.14) for the glued form $\Omega^{\text {glue }}$ are

$$
\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}=-d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}(\nabla)
$$

and

$$
\dot{\chi}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}=\left(-d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}-\frac{\theta}{2 \pi} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}\right)(\nabla)
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue }}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right) \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{2}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\right) \\
&-\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}\left(\dot{\chi}_{1}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{1}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}\right) \\
&=d \log \mathcal{X}_{e} \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{\text { def }}{=}-4 \pi^{2} \cdot \Omega^{\text {ov }}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

which proves Proposition 5.2.
Finally, by combining the results as indicated in the diagram (1.4), we get the equality of forms

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{ov}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue }}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue,reg }}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega^{\text {reg }}
$$

on $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$. Pulling back to $\mathcal{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ via $\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}$ gives

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{reg}}
$$

completing the proof of Theorem 5.3.

# 6. SEMIFLAT ANALYSIS 

In this section we will carry out a version of the preceding analysis in order to study the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov,sf }}$. All of the main objects and spaces defined earlier have natural semiflat analogues (see Figure 25). The overall argument will be of a similar flavour, but with some key technical differences - in particular, we will now have to work directly with the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ instead of just the magnetic twistor coordinate.

Our main result in this section, analogous to Theorem 5.3, will be an identification

$$
\Omega_{\text {shift }}^{\text {ov,sf }}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega^{\text {reg,sf }}
$$

of a shifted version of the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form (Definition 6.15) with the regularized AtiyahBott form for the corresponding semiflat connections - this is Theorem 6.17 below. The shift involves a modified integral in the definition of the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$, which we will study further in Section 7 (on the Hitchin section).

![img-29.jpeg](img-29.jpeg)

Figure 25. The semiflat analogues of the spaces in Figure 1, to be defined below.

The four subsections below correspond to Sections 2 to 5. We will follow our previous steps but try to avoid repetition, instead emphasizing the novel aspects of the calculations. We begin with a brief summary of the relevant semiflat objects.

# 6.1. Overview of semiflat constructions. 

6.1.1. Semiflat metrics and harmonic bundles. There are various ways to describe the semiflat hyperkähler metric $g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{sf}}$ on Higgs moduli spaces, such as a twistorial construction in [GMN10], and a more general construction involving the theory of special Kähler manifolds and algebraic integrable systems [Fre99]. For our purposes it will be most useful to use a characterization in terms of limiting configurations $\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}\right)$ for Hitchin's equation, following [FMSW22] (see also [MSWW19, Fre20]).
Remark 6.1 (Irregular singularities). The approach in [FMSW22] applies in the setting of Higgs bundles with simple poles, where it was proved that the natural $L^{2}$-metric on the moduli space of limiting configurations coincides with the semiflat metric $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {sf }}$ defined via the integrable system structure. However, the literature is not as developed for higher-order poles.

We will extend the construction of limiting configurations $\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}\right)$ in a natural way for our setting with irregular singularities, and take this as our definition of the "semiflat harmonic metric" $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$. This approach will allow us to define semiflat analogues of the various objects and spaces considered in the previous sections. We will not discuss the corresponding $L^{2}$-metric on the moduli space, but we expect that it coincides with other constructions for the semiflat metric.

Given a Higgs bundle $(E, \theta)$ over $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}-$ say, underlying an element $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ - consider its associated spectral Higgs line bundle $(\mathcal{L}, \lambda)$ over $\Sigma$, where $\lambda$ is the canonical 1form. (Here $\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{L}_{\theta}$ comes from abelianizing the Higgs bundle; it should not be confused with the line bundles $\mathcal{L}^{\text {ab }}$ from the previous sections which came from abelianizing the corresponding connections $\nabla_{\zeta}$.)

As before, let $\Sigma^{\prime}$ denote $\Sigma$ with the branch points removed. The semiflat harmonic metric $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ will be obtained by pushing forward a metric from $(\mathcal{L}, \lambda) \mid \Sigma^{\prime}$.

Construction 6.2 (Semiflat harmonic metric). Equip $\mathcal{L}$ with parabolic weights $-\frac{1}{2}$ at the branch points and $\pm m^{(3)}$ at the punctures $\infty_{\mp}$. Then, there is a unique hermitian metric $h_{\mathcal{L}}$ on $\left.\mathcal{L}\right|_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ such that:
(i) $F_{D_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}}=0$ (i.e. the Chern connection corresponding to $h_{\mathcal{L}}$ is flat).

(ii) $h_{\mathcal{L}}$ is adapted to the parabolic structure (i.e. near each branch point or puncture $p$ with parabolic weight $\alpha_{p}$, there is a local coordinate $w_{p}$ centred at $p$ and local holomorphic frame $e_{p}$ for $\mathcal{L}$ such that $h_{\mathcal{L}}\left(e_{p}, e_{p}\right)=\left|w_{p}\right|^{2 \alpha_{p}}$ ).
( $h_{\mathcal{L}}$ is a solution to the abelian version of the Hitchin equation (2.1) with suitable boundary conditions.) Let $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ denote the orthogonal pushforward of $h_{\mathcal{L}}$ to $E \cong \pi_{*} \mathcal{L}$, where as usual $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow C$. We call $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ the semiflat harmonic metric for $(E, \theta)$.

We emphasize that $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ is singular at the branch points of $C$, unlike $h$. Also note that by construction, the $\theta$-eigenspaces are orthogonal with respect to $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$, and $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ solves the decoupled Hitchin equations

$$
F_{D_{n_{\mathrm{sf}}}}=\left[\theta, \theta^{\dagger_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}}\right]=0
$$

Now we can define semiflat versions of the spaces of harmonic bundles from Section 2.1. Instead of belabouring the point by fully repeating the definitions, we will just stress the main differences.

Definition 6.3 (Semiflat harmonic bundles in $\mathcal{H}_{\mathrm{sf}}$ ). Define a set $\mathcal{H}_{\mathrm{sf}}$ of semiflat harmonic bundles $\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}\right)$ by making the appropriate replacements of $h$ with $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ in Definition 2.1 for $\mathcal{H}$. Now, these are bundles over $C^{\prime} \backslash\{\infty\}$, where $C^{\prime}$ denotes $C$ with the branch points removed.
Definition 6.4 (Framed semiflat harmonic bundles in $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr,sf }}$ ). Define a set $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr,sf }}$ of compatibly framed semiflat harmonic bundles $\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right)$ by similarly modifying Definition 2.2 for $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$. Now, we will say that a frame $g$ at $\infty$ is compatible if it extends to an $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$-unitary frame of eigenvectors for $\theta$, with respect to which

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sqrt{z^{2}+2 m} & 0 \\
0 & -\sqrt{z^{2}+2 m}
\end{array}\right) d z=-H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m H \frac{d w}{w}+\text { diagonal regular terms. }
$$

(cf. the compatibly framed form (2.2) in $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, where $g$ was an $h$-unitary frame diagonalizing just the singular part of $\theta$.)

Let $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr,sf }}$ denote the set of isomorphism classes in $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr,sf }}$.
Lemma 6.5 (Comparison map). There is a natural map

$$
\begin{aligned}
i^{\mathrm{sf}}: \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}} & \rightarrow \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}} \\
(E, \theta, h, g) & \mapsto\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which descends to a map of moduli spaces

$$
\begin{aligned}
i^{\mathrm{sf}}: \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} & \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}} \\
{[(E, \theta, h, g)] } & \mapsto\left[\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Unwinding the definitions, the main nontrivial statement here is that the original frame $g$ admits the desired extension to an $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$-unitary eigenframe for $\theta$; this is proved in Lemma C.8.

The map $i^{\text {sf }}$ can be used to pull back semiflat objects (e.g. symplectic forms) to $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ or $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$, where they can be compared with their standard counterparts. The analogous (unframed) map in [MSWW19] gives a diffeomorphism of moduli spaces, and is used to compare the Hitchin metric $g_{L^{2}}$ to the semiflat metric $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {sf }}$.
6.1.2. Semiflat connections. Now we define analogues of the framed connections from Section 2.2. Given $\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}}$ and $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, we can consider the corresponding connection

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}:=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}}
$$

Note that $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}$ is singular at the two branch points as well as the puncture at $\infty$, but it is flat over their complement in $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ (since $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ satisfies the decoupled Hitchin equations (6.1)).

With respect to the (extension of the) frame $g$ near $w=0$, the Chern connection for $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ is of the form

$$
D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}=d+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}= & d+\left[\zeta^{-1}\left(-\frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m \frac{d w}{w}\right)+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)+\zeta\left(-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\bar{m} \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)\right] H \\
& + \text { diagonal regular terms } \\
= & d+\left[-\zeta^{-1} \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-\zeta \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}^{3}}-\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d w}{w}-\left(\zeta \bar{m}+\frac{1}{2} m^{(3)}\right) \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right] H \\
& + \text { diagonal regular terms. }
\end{aligned}
$$

We emphasize that although these are the same singular terms that appeared in our original calculations, we are now working with a different metric $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ and extension of the frame $g$.

Definition 6.6 (Framed semiflat bundles in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr.sf }}$ ). For fixed $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, let $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr.sf }}$ denote the set of $\zeta$-compatibly framed semiflat bundles $\left(E, \nabla^{\text {sf }}, g\right)$ with framing of the form (6.8) near $\infty$, analogously to Definition 2.6 for $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr }}$.

As before, we will denote the nonabelian Hodge map by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}: \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}} & \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}} \\
\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right) & \mapsto\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Before discussing the abelian counterpart of $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr.sf }}$, we will fill in some gaps from our earlier discussion of the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form.
6.1.3. Semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form and the magnetic angle. As promised in Section 2.3, we will now describe the explicit formula for the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ from [Tul19]. Given a framed Higgs bundle $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ with $m \neq 0$, let $\phi_{2}=-\operatorname{det} \theta=\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$ be the corresponding quadratic differential. Choose a square root

$$
\lambda_{0}:=\sqrt{\phi_{2}}=\sqrt{z^{2}+2 m} d z
$$

with branch cut between $z= \pm \sqrt{-2 m}$, so that near $w=0$

$$
\lambda_{0}=-\frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m \frac{d w}{w}+\text { regular terms. }
$$

Following the setup in [Tul19, Section 3.6.1]:

- Let $\gamma$ be a WKB curve for $\phi_{2}$ with phase $e^{i \arg (m) \frac{19}{2}}$ such that $\lambda_{0}(\dot{\gamma})=e^{i \arg (m)}$.
- Such a curve crosses the branch cut for $\lambda_{0}$. As $t \rightarrow \infty$ and for $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0, \gamma(t)$ lies in either

$$
\widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{1}}(\zeta) \cap \widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{4}}(\zeta) \quad \text { or } \quad \widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{2}}(\zeta) \cap \widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{4}}(\zeta)
$$

i.e. the sector centred around the anti-Stokes ray $r_{1}$ or $r_{3}$ (see Figure 26a). We assume that $\gamma$ is oriented from $\widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{2}}(\zeta) \cap \widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{4}}(\zeta)$ to $\widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{1}}(\zeta) \cap \widetilde{\operatorname{sect}_{4}}(\zeta)$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{19}$ i.e. a $\theta$-trajectory of phase $\theta=\arg (m)$, in the language of Definition 3.2

- In fact, we can (and will) choose $\gamma$ to be a straight line of the form

$$
\gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}(t)=\rho(t) e^{i \arg (m) / 2}
$$

for an appropriate real-valued function $\rho$ (see Figure 26b).

- For later use, let $\Gamma_{\text {WKB }}$ denote the lift of $\gamma$ to the spectral cover $\Sigma$ from $\infty_{+}$to $\infty_{-}$. (We choose this ordering of sheets in order to be consistent with the choice of square root branch along $\gamma$ in [Tul19].)
![img-30.jpeg](img-30.jpeg)
(a) $\gamma(t)$ lies in the indicated sectors as $t \rightarrow \pm \infty$.
![img-31.jpeg](img-31.jpeg)
(b) The chosen WKB curve $\gamma$ and possible directions for $r_{1}$ and $r_{3}$.

Figure 26. The WKB curve $\gamma$ is chosen to be a straight line $\rho(t) e^{i \arg (m) / 2}$, oriented so that it goes from the sector centred around $r_{3}$ in (a) to the sector around $r_{1}$ when $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$. Conversely, the anti-Stokes directions $r_{1}$ and $r_{3}$ must lie somewhere within the yellow shaded region in (b).

- Choose a frame $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ of $\theta$-eigenvectors along $\gamma$ such that

$$
\left.\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)\right|_{\gamma(t)} \rightarrow \begin{cases}\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right) & \text { as } t \rightarrow \infty \\ \left(e_{2},-e_{1}\right) & \text { as } t \rightarrow-\infty\end{cases}
$$

where $g=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ is the specified frame for $E$ at $\infty$. We will make a particular choice of $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ in Remark 6.12 below.

- Let $A_{h}$ denote the connection form of the Chern connection $D_{h}$ with respect to $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$.

Definition 6.7 ( $\theta_{m}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ ). With setup as above, the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ is given by

$$
\theta_{m}(E, \theta, h, g)=m^{(3)} \arg (-m)+\pi+\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h}\right)_{11} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi)
$$

This formula is isomorphism invariant and hence descends to the moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$, where it agrees with the Ooguri-Vafa magnetic coordinate under the identification in [Tul19, Section 4].

For reference we also note the following fact from [Tul19].
Proposition $6.8\left(U(1)\right.$-action and $\left.\theta_{m}\right)$. The $U(1)$-action of $e^{i \vartheta}$ on $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ shifts $\theta_{m} \rightarrow \theta_{m}+\vartheta$; that is,

$$
\theta_{m}\left(e^{i \vartheta} \cdot[(E, \theta, h, g)]\right)=\theta_{m}([(E, \theta, h, g)])+\vartheta
$$

We now have a fully explicit definition of the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}(\zeta) \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\mathrm{sf}}(\zeta)
$$

In terms of the parameters on $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, the semiflat magnetic twistor coordinate (2.20) can be written

$$
\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\mathrm{sf}}(\zeta)=\exp \left(\zeta^{-1} Z_{B}+i \theta_{m}+\zeta \overline{Z_{B}}\right)
$$

where

$$
Z_{B}:=-m \log \left(\frac{m}{-2 e}\right)
$$

We will interpret the twistor coordinates $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ and $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {sf }}$ in terms of certain integrals of abelian connections, as in Section 5.6.
6.2. Semiflat abelianization and framing. Continuing with our argument from before, the next step is to abelianize the framed connections in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf }}$.

Let $\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}}$ and $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. By construction, the connection

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{\mathrm{s}_{\mathrm{sf}}}}
$$

is the pushforward of the abelian connection

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}:=\zeta^{-1} \lambda+D_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}+\zeta \bar{\Lambda}
$$

on the spectral line bundle $\mathcal{L}$ over $\Sigma$. In Section 6.4 we will apply the gluing procedure to these connections.

We must first explain how to lift the frame $g$ from $E$ to $\mathcal{L}$, as in Section 3.2. But now this is automatic: the compatible frame $g$ extends (by definition) to a frame of $\theta$-eigenvectors, which define sections of the spectral line bundle $\mathcal{L}$.

Recall that with respect to the frame $g$ near $w=0$,

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\lambda_{0} & 0 \\
0 & -\lambda_{0}
\end{array}\right)=-H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m H \frac{d w}{w}+\text { diagonal regular terms }
$$

where $\lambda_{0}=\sqrt{z^{2}+2 m} d z$ as in (6.10), and

$$
D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}=d+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)
$$

Since these are already diagonal with respect to $g$, we do not need to make any additional modifications to the frame.

Corollary 6.9 (Induced frame for $\mathcal{L}$ ). In a neighbourhood of each puncture $\infty_{ \pm}$of $\Sigma$, there exists a frame $g_{ \pm}^{\mathcal{L}}$ for $\mathcal{L}$ with respect to which

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}=d \pm \pi^{*}\left[-\zeta^{-1} \lambda_{0}-\left(\frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)\right)-\zeta \overline{\lambda_{0}}\right]
$$

Definition 6.10 (Framed abelian semiflat bundles in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$ ). For fixed $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, let $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$ denote the set of abelian semiflat bundles $\left(\mathcal{L}, \nabla^{\text {sf,ab }}, g_{ \pm}^{\mathcal{L}}\right)$ with framing of the form (6.19) near $\infty_{ \pm}$, analogously to Definition 3.12 for $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$.

Remark 6.11 (Framed semiflat form). The framed form (6.19) for the connections in $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$ is also quite rigid, but in a slightly different way than $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$ (cf. Remark 3.13):

- For $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,ab }}$, the connections had prescribed singular terms with no additional regular terms.
- For $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$, the connections now do have additional regular terms, but they are fully explicit (in terms of $\lambda_{0}$ ).

Next, as in Section 3.3, we extend these local frames to a global frame $g^{\mathcal{L}}$ defined away from the punctures and branch points. Note that over each sheet of $\Sigma$, the frame $g^{\mathcal{L}}$ pushes down to $E$ to give an eigensection for $\theta$ with corresponding eigenvalue $\pm \lambda_{0}$.

Remark 6.12 (Pushed-forward frame along $\gamma$ ). The pushforward of $g^{\mathcal{L}}$ along the path $\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}$ gives an eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ along the WKB curve $\gamma$ which satisfies the normalization condition (6.13). We therefore can (and will) use this frame to compute the integral appearing in the formula (6.14) for the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$.
6.3. Regularized semiflat Atiyah-Bott forms. We can define regularized Atiyah-Bott forms $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ and $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$ on the spaces of semiflat connections $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,sf }}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$ exactly as we did in Section 4, namely by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right) & =\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{\mathrm{C}_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)\right] \\
