\mathcal{R}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right) & =\operatorname{tr}\left(\mu_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}} \lambda_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}-\mu_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}} \lambda_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right) \\
\nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}} & =\left(\mu_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left(\lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for some } \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}}, \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}} \in \mathfrak{h}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}\right) & =\lim _{R \rightarrow 0}\left[\int_{\Sigma_{R}} \nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}} \wedge \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}\right)\right] \\
\mathcal{R}^{\mathrm{ab}}\left(\nabla_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}, \nabla_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}\right) & =2\left(\mu_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}-\mu_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}} \lambda_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}\right) \\
\nabla_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}} & =\left( \pm \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) d \theta+\left( \pm \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}+\mathcal{O}(r)\right) \frac{d r}{r} \quad \text { for } \mu_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}, \lambda_{i}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}} \in \mathbb{C}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the forms themselves are given by the same formulas as before - only the underlying spaces of connections are different - so we will still denote them by $\Omega^{\text {reg }}$ and $\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}$ without an "sf" subscript.

We define the regularized semiflat Atiyah-Bott form $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg,sf }}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ by pulling back $\left.\Omega^{\text {reg }}\right|_{\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,sf }}}$ via the composition

$$
\mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}:=\mathrm{NAH}_{\xi} \circ i^{\mathrm{sf}}: \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}} \xrightarrow{i^{\mathrm{sf}}} \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}} \mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}}
$$

where $i^{\text {sf }}$ is the comparison map from Lemma 6.5. This allows us to compare $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg }}$ and $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg,sf }}$ on the same underlying space (see Figure 27). By the usual abuse of notation we will also let $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg,sf }}$ denote the induced form on the moduli space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$.
![img-32.jpeg](img-32.jpeg)

Figure 27. Forms induced on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ by the regularized forms $\left.\Omega^{\text {reg }}\right|_{\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr }}}$ and $\left.\Omega^{\text {reg }}\right|_{\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\text {fr,sf }}}$.

Remark 6.13 (Semiflat regularization terms). If $\dot{\nabla}_{i}$ and $\dot{\nabla}_{i}^{\text {sf }}$ are variations of $\nabla_{\zeta}=\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}(E, \theta, h, g)$ and $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}=\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}(E, \theta, h, g)$ respectively, induced by variations of $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, then

$$
\mathcal{R}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}\right)=\mathcal{R}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)
$$

i.e. the regularization terms of $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg }}$ and $\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg,sf }}$ coincide.

We also get the expected analogue of Proposition 4.10:
Proposition 6.14 ("Semiflat abelianization is a symplectomorphism"). As forms on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf }}$,

$$
\mathrm{ab}^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{ab}}=\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}
$$

i.e.

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)=\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{ab}}\left(\dot{\nabla}_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}, \dot{\nabla}_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}\right)
$$

Proof. This time the result is essentially immediate, since the semiflat connections $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\text {sf }}$ are the pushforwards of $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\text {sf,ab }}$. (Alternatively we could follow the proof of Proposition 4.10, except now the Stokes matrices $S$ are just the identity.)
6.4. Semiflat glued symplectic form. Our goal here, analogously to Section 5, is to produce a semiflat glued form $\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$ as an intermediary between the regularized abelian AtiyahBott form and the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form. Once again the glued form will coincide with the regularized one, but its identification with the Ooguri-Vafa form will be slightly modified as a result of replacing $h$ with $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ in the definitions.
Definition 6.15 (Shifted magnetic angle and form).
(1) Define the magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr,sf }}$ by

$$
\theta_{m}\left(E, \theta, h_{\mathrm{sf}}, g\right):=m^{(3)} \arg (-m)+\pi+\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}\right)_{11} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi)
$$

where $A_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}$ is the connection form of the semiflat Chern connection $D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}$ with respect to the eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ from Section 6.1.3. (cf. Definition 6.7 for the magnetic angle on $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, which instead used $A_{h}$.)
(2) Define a shifted magnetic angle $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ by the pullback

$$
\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}:=\left(i^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*}\left(\left.\theta_{m}\right|_{\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}}}\right)
$$

i.e.

$$
\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}(E, \theta, h, g)=m^{(3)} \arg (-m)+\pi+\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}\right)_{11} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi)
$$

(3) Define the corresponding shifted semiflat magnetic twistor coordinate on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ by

$$
\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}(\zeta):=\exp \left(\zeta^{-1} Z_{B}+i \theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}+\zeta \overline{Z_{B}}\right)
$$

and shifted semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}, \text { shift }}:=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e}(\zeta) \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}(\zeta)
$$

Remark 6.16 (shift vs sf). The (perhaps subtle) choice of notation above is deliberate. The definition (6.30) of $\theta_{m}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr,sf }}$ is really the natural analogue of $\theta_{m}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$, given by the same formula but with a different underlying harmonic metric. In this sense, $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ is the natural semiflat magnetic coordinate from the point of view of $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$.

However, it is not a priori obvious that $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ does (or should) coincide with the semiflat OoguriVafa coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {sf }}$ (defined by (6.16), in terms of $\theta_{m}$ ). We use the "shift" superscript to emphasize this distinction.

In Propositions 6.20 and 6.24 below we will show that

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue,st }}=\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}
$$

and

$$
\left(\mathrm{ab} \circ \mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}=-4 \pi^{2} \cdot \Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov,shift }}
$$

which will give the following analogue of Theorem 5.3:
Theorem 6.17 (Shifted semiflat Ooguri-Vafa and regularization). Under the identification of spaces $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {ov,shift }}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg,sf }}
$$

i.e. the shifted semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form coincides with the regularized semiflat Atiyah-Bott form, pulled back to $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}$.
Remark $6.18\left(\theta_{m}\right.$ vs $\left.\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}\right)$. More explicitly,

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{ov}, \text { shift }}=\Omega^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}+\frac{i}{4 \pi^{2}} d \log \mathcal{X}_{e} \wedge d\left(\theta_{m}-\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}\right)
$$

where

$$
\theta_{m}-\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}=\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h}\right)_{11}-\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{s t}}\right)_{11}
$$

We will postpone the issue of comparing these integrals until Section 7.
6.4.1. Setup for the semiflat gluing procedure. Now we will follow the gluing procedure as in Section 5.2. We will use the same

- cut off cylinder $\Sigma_{r} \subseteq \Sigma$,
- gluing diffeomorphism $\sigma(w, s)=\left(e^{i \phi} \bar{w},-s\right)$, and
- paths $\gamma_{e}$ and $\gamma_{m}$ (as shown in Figure 22),
but must specify a new map $\chi^{\text {sf }}$ for the gluing gauge transformation.
Write $\nabla_{\zeta}^{\text {sf,ab }}=d+\alpha^{\text {sf }}$ with respect to the global frame $g^{\mathcal{L}}$. Also let $A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}$ denote the connection form of the Chern connection $D_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}$ with respect to this frame, so that we can (globally) write

$$
\alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}=\zeta^{-1} \lambda+A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}+\zeta \bar{\lambda}
$$

With notation as in Section 5.2 (in particular suppressing the pullback $\pi^{*}$ ), near the punctures we have

$$
A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=\varepsilon \cdot \frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)
$$

and

$$
\alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}=\varepsilon \cdot\left[\zeta^{-1} \lambda_{0}+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)+\zeta \bar{\lambda}_{0}\right]
$$

The above formula almost coincides with the earlier expression (5.20) for $\alpha$, except now the series expansion (6.11) of $\lambda_{0}$ contains additional regular $\mathcal{O}(w)$ terms, and so we can write

$$
\alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}=\alpha+\mathcal{O}(|w|)
$$

It follows that there is a unique choice of gluing map $\chi^{\text {sf }}$ satisfying the symmetric gluing condition (5.8) such that

$$
\chi^{\mathrm{sf}}=\chi+\mathcal{O}(|w|)
$$

near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$, where $\chi$ denotes the original choice of gluing map (5.26).
In fact, we can once again specify $\chi^{\text {sf }}$ completely explicitly:

- First choose the antiderivative

$$
\Lambda_{0}(z)=\frac{z}{2} \sqrt{z^{2}+2 m}+m \log \left(z+\sqrt{z^{2}+2 m}\right)-\frac{m}{2}-m \log 2
$$

of $\lambda_{0}$, as in [Tul19, Equation (3.104)], so that $\Lambda_{0}(w)=\frac{1}{2} w^{-2}-m \log w+\mathcal{O}(w)$.

- Define an antiderivative of $\alpha^{\text {sf }}$ in a neighbourhood of $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ by

$$
A^{\mathrm{sf}}:=\varepsilon \cdot \pi^{*}\left(\zeta^{-1} \Lambda_{0}+C_{0}+\zeta \overline{\Lambda_{0}}\right)
$$

where

$$
C_{0}(w)=\frac{m^{(3)}}{2}(\log w-\log \bar{w})
$$

(so $C_{0}$ is an antiderivative for the Chern connection term, i.e. $d\left(\varepsilon \cdot \pi^{*} C_{0}\right)=A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}$ near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ ).
Analogously to (5.25), we will choose the gluing map

$$
\chi^{\mathrm{sf}}=\frac{A^{\mathrm{sf}}-\sigma^{*} A^{\mathrm{sf}}}{2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2} \cdot \frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi} x_{e}
$$

(which is indeed consistent with (6.42)).
Construction 6.19 (Semiflat glued form $\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}$ ). With this choice of $\chi^{\text {sf }}$, the gluing construction produces a form $\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}$ on $\mathcal{A}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$ (and its moduli space). It can be calculated by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}\left(\hat{\nabla}_{1}^{\text {sf,ab }}, \hat{\nabla}_{2}^{\text {sf,ab }}\right)= & \int_{\Sigma_{r}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\text {sf }} \wedge \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\text {sf }}+\int_{\partial \Sigma_{r}}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2}^{\text {sf }} \dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\text {sf }}-\dot{\chi}_{1}^{\text {sf }} \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\text {sf }}+\dot{\chi}_{1}^{\text {sf }} d \dot{\chi}_{2}^{\text {sf }}\right) \\
= & \int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\text {sf }}\left(\dot{\chi}_{2}^{\text {sf }}\left(p_{0}\right)-\dot{\chi}_{2}^{\text {sf }}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\text {sf }}\right) \\
& -\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\text {sf }}\left(\dot{\chi}_{1}^{\text {sf }}\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi_{1}^{\text {sf }}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\text {sf }}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

6.4.2. Semiflat gluing and regularization. Just as in Section 5.3.1, the regularized integrals

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi^{\mathrm{sf}}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}} & :=\chi^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}} \\
& =\left(A^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(p_{0}\right)-A^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)-\frac{\vartheta}{2 \pi} x_{e}
\end{aligned}
$$

are $r$-independent, and hence so is the form $\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}$. By the same argument as in Section 5.3.2, we obtain the analogue of Proposition 5.1.

Proposition 6.20 (Semiflat gluing and regularization). As forms on $\mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf,ab }}$,

$$
\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}=\Omega^{\text {reg,ab }}
$$

i.e. the semiflat glued form $\Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}$ coincides with the regularized abelian Atiyah-Bott form.
6.4.3. Interpreting the semiflat twistor coordinates. Next we will interpret the integrals

$$
\int_{\gamma_{e}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}} \text { and } \int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi^{\mathrm{sf}}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}
$$

in terms of the semiflat twistor coordinates, as in Sections 5.4 and 5.5.

As another sanity check, note that the integral over $\gamma_{e}$ has the same interpretation in terms of $\mathcal{X}_{e}$ as before:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\gamma_{e}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}} & =\int_{\gamma_{e}}\left(\zeta^{-1} \lambda_{0}+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)+\zeta \overline{\lambda_{0}}\right) \\
& =2 \pi i\left(\zeta^{-1} m-\zeta \bar{m}-m^{(3)}\right) \\
& =-\log \mathcal{X}_{e}(E, \theta, h, g) \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
\end{aligned}
$$

(This is consistent with the fact that $\mathcal{X}_{e}^{\text {sf }}=\mathcal{X}_{e}$.)
We now turn to the more complicated regularized integral over $\gamma_{m}$. We will obtain an analogue of (5.53) for the corresponding integral in $\Omega^{\text {flu, }}$, but involving the shifted version of the magnetic angle.
Proposition 6.21 (Semiflat $\gamma_{m}$ integral). For a semiflat connection $\nabla^{\text {sf }}=\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}^{\text {sf }}(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{A}_{\zeta}^{\text {fr,sf }}$, pushed down from $\nabla^{\text {sf,ab }}=d+\alpha^{\text {sf }}$,

$$
\int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg}, \chi^{\text {sf }}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}=-\log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}(E, \theta, h, g)-\frac{\theta}{2 \pi} \log \mathcal{X}_{e}(E, \theta, h, g) \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

The calculation of this regularized integral involves several steps, but it provides some geometric insight into the terms appearing in $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$. For notational concreteness we will assume that $\operatorname{Re}\left(\zeta^{-1} m\right)>0$, but the argument for the other case is the same. ${ }^{20}$

Proof. Using the formulas (6.50) for $\int_{\gamma_{m}}^{\operatorname{reg} \chi^{\text {sf }}} \alpha^{\text {sf }}$ and (6.33) for $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}$, we need to match up

$$
I_{m}^{\mathrm{sf}}:=A^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)-A^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(p_{2}^{h}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}
$$

with

$$
-\log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}=-\zeta^{-1} Z_{B} \underbrace{-i m^{(3)} \operatorname{arg}(-m)-\pi i-\int_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}} A_{h_{\zeta}}}_{-i \theta_{m}^{\text {shif }}}-\zeta \overline{Z_{B}} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

In the expansion (6.32) of $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ we have rewritten

$$
\int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{s t}}\right)_{11}=\int_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}} A_{h_{\zeta^{\prime}}}
$$

where $\Gamma_{\text {WKB }}$ is the lift of $\gamma$ to $\Sigma$ from Section 6.1.3. (Note that this integral is purely imaginary.)
To start, we can use the expressions (6.38) for $\alpha^{\text {sf }}$ and (6.44) for $A^{\text {sf }}$ to split up

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{m}^{\mathrm{sf}}= & \zeta^{-1}\left(\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{2}^{h}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \lambda\right)+\left(C_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+C_{0}\left(p_{2}^{h}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} A_{h_{\zeta}}\right) \\
& +\zeta\left(\overline{\Lambda_{0}}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+\overline{\Lambda_{0}}\left(p_{2}^{h}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \bar{\lambda}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The $\zeta^{-1}$ and $\zeta$ terms can be calculated explicitly.
Lemma 6.22 (Regularized integral of $\lambda$ along $\gamma_{m}$ ).

$$
\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{2}^{h}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \lambda=-Z_{B}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{20}$ Unlike the full magnetic coordinate $\mathcal{X}_{m}(\zeta)$, the semiflat coordinate does not involve any jumps in $\zeta$.

Proof. Essentially the same calculation appears in [GMN13b, Section 9.4.3] and [Tul19, Lemma 3.13]. Begin by deforming the path $\gamma_{m}$ so that it passes through the (preimage of the) branch point $z=\sqrt{-2 m}$, and write

$$
\int_{\gamma_{m}} \lambda=\int_{p_{3}^{t}}^{\sqrt{-2 m}} \lambda+\int_{\sqrt{-2 m}}^{p_{2}^{b}} \lambda
$$

These two paths respectively lie on the top/bottom sheets of $\Sigma$, where $\left.\lambda\right|_{\text {top }}=\lambda_{0}$ and $\left.\lambda\right|_{\text {bot }}=-\lambda_{0}$, so we can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\gamma_{m}} \lambda & =\int_{p_{3}^{t}}^{\sqrt{-2 m}} \lambda_{0}+\int_{\sqrt{-2 m}}^{p_{2}^{b}}\left(-\lambda_{0}\right) \\
& =\left(\Lambda_{0}(\sqrt{-2 m})-\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)\right)+\left(\Lambda_{0}(\sqrt{-2 m})-\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+\Lambda_{0}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \lambda=2 \Lambda_{0}(\sqrt{-2 m})=m \log \left(\frac{m}{-2 e}\right)=-Z_{B}
$$

where the second equality is a direct calculation using the definition (6.43) of $\Lambda_{0}$.
It follows that

$$
I_{m}^{\mathrm{sf}}=-\zeta^{-1} Z_{B}+\left(C_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+C_{0}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}\right)-\zeta \overline{Z_{B}}
$$

This is starting to look like the desired expression (6.54). Next we need to incorporate the lifted WKB curve $\Gamma_{\text {WKB }}$.
Lemma $6.23\left(\gamma_{m}\right.$ vs $\left.\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}\right)$.

$$
C_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+C_{0}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=-i \theta_{m}^{\text {shift }} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

Proof. We must show that

$$
C_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)+C_{0}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=-i m^{(3)} \arg (-m)-\int_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}+\pi i \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

We will compare the integrals in terms of the paths indicated in the triptych below (Figure 28).
![img-33.jpeg](img-33.jpeg)

Figure 28. Comparison of the lifted WKB curve $\Gamma_{\text {WKB }}$ and $\gamma_{m}$, in terms of paths $\delta^{t}$ and $\delta^{b}$ near the boundary of $\Sigma_{r}$.

Let $q^{b}$ and $q^{t}$ denote the points where $\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}$ intersects $\partial \Sigma_{r}$, lying on the sheets indicated by their superscripts, and decompose

$$
\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}=\Gamma_{\mathrm{in}}+\Gamma_{\mathrm{out}}
$$

into components lying inside and outside $\Sigma_{r}$.
Recall that near the punctures - so in particular, near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ and along $\Gamma_{\text {out }}$ - we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}} & =\varepsilon \cdot \frac{m^{(3)}}{2}\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right) \\
& =\varepsilon \cdot i m^{(3)} d \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $d \theta\left(\dot{\Gamma}_{\mathrm{WKB}}\right)=0$ (i.e. $\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}$ is a straight line), it follows that

$$
\int_{\Gamma_{\text {out }}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=0
$$

and so

$$
\int_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=\int_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{in}}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}
$$

Now consider the two paths $\delta^{t}$ and $\delta^{b}$ shown in Figure 28c, going along $\partial \Sigma_{r}$ from $q^{t}$ to $p_{3}^{t}$ and $p_{2}^{b}$ to $q^{b}$ respectively. The concatenation

$$
\Gamma_{\text {in }}+\delta^{t}+\gamma_{m}+\delta^{b}
$$

is homotopic to a small loop around one of the branch points, so

$$
\exp \left(\int_{\Gamma_{\text {in }}+\delta^{t}+\gamma_{m}+\delta^{b}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}\right)=-1
$$

and hence

$$
\int_{\gamma_{m}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}+\int_{\delta^{t}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}+\int_{\delta^{b}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=-\int_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{WKB}}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}+\pi i \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

Since $d\left(\varepsilon \cdot C_{0}\right)=A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}$ near $\partial \Sigma_{r}$, we can write

$$
\int_{\delta^{t}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=C_{0}\left(p_{3}^{t}\right)-C_{0}\left(q^{t}\right)
$$

on the top sheet

$$
\int_{\delta^{b}} A_{h_{\mathcal{L}}}=C_{0}\left(p_{2}^{b}\right)-C_{0}\left(q^{b}\right)
$$

and on the bottom. Finally, we can use the angle (6.12) of the WKB curve to compute ${ }^{21}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{0}\left(q^{t}\right)+C_{0}\left(q^{b}\right) & =-i m^{(3)} \frac{\arg (m)}{2}-i m^{(3)}\left(\frac{\arg (m)}{2}+\pi\right) \\
& =-i m^{(3)} \arg (-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

from which (6.60) follows.
Therefore

$$
t_{m}^{\mathrm{sf}}=-\zeta^{-1} Z_{B}-i \theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}-\zeta \overline{Z_{B}}=-\log \lambda_{m}^{\text {shift }} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi i)
$$

which proves Proposition 6.21.

6.4.4. Summary of semiflat twistor interpretations and completing the proof. Similarly to Section 5.6, we see that for variations $\dot{\mathcal{E}}_{i}$ of $\mathcal{E}=(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, with induced variations of the semiflat connections $\nabla_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}$ and $\nabla_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}=d+\alpha^{\mathrm{sf}}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathrm{ab} \circ \mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}\left(\dot{\mathcal{E}}_{1}, \dot{\mathcal{E}}_{2}\right) \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} & \int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(\chi_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right) \\
& -\int_{\gamma_{e}} \dot{\alpha}_{2}^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(\chi_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(p_{0}\right)-\chi_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}\left(\sigma\left(p_{0}\right)\right)+\int_{\gamma_{m}} \dot{\alpha}_{1}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right) \\
= & d \log \mathcal{X}_{e} \wedge d \log \mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}\left(\dot{\mathcal{E}}_{1}, \dot{\mathcal{E}}_{2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{\text { def }}{=}-4 \pi^{2} \cdot \Omega_{\xi}^{\text {ov,shift }}\left(\dot{\mathcal{E}}_{1}, \dot{\mathcal{E}}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which gives the following analogue of Proposition 5.2:
Proposition 6.24 (Semiflat gluing and shifted Ooguri-Vafa).

$$
\left(\mathrm{ab} \circ \mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue,sf }}=-4 \pi^{2} \cdot \Omega_{\xi}^{\text {ov,shift }}
$$

Combining our results, we get the equality of forms

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega^{\text {ov,shift }} & =-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}}\left(\mathrm{ab} \circ \mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\text {glue,sf }} \\
& =-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}}\left(\left.\mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*} \mathrm{ab}^{*}\left(\left.\Omega^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{ab}}\right|_{\mathcal{A}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}, \mathrm{ab}}}\right)\right. \\
& =-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}}\left(\left.\mathrm{NAH}_{\xi}^{\mathrm{sf}}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\right|_{\mathcal{A}^{\mathrm{fr}, \mathrm{sf}}} \\
& =-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{sf}}
\end{aligned}
$$

completing the proof of Theorem 6.17.

# 7. DUALITY AND THE MAGNETIC ANGLES ON THE Hitchin SECTION 

It remains to compare the usual semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form $\Omega^{\text {ov,sf }}$ to the shifted version $\Omega^{\text {ov,shift }}$ appearing in Theorem 6.17. One might hope that the a priori different magnetic angles $\theta_{m}$ and $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ actually coincide, which would mean that $\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {sf }}=\mathcal{X}_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ and hence $\Omega^{\text {ov,sf }}=\Omega^{\text {ov,shift }}$. We will prove that this holds on a "framed Hitchin section" $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (Definition 7.15).

Theorem 7.1 (Vanishing angles on the Hitchin section). Restricted to the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\left.\theta_{m}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}} \equiv 0 \equiv \left.\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}
$$

Consequently

$$
\left.\Omega_{\xi}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\xi}^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{sf}}\left|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}\right.
$$

i.e. the (usual) semiflat Ooguri-Vafa form coincides with the regularized semiflat Atiyah-Bott form.

Comparing the angles $\theta_{m}$ and $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ amounts to comparing the integrals

$$
\int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h}\right)_{11} \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{s f}}\right)_{11}
$$

These integrals are generally hard to describe explicitly - they respectively involve solutions to Hitchin's equations (2.1) and (6.1) - but by restricting to the Hitchin section we will be able take advantage of an additional symmetry of the bundles.

Similarly to the standard Hitchin section, we will consider a family of bundles of the form $E=K_{\mathrm{C}}^{-1 / 2} \oplus K_{\mathrm{C}}^{1 / 2}$ with Higgs field

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2} & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad m \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

but we will need to take some extra care to specify the parabolic structure and framing.
As in the unframed case [Hit92b], these bundles should exhibit a kind of self-duality related to their structure as real Higgs bundles (cf. [Nei24] for a similar wild setting, but in rank 3). We will discuss this duality more generally before returning to the Hitchin section, where we will use it to show that the magnetic angles vanish.
7.1. Framed duality. There is a natural duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {ov }}$ on the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ defined by negating the angles on each torus fibre, i.e. acting on the coordinates by

$$
\mathbb{D}^{o v}:\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
z & \mapsto z \\
\theta_{e} & \mapsto-\theta_{e} \\
\theta_{m} & \mapsto-\theta_{m}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Our goal in this subsection is to describe the corresponding duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$ on the space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$. Note that in terms of the correspondence $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (see Table 2), $\mathbb{D}^{\text {ov }}$ sends $m \mapsto m$ and $m^{(3)} \mapsto-m^{(3)}$.
7.1.1. Duality for unrestricted framed harmonic bundles. A natural first guess for $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$ is to send each component of $(E, \theta, h, g)$ to its dual object. This is almost correct, but we will also need to shift the dual parabolic weights when $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$ to ensure that they remain in the half-open interval $\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$. We will proceed towards the full definition in steps, starting with the duality

$$
(E, \theta, h)^{*}:=\left(E^{*}, \theta^{t}, h^{*}\right)
$$

on the space $\mathcal{H}$ of (unframed) harmonic bundles.
Lemma 7.2 (Dual harmonic bundle). $(E, \theta, h)^{*}$ is in fact a harmonic bundle, i.e. the dual metric $h^{*}$ satisfies the "dual Hitchin equation"

$$
F_{D_{h^{*}}}+\left[\theta^{t},\left(\theta^{t}\right)^{\dagger_{h^{*}}}\right]=0
$$

Proof. By general properties of duality, $\left(\theta^{t}\right)^{\dagger_{h^{*}}}=\left(\theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right)^{t}$, and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\theta^{t},\left(\theta^{t}\right)^{\dagger_{h^{*}}}\right] } & =\left[\theta^{t},\left(\theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right)^{t}\right]=-\left[\theta, \theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right]^{t} \\
& =\left(F_{D_{h}}\right)^{t} \quad \text { since } h \text { satisfies the Hitchin equation (2.1) } \\
& =-F_{D_{h^{*}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Also note that the parameter $m$ is preserved, since $\operatorname{det} \theta^{t}=\operatorname{det} \theta=-\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$.
Remark 7.3. One could also reasonably define $(E, \theta, h)^{*}=\left(E^{*},-\theta^{t}, h^{*}\right)$ as in e.g. [Sim92], but the version without the minus sign will work better with our framing conventions.

In order to extend this duality to the space $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ of framed bundles we will also need to take into account the parameter $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$. To simplify matters we will temporarily introduce a larger unrestricted space of bundles.

Definition 7.4 (Unrestricted framed harmonic bundles). Let $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$ be the space of framed harmonic bundles satisfying the same conditions as $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ in Definition 2.2, but without any restriction on $m^{(3)}$, i.e. replacing (2.3) with

$$
\hat{\partial}_{E}=\hat{\partial}-\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}+\text { regular terms for some } m^{(3)} \in \mathbb{R}
$$

This extended space is the natural setting for the "naive duality"

$$
(E, \theta, h, g)^{*}:=\left(E^{*}, \theta^{t}, h^{*}, g^{*}\right)
$$

Lemma 7.5 (Duality and $m, m^{(3)}$ ). If $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ has associated parameters $m$ and $m^{(3)}$, then its dual $(E, \theta, h, g)^{*}$ also belongs to $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ and has associated parameters $m$ and $-m^{(3)}$.

Proof. With respect to the dual frame $g^{*}$ near $w=0$,

$$
\theta^{t}=-H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m H \frac{d w}{w}+\text { regular terms }
$$

and

$$
\tilde{\partial}_{E^{*}}=\tilde{\partial}+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H \frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}+\text { regular terms }
$$

(cf. the expressions (2.2) for $\theta$ and (2.3) for $\tilde{\partial}_{E}$ with respect to $g$ ). Therefore $g^{*}$ is a compatible frame for $\left(E^{*}, \theta^{t}, h^{*}\right)$ exhibiting the desired properties.

This definition of duality is natural with respect to many of the other constructions on $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$. In particular:

- The parabolic structure of $(E, \theta, h, g)^{*} \in \widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ is dual to that of $(E, \theta, h, g)$ (see Appendix E.1).
- The semiflat constructions from Section 6 are compatible with duality, in the sense that:
- The spectral Higgs line bundle of $(E, \theta)^{*}$ is the dual of that of $(E, \theta)$, and their corresponding induced frames (as in Section 6.2) are also dual.
- The semiflat harmonic metric for $(E, \theta)^{*}$ is the dual of that for $(E, \theta)$.

We can define magnetic angles on the larger space $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ using the exact same formulas as for $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ :

$$
\hat{\theta}_{m}:=m^{(3)} \arg (-m)+\pi+\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h}\right)_{11} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi)
$$

and

$$
\hat{\theta}_{m}^{\text {shift }}:=m^{(3)} \arg (-m)+\pi+\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{M}}\right)_{11} \quad(\bmod 2 \pi)
$$

Proposition 7.6 (Magnetic angles under duality on $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ ).

$$
\hat{\theta}_{m}\left((E, \theta, h, g)^{*}\right)=-\hat{\theta}_{m}(E, \theta, h, g)
$$

and

$$
\hat{\theta}_{m}^{\text {shift }}\left((E, \theta, h, g)^{*}\right)=-\hat{\theta}_{m}^{\text {shift }}(E, \theta, h, g)
$$

Proof. By Lemma 7.5 the first term $m^{(3)} \arg (-m)$ is negated, so we must show that the same is true of

$$
\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h}\right)_{11} \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h_{M}}\right)_{11}
$$

For the first integral, recall that $A_{h}$ denotes the connection form of the Chern connection $D_{h}$ with respect to a $\theta$-eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ satisfying the normalization condition (6.13). In order to compute the corresponding integral for $(E, \theta, g)^{*}$, we can use the dual frame $\left(\eta_{1}^{*}, \eta_{2}^{*}\right)$, with respect to which $A_{h}$ is replaced by $-A_{h}^{t}$ and hence $\left(A_{h}\right)_{11}$ by $-\left(A_{h}\right)_{11}$. Therefore the first integral is negated.

The same argument works for the second integral, by the compatibility of the semiflat construction with duality.

7.1.2. Hecke modifications and magnetic angles. Shifting the weight $m^{(3)}$ of an element of $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$ can be described in terms of certain Hecke modifications.

In Appendix E. 2 we recall a standard definition of Hecke modifications, which involves making a choice of a holomorphic trivialization. If the chosen holomorphic frame is compatible with the parabolic structure, then the Hecke modification naturally shifts the associated parabolic weights. However, the bundles in $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$ come equipped with unitary rather than holomorphic frames, so it will be convenient to give an alternative definition adapted to this setting.

Definition 7.7 (Unitary Hecke modification). Let $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, and write $g=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ for the frame in a neighbourhood of $\infty$. A unitary Hecke modification of $(E, \theta, h, g)$ of type $n \in \mathbb{Z}$ is the new bundle $(\tilde{E}, \theta, \tilde{h}, \tilde{g}) \in \widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ such that:
(1) The underlying harmonic bundle satisfies

$$
\left.(\tilde{E}, \theta, \tilde{h})\right|_{\mathrm{CP}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}=\left.(E, \theta, h)\right|_{\mathrm{CP}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}
$$

(2) The modified frame is

$$
\left.\tilde{g}\right|_{\mathrm{CP}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}=\left(\frac{w^{n}}{|w|^{n}} \cdot e_{1}, \frac{w^{-n}}{|w|^{-n}} \cdot e_{2}\right)
$$

(This defines the required unitary extension of $\left.(\tilde{E}, \theta, \tilde{h})\right|_{\mathrm{CP}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}$ over $\left.\infty.\right)$
Remark 7.8. If $g$ was obtained by orthonormalizing a holomorphic frame as in Construction C.7, then Definition 7.7 is compatible with our definition of a parabolic Hecke modification in Appendix E.2.

It is clear from the definition that unitary Hecke modifications define a $\mathbb{Z}$-action on $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$.
Lemma 7.9 (Hecke modifications and $m^{(3)}$ ). A unitary Hecke modification of type $n$ shifts the weight $m^{(3)}$ of an element of $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$ to $m^{(3)}+n$.

Proof. Calculate (7.6) under the change of frame $g \rightarrow \tilde{g}$.
By making an appropriate Hecke modification, the weight $m^{(3)}$ associated to $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ can always therefore be (uniquely) shifted to lie in $\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$.

Corollary 7.10. The quotient of the space $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$ by the action of unitary Hecke modifications is $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$.
This allows us to complete the definition of duality on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$.
Definition 7.11 (Duality on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ ). Given a framed bundle $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ with weight $m^{(3)}$, define its dual $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ by
(1) taking the dual $(E, \theta, h, g)^{*}$ in $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, and
(2) performing a Hecke modification of type 1 if $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$.

The resulting bundle has weight

$$
\begin{cases}-m^{(3)} & \text { if } m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right) \\ -m^{(3)}+1=\frac{1}{2} & \text { if } m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}\end{cases}
$$

and hence still lies in $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$.
Proposition 7.12. The magnetic angle $\hat{\theta}_{m}$ and shifted magnetic angle $\hat{\theta}_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ on $\widehat{\mathcal{H}}^{\text {fr }}$ are invariant under unitary Hecke modifications.

Proof. It suffices to consider a modification $(E, \theta, g) \rightarrow(\tilde{E}, \theta, \tilde{g})$ of type 1 . We must show that the integrals in (7.10) and (7.11) shift by $-\arg (-m)$ to compensate for the increment $m^{(3)} \rightarrow m^{(3)}+1$.

Starting with (7.10), let

$$
I_{m}(g):=\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(A_{h}\right)_{11} \quad \text { and } \quad I_{m}(\tilde{g}):=\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(\tilde{A}_{h}\right)_{11}
$$

denote the integrals for $\hat{\theta}_{m}(E, \theta, g)$ and $\hat{\theta}_{m}(\tilde{E}, \theta, \tilde{g})$. The first integral $I_{m}(g)$ is computed with respect to an eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ along $\gamma$ that satisfies the normalization condition (6.13) involving $g=$ $\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right):$

$$
\left.\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)\right|_{\gamma(t)} \rightarrow \begin{cases}\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right) & \text { as } t \rightarrow \infty \\ \left(e_{2},-e_{1}\right) & \text { as } t \rightarrow-\infty\end{cases}
$$

The Hecke modified bundle is defined by the frame

$$
\tilde{g}=\left(\frac{w}{|w|} e_{1}, \frac{w^{-1}}{|w|^{-1}} e_{2}\right)=\left(\frac{z^{-1}}{|z|^{-1}} e_{1}, \frac{z}{|z|} e_{2}\right)
$$

near $\infty$. By the choice (6.12) of $\gamma$ as a straight line $\gamma(t)=\rho(t) e^{i \arg (m) / 2}$,

$$
\left.\tilde{g}\right|_{\gamma(t)}= \begin{cases}\left(e^{-i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{1}, e^{i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{2}\right) & \text { for } t \gg 0 \\ \left(-e^{-i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{1},-e^{i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{2}\right) & \text { for } t \ll 0\end{cases}
$$

The corresponding normalization condition for the eigenframe $\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}, \tilde{\eta}_{2}\right)$ used to calculate $I_{m}(\tilde{g})$ is

$$
\left.\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}, \tilde{\eta}_{2}\right)\right|_{\gamma(t)} \rightarrow \begin{cases}\left(e^{-i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{1}, e^{i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{2}\right) & \text { as } t \rightarrow \infty \\ \left(-e^{i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{2}, e^{-i \arg (m) / 2} \cdot e_{1}\right) & \text { as } t \rightarrow-\infty\end{cases}
$$

We can therefore take $\tilde{\eta}_{i}=c_{i} \eta_{i}$, where the coefficients $c_{i}$ are chosen to approach the phases above as $t \rightarrow \pm \infty$, e.g.

$$
\left.c_{1}\right|_{\gamma(t)} \rightarrow \begin{cases}e^{-i \arg (m) / 2} & \text { as } t \rightarrow \infty \\ -e^{i \arg (m) / 2} & \text { as } t \rightarrow-\infty\end{cases}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{m}(\tilde{g}) & =\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(\tilde{A}_{h}\right)_{11}=\operatorname{Im} \int_{\gamma}\left(\left(A_{h}\right)_{11}+d \log c_{1}\right) \\
& =I_{m}(g)+\underbrace{\arg \left(c_{1}\right|_{\gamma(\infty)}}_{-\arg (m) / 2}-\underbrace{\arg \left(c_{1}\right|_{\gamma(-\infty)}}_{\arg (m) / 2+\pi}) \\
& =I_{m}(g)-\arg (-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

as required. The argument for the shifted magnetic angle (7.11) is identical.
Corollary 7.13 (Magnetic angles under duality on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ ). The duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$ on $\mathcal{H}^{\text {fr }}$ negates the magnetic angles $\theta_{m}$ and $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$.

We will also write $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$ to denote the induced duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}([E, \theta, h, g])=\left[\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}(E, \theta, h, g)\right]$ on the space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ of isomorphism classes.

Corollary $7.14\left(\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }} \leftrightarrow \mathbb{D}^{\text {ov }}\right)$. Under the identification of $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ with $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$, the duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$ coincides with the natural duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {ov }}$ defined by (7.3).

7.2. Framed Hitchin section and self-duality. Now we will construct a framed version of the Hitchin section and show that it is self-dual under $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$. Certain technical details are relegated to Appendix E.3, but we summarize the main points below.
Definition 7.15 (Hitchin section for $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ ). Consider the set of quadratic differentials

$$
\mathcal{Q}:=\left\{\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}: m \in \mathbb{C}^{*}\right\}
$$

Define a map

$$
\iota^{\mathrm{fr}}: \mathcal{Q} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}}
$$

sending $\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2}$ to the isomorphism class $\left[\left(E, \theta, g_{0}\right)\right]$ of the framed bundle with

- underlying vector bundle

$$
\left.E\right|_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}=K_{\mathrm{C}}^{-1 / 2} \oplus K_{\mathrm{C}}^{1 / 2}\left|{ }_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}\right.
$$

where $K_{\mathrm{C}}^{1 / 2}$ is a spin structure ${ }^{22}$,

- Higgs field

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

- parabolic weight $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$ (with multiplicity 2 ) at $\infty$, as in Construction C.6, and
- framing $g_{0}=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ at $\infty$ as specified in Definition E.7, that is, obtained by orthonormalizing the eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, w \eta_{2}\right)$ where

$$
\eta_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{i z}{2 \sqrt{P}}} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \eta_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{-i z}{2 \sqrt{P}}} \cdot\left(\frac{-1}{\sqrt{P}}\right)
$$

We will refer to the image $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}:=\iota^{\text {fr }}(\mathcal{B}) \subseteq \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ as the (framed) Hitchin section for $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$.
Proposition 7.16 (Self-duality on $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ ). Isomorphism classes of bundles in the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subseteq \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ are fixed under the duality $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}$.
Proof. Unpacking the definitions, we must show that $(E, \theta, h, g) \cong\left(E^{*}, \theta^{t}, h^{*}, g^{*}\right)$ up to a unitary Hecke modification of type 1.

We claim that the desired isomorphism is given by

$$
S=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right): E \xrightarrow{\sim} E^{*}
$$

It is straightforward to compute that:
(1) $S$ sends $\theta$ to $\theta^{t}$, i.e. $S \theta S^{-1}=\theta^{t}$.
(2) $S$ sends $h$ to $h^{*}$, since on the Hitchin section the harmonic metric is diagonal with respect to the direct sum decomposition of $E$.
It remains to show that $S g^{*}=g$ up to a Hecke modification. This boils down to a linear algebra computation which we give in Lemma E.8.

Finally, we conclude that the magnetic angles vanish on the Hitchin section (Theorem 7.1).
Proof of Theorem 7.1. Since $\mathbb{D}^{\text {fr }}[(E, \theta, h, g)]=[(E, \theta, h, g)]$ on $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
\theta_{m}[(E, \theta, h, g)]=\theta_{m}\left(\mathbb{D}^{\mathrm{fr}}[(E, \theta, h, g)]\right)=-\theta_{m}[(E, \theta, h, g)]
$$

and likewise for $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$. Therefore

$$
\left.\theta_{m}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}} \equiv 0 \equiv \left.\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{22}$ i.e. a choice of line bundle such that $K_{C}^{1 / 2} \otimes K_{C}^{1 / 2} \cong K_{C}$, the canonical bundle on $C$. For $C=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ there is a unique choice, namely $K_{C}^{1 / 2}=\mathcal{O}(-1)$.

# 8. Metric on the Hitchin SECTION 

The natural remaining question is how to translate the equality of the symplectic forms $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {reg }}$ and $\Omega_{\xi}^{\text {ov }}$ to the corresponding metrics.

At least formally, we would like to say something like

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg }}(\cdot, \cdot) & =-\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta=1}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}(\cdot, I \cdot) \\
& \stackrel{\text { def }}{=}-\operatorname{Re} \Omega_{\zeta=1}^{\mathrm{reg}}(\cdot, I \cdot)
\end{aligned}
$$

for a suitably regularized version of $g_{L^{2}}$.
The main difficulty here comes from understanding the complex structure $I$ on the space $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ of framed Higgs bundles. It is not a priori clear how the complex structure should act on variations of the parabolic weights or framing. ${ }^{23}$

This difficulty is also related to the analytic question of describing the tangent space. As mentioned before, we do not have a gauge-theoretic construction of these moduli spaces. In the standard (compact, unframed) setting, the tangent space to a point in a Hitchin moduli space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ can be identified with the space of variations $(\hat{A}, \theta)$ which satisfy the linearizations of Hitchin's equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
F_{D_{h}}+\left[\theta, \theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right]=0 \\
\tilde{\partial}_{E} \phi=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

and lie in the orthocomplement of the linearized gauge orbit. In our setting, a variation of the parabolic weight corresponds to changing the boundary conditions of the relevant PDEs. We leave these analytic considerations for future work.

However, these technical difficulties can be circumvented by restricting to the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$, along which the weights and framing do not change.
8.1. Polynomial Hitchin sections. An explicit integral for the $L^{2}$-metric on certain "polynomial Hitchin sections" is given in [DN20] (using the computations from [DN19] for the compact surface case). Our situation will be described by a regularized version of this integral. We will briefly summarize the relevant definitions and results from [DN20] below, and then apply them to our setting in the next section.

Let $\mathcal{B}_{d}$ denote the space of quadratic differentials $\phi$ on $\mathbb{C}$ of the form $\phi=P(z) d z^{2}$, where $P$ is a polynomial of degree $d$. (By abuse of notation we will sometimes just write $P \in \mathcal{B}_{d}$.) The differentials $\phi \in \mathcal{B}_{d}$ parametrize a polynomial Hitchin section of degree $d$, consisting of Higgs bundles $\left(E, \theta_{\phi}\right)$ where $E$ is the trivial ${ }^{24}$ rank 2 bundle over $\mathbb{C}$ and

$$
\theta_{\phi}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
P & 0
\end{array}\right) d z
$$

The harmonic metric $h=h_{\phi}$ for $\left(E, \theta_{\phi}\right)$ is diagonal and can be written as

$$
h=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
e^{u} & 0 \\
0 & e^{-u}
\end{array}\right)
$$

for a scalar function $u$ that satisfies:
(1) the self-duality equation

$$
\Delta u=4\left(e^{2 u}-e^{-2 u}|P|^{2}\right)
$$

(This is equivalent to Hitchin's equation (2.1).)

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{23}$ Of course, the identification $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }} \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ from [Tul19] induces a complex structure $I$ on $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$, but it is not obvious how/if it is related to the "natural one" on $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (whatever that may be).
    ${ }^{24}$ The canonical bundle of $C=\mathbb{C}$ is trivial, so we fix a trivialization $E=K_{C}^{-1 / 2} \oplus K_{C}^{1 / 2} \cong \mathcal{O}^{2}$ to simplify the notation.

(2) the growth rate condition

$$
u \sim \frac{1}{2} \log |P| \quad \text { as }|z| \rightarrow \infty
$$

(This is equivalent to the choice of parabolic weights $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$ in our setting.)
Tangent vectors to $\mathcal{B}_{d}$ are just represented by polynomials $\dot{P}$, but one must restrict their degrees as follows in order to obtain a convergent $L^{2}$-integral.

Given a polynomial $h(z)$ of degree $d$, let $\mathcal{B}_{d, h} \subseteq \mathcal{B}_{d}$ denote the space of polynomials

$$
P(z)=h(z)+\ell(z)
$$

with $\operatorname{deg} \ell<\frac{d}{2}-1$. Then tangent vectors to $P \in \mathcal{B}_{d, h}$ are polynomials $\dot{P}=\dot{\ell}$ with

$$
\operatorname{deg} \dot{P}<\frac{d}{2}-1
$$

As computed in [DN19, Section 4], the norm of $\dot{P}$ with respect to Hitchin's metric is given by

$$
g_{L^{2}}(\dot{P}, \dot{P})=\int_{\mathbb{C}} 4 e^{-2 u}(|\dot{P}|-\operatorname{Re}(F P \bar{P})) d x d y
$$

where $F$ is the solution on $\mathbb{C}$ to the "complex variation equation"

$$
\left(\Delta-8\left(e^{2 u}+e^{-2 u}|P|^{2}\right)\right) F+8 e^{-2 u} \bar{P} \dot{P}=0
$$

(This integral is the norm $\int_{\mathbb{C}}\|\dot{A}\|^{2}+\|\dot{\Theta}\|^{2}$ of the Coulomb gauge representative $(\dot{A}, \dot{\Theta})$ corresponding to the variation $\dot{P}$, as described in Appendix A.1.)

For large $|z|$,

$$
u \sim u_{\mathrm{sf}}:=\frac{1}{2} \log |P| \quad \text { and } \quad F \sim F_{\mathrm{sf}}:=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\dot{P}}{P}
$$

so the integrand in (8.7) grows like $|\dot{P}|^{2} /|P| \sim|z|^{2 \operatorname{deg} \dot{P}-d}$. Therefore the integral converges if and only if the degree condition (8.6) is satisfied.

In addition, replacing $u$ and $F$ with their semiflat approximations $u_{\mathrm{sf}}$ and $F_{\mathrm{sf}}$ gives the formula for the norm with respect to the semiflat metric:

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{sf}}(\dot{P}, \dot{P})=\int_{\mathbb{C}} 2 \frac{|\dot{P}|^{2}}{|P|} d x d y
$$

8.2. Regularization. Our framed Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (Definition 7.15) is a polynomial Hitchin section of degree $d=2$. We are interested in polynomials of the form

$$
P(z)=z^{2}+2 m
$$

but we wish to allow variations $\dot{P}=2 \dot{m} \in \mathbb{C}$. This violates the degree condition (8.6), so we will need to regularize the integral (8.7).

For large $|z|$, the integrand is asymptotic to

$$
2 \frac{|\dot{P}|^{2}}{|\dot{P}|} \sim \frac{8|\dot{m}|^{2}}{|z|^{2}}
$$

so the integral diverges logarithmically like $8|\dot{m}|^{2} \cdot 2 \pi \log R$ as $|z|=R \rightarrow \infty$.
Definition 8.1 (Regularized $L^{2}$-metric on $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ ). Define a regularized version of the metric (8.7) on $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ by

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg }}(\dot{P}, \dot{P}):=\lim _{R \rightarrow \infty}\left[\left(\int_{C_{R}} 4 e^{-2 u}(|\dot{P}|-\operatorname{Re}(F P \bar{P})) d x d y\right)-16 \pi \log R|\dot{m}|^{2}\right]
$$

where $C_{R}:=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|z| \leq R\}$.

The natural complex structure $I$ on $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ acts by $I(\dot{P})=i \dot{P}$, i.e.

$$
I(\dot{m})=i \dot{m}
$$

(This is the restriction of the natural Higgs complex structure (A.5) which sends $I(\dot{\theta})=i \dot{\theta}$.)
Proposition 8.2 (Metric and form compatibility). On the framed Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$,

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{reg}}(\cdot, \cdot)=-\operatorname{Re} \Omega_{\zeta=1}^{\mathrm{reg}}(\cdot, I \cdot)
$$

i.e. the regularized $L^{2}$-metric is compatible with the regularized Atiyah-Bott form (from Definition 4.2) with respect to the complex structure I.

To spell out the notation, write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla & :=\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta=1}\left(E, \theta_{\phi}, h_{\phi}\right) \\
& =\theta_{\phi}+D_{h_{\phi}}+\theta_{\phi}^{\mathrm{T}_{\phi}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for the connection associated to $\phi=\left(z^{2}+2 m\right) d z^{2} \in \mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$. Then a variation $\dot{P}$ of the polynomial $z^{2}+2 m$ induces a variation $\nabla_{\dot{P}}$ of $\nabla$, and (8.14) says that

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{reg}}(\dot{P}, \dot{P}) \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \lim _{R \rightarrow \infty}\left[\left(\int_{C_{R}} 4 e^{-2 u}(|\dot{P}|-\operatorname{Re}(F P \bar{P})) d x d y\right)-16 \pi \log R|\dot{m}|^{2}\right]
$$

is equal to

$$
-\operatorname{Re} \Omega^{\mathrm{reg}}\left(\nabla_{\dot{P}}, \dot{\nabla}_{i \dot{P}}\right) \stackrel{\text { def }}{=} \lim _{R \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\left(-\int_{C_{R}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{\dot{P}} \wedge \nabla_{i \dot{P}}\right)\right)-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}\left(\nabla_{\dot{P}}, \dot{\nabla}_{i \dot{P}}\right)\right]
$$

where as above $C_{R}=\{|z| \leq R\}$.
Proof. The integral terms match up just as they do in the usual (unregularized) case, so we only need to check that the regularization terms coincide. Since $\dot{m}^{(3)} \equiv 0$ on the Hitchin section, the regularization term (4.10) for $\Omega^{\text {reg }}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)$ takes the simpler form

$$
-2 \pi \log R \cdot \mathcal{R}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=16 \pi \log R \operatorname{Im}\left(\dot{m}_{1} \bar{m}_{2}\right)
$$

For $\Omega^{\text {reg }}\left(\nabla_{\dot{P}}, \dot{\nabla}_{i \dot{P}}\right)$, this becomes

$$
16 \pi \log R \operatorname{Im}(\dot{m} \bar{i} \bar{m})=-16 \pi \log R|\dot{m}|^{2}
$$

which is the same as the regularization term for the $L^{2}$-norm.
Theorem 8.3 (Ooguri-Vafa metric and regularization). On the polynomial Hitchin section parametrized by $P(z)=z^{2}+2 m$ for $m \in \mathbb{C}$,

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{reg}}=4 \pi^{2} \cdot g^{\mathrm{ov}}
$$

i.e. the regularized version of Hitchin's metric coincides with the Ooguri-Vafa metric.

Proof.

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{reg}}(\cdot, \cdot) & =-\operatorname{Re} \Omega_{\zeta=1}^{\mathrm{reg}}(\cdot, I \cdot) & & \text { by Proposition } 8.2 \\
& =4 \pi^{2} \cdot \operatorname{Re} \Omega_{\zeta=1}^{\mathrm{ov}}\left(\cdot, I^{\mathrm{ov}} \cdot\right) & & \text { by Theorem } 5.3 \\
& =4 \pi^{2} \cdot g^{\mathrm{ov}}(\cdot, \cdot) & & \text { since } g^{\mathrm{ov}} \text { is hyperkähler. }
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equality uses the fact that the identification $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{ov}}$ preserves the complex structures on the Hitchin section. Indeed, $I^{\text {ov }}$ acts by multiplication by $+i$ on variations $z$ of the OoguriVafa coordinate (see Appendix B), and $I$ acts by $+i$ on the corresponding variations $-2 \pi \dot{m}$.

8.3. Semiflat metric. The same argument works for the semiflat metric on the Hitchin section. Here we can define

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg,sf }}(\dot{P}, \dot{P}):=\lim _{R \rightarrow \infty}\left[\left(\int_{C_{R}} 2 \frac{|\dot{P}|^{2}}{|P|} d x d y\right)-16 \pi \log R|\dot{m}|^{2}\right]
$$

and make use of the identification

$$
\left.\Omega_{\zeta}^{\mathrm{ov}, \mathrm{sf}}\right|_{B^{2 r}}=-\left.\frac{1}{4 \pi^{2}} \Omega_{\zeta}^{\text {reg,sf }}\right|_{B^{2 r}}
$$

from Theorem 7.1.
Corollary 8.4 (Semiflat Ooguri-Vafa metric and regularization). On the polynomial Hitchin section parametrized by $P(z)=z^{2}+2 m$ for $m \in \mathbb{C}$,

$$
g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg,sf }}=4 \pi^{2} \cdot g^{\text {ov,sf }}
$$

i.e. the regularized semiflat $L^{2}$-metric coincides with the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa metric.

In fact, everything here is so explicit that the calculation can be done by hand. In elliptic coordinates $(\mu, v)$ with $x=\sqrt{-2 m} \cosh \mu \cos v$ and $y=\sqrt{-2 m} \sinh \mu \sin v$, there is a neat expression for the integral

$$
\int_{C_{\mu_{0}}} 2 \frac{|\dot{P}|^{2}}{|P|} d x d y=16 \pi|\dot{m}|^{2} \mu_{0}
$$

over $C_{\mu_{0}}:=\left\{(\mu, v): \mu \leq \mu_{0}\right\}$.
For large $\mu_{0}$,

$$
R=|x+i y| \approx\left|\sqrt{-2 m} \cdot \frac{e^{\mu_{0}}}{2}\right|=\sqrt{\frac{|m|}{2}} e^{\mu_{0}}
$$

and so

$$
\log R \approx \frac{1}{2} \log \frac{|m|}{2}+\mu_{0}
$$

We can therefore rewrite the regularized semiflat metric (8.16) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{L^{2}}^{\text {reg,sf }}(\dot{P}, \dot{P}) & =\lim _{\mu_{0} \rightarrow \infty}\left[\left(\int_{C_{\mu_{0}}} 2 \frac{|\dot{P}|^{2}}{|P|} d x d y\right)-16 \pi\left(\frac{1}{2} \log \frac{|m|}{2}+\mu_{0}\right)|\dot{m}|^{2}\right] \\
& =-8 \pi \log \left(\frac{|m|}{2}\right)|\dot{m}|^{2} \\
& =4 \pi^{2} \cdot g^{\text {ov,sf }}(\dot{P}, \dot{P})
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality uses the explicit formula for the semiflat Ooguri-Vafa metric

$$
g^{\text {ov,sf }}=4 V^{\text {sf }} \| d m\|^{2}
$$

on the Hitchin section from Appendix B.3. (Recall that $V^{\text {sf }}$ depends on the Ooguri-Vafa cutoff $\Lambda$ :

$$
V^{\mathrm{sf}}(m)=-\frac{1}{2 \pi} \log \left(\frac{2|m|}{|\Lambda|}\right)
$$

The above calculation perhaps gives some geometric insight into the mysterious-looking choice $\Lambda=4 i$.

Remark 8.5. Although the (non-regularized) integrals defining $g_{L^{2}}$ and $g_{L^{2}}^{\text {sf }}$ are both divergent, their difference

$$
g_{L^{2}}-g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{sf}}=g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{reg}}-g_{L^{2}}^{\mathrm{reg}, \mathrm{sf}}
$$

is convergent (the regularization terms cancel).

Corollary 8.6 (Instanton part). On the polynomial Hitchin section parametrized by $P(z)=z^{2}+2 m$ for $m \in \mathbb{C}$,

$$
g_{L^{2}}-g_{L^{2}}^{\text {st }}=4 \pi^{2} \cdot \underbrace{\left(g^{\text {ov }}-g^{\text {ov,st }}\right)}_{g^{\text {ov,inst }}}
$$

i.e. the difference of the (divergent) $L^{2}$-metrics is given by the instanton part of the Ooguri-Vafa metric

$$
g^{\text {ov, inst }}=V^{\text {inst }}(m)\|d m\|^{2}
$$

where $V^{\text {inst }}$ is the sum of Bessel functions in (B.11).
This was originally anticipated in a numerical calculation by Andy Neitzke (relayed in a personal communication), which this project set out to explain.

# APPENDIX A. BACKGROUND ON Hitchin'S HYPERKÄHLER METRIC 

In order to establish notation and conventions, we will briefly recall some salient facts about the hyperkähler metric on a moduli space of Higgs bundles. For simplicity we will specialize to SL(2)-Higgs bundles of degree 0 on a compact Riemann surface $C$, as first studied in [Hit87]. ${ }^{25}$

In this case the Hitchin moduli space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Higgs }}$ parametrizes harmonic bundles $(E, \theta, h)$ where:

- $E$ is a holomorphic rank 2 vector bundle over $C$.
- $\theta$, the Higgs field, is a traceless holomorphic bundle map

$$
\theta: E \rightarrow E \otimes K_{C}
$$

where $K_{C}$ is the canonical bundle of holomorphic 1-forms on $C$.

- $h$, the harmonic metric, is a hermitian metric on $E$ satisfying Hitchin's equation

$$
F_{D_{h}}+\left[\theta, \theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right]=0
$$

Here $D_{h}$ is the canonical Chern connection associated to $(E, h)$ and $F_{D_{h}}$ is its curvature.
A.1. $L^{2}$-metric. There is a naturally defined (but highly transcendental) Riemannian metric $g_{L^{2}}$ on $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$, involving solutions to Hitchin's equation (A.2). The metric can be written down as follows (see the presentation in [DN19]).

A tangent vector $v$ to $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ is represented by a 1-parameter family of harmonic bundles $\left(E_{t}, \theta_{t}, h_{t}\right)$, up to gauge transformations. By identifying the underlying hermitian bundles $\left(E_{t}, h_{t}\right)$ we obtain a family of unitary connections $D_{t}=d+A_{t}$ and 1 -forms $\Theta_{t}:=\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\dagger_{h}} \in \Omega^{1}(\mathfrak{s u}(E))$, with variations

$$
(\dot{A}, \dot{\Theta})=\left.\frac{d}{d t}\right|_{t=0}\left(D_{t}, \Theta_{t}\right) \in \Omega^{1}(\mathfrak{s u}(E))^{2}
$$

The $L^{2}$-norm of $v$ is given by

$$
g_{L^{2}}(v, v)=\int_{C}\|\dot{A}\|^{2}+\|\dot{\Theta}\|^{2}
$$

for the choice of representative $(\dot{A}, \dot{\Theta})$ which minimizes the norm (or equivalently, is $L^{2}$-orthogonal to the gauge orbit through $\left.\left(D_{0}, \Theta_{0}\right)\right)$. Such a representative is said to be in Coulomb gauge.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{25}$ In the main text we will consider surfaces with punctures (i.e. allow the Higgs bundles to have singularities); see Section 2 for the relevant definitions.

A.2. Hyperkähler structure. The metric $g_{L^{2}}$ is in fact hyperkähler, meaning it is compatible with three complex structures $I, J, K$ satisfying the quaternion relations.

The first complex structure $I$ is the natural complex structure on $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ viewed as a space of Higgs bundles. In particular, it acts on a variation $\dot{\theta}$ of a Higgs field by

$$
I(\dot{\theta})=i \dot{\theta}
$$

The other complex structures naturally come from viewing $\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}$ as a space of flat connections, as we will describe later.

If $w_{I}, w_{J}, w_{K}$ denote the three Kähler forms, then

$$
\Omega_{I}:=\omega_{J}+i \omega_{K}
$$

is a holomorphic symplectic form with respect to $I$, and likewise with the indices cyclically permuted. The metric can be recovered by

$$
g_{L^{2}}(\cdot, \cdot)=\omega_{I}(\cdot, I \cdot)=\operatorname{Re} \Omega_{K}(\cdot, I \cdot)
$$

(and cyclic permutations thereof).
The above data can be packaged into a twistor family of complex structures $I_{\zeta}$ for $\zeta \in \mathbb{C P}^{1}$ with corresponding holomorphic symplectic forms $\Omega_{\zeta}$ (see [HKLR87, Hit92a], or [GMN10, Section 3] for a summary). This comes from the fact that $a I+b J+c K$ is also a complex structure for any

$$
(a, b, c) \in S^{2} \leftrightarrow \zeta \in \mathbb{C P}^{1}
$$

identified stereographically so that

$$
I \leftrightarrow I_{\zeta=0}, \quad J \leftrightarrow I_{\zeta=-i}, \quad K \leftrightarrow I_{\zeta=1}
$$

A.3. Flat connections and nonabelian Hodge. As mentioned in Section 1, for each $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ the nonabelian Hodge map

$$
\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}:(E, \theta, h) \mapsto\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}=\zeta^{-1} \theta+D_{h}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger_{h}}\right)
$$

identifies $\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}, I_{\zeta}\right)$ with the moduli space $\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{dR}}$ of flat $\operatorname{SL}(2, \mathbb{C})$-connections on $C$ (in its natural complex structure). Furthermore, the holomorphic symplectic form $\Omega_{\zeta}$ for $\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {Hit }}, I_{\zeta}\right)$ satisfies

$$
\Omega_{\zeta}=-\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{AB}}
$$

where

$$
\Omega^{\mathrm{AB}}\left(\nabla_{1}, \nabla_{2}\right)=\int_{\mathbb{C}} \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla_{1} \wedge \nabla_{2}\right)
$$

is the holomorphic symplectic Atiyah-Bott form on $\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{dR}}[\mathrm{AB} 83] .{ }^{26}$
In particular, with notation as above,

$$
\Omega_{K} \equiv \Omega_{\zeta=1}=-\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta=1}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{AB}}
$$

and so the hyperkähler metric satisfies

$$
g_{L^{2}}(\cdot, \cdot)=-\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathrm{NAH}_{\zeta=1}\right)^{*} \Omega^{\mathrm{AB}}(\cdot, I \cdot)
$$

# APPENDIX B. CONSTRUCTION OF THE OOGURI-VAFA SPACE 

In this appendix we will briefly explain how the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ can be constructed using the Gibbons-Hawking ansatz. The construction itself is not crucial for understanding our results, but we include an overview for completeness. (The essential features of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ that we will use are summarized in Section 1.2.2.) Many more technical details and proofs can be found in [GW00]; we will mostly follow the presentation of the summaries in [GMN10, Tu119].

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{26}$ The negative sign in (A.9) is just due to our choice of conventions; we could instead have absorbed it into the definition of $\Omega^{\mathrm{AB}}$.

B.1. Gibbons-Hawking ansatz. The Gibbons-Hawking ansatz is a recipe for producing a hyperkähler metric on a $U(1)$-bundle $X$ over an open subset of $\mathbb{R}^{3}$, using a positive harmonic function $V$ (which satisfies a certain integrality condition). The Ooguri-Vafa space [OV96] can be constructed as a quotient of such a space $X$, for a particular choice of harmonic function $V$ with an additional $\mathbb{Z}$-symmetry.

# Construction B. 1 (Gibbons-Hawking). 

(1) Fix an open subset $U \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{3}$ with coordinates $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}$. Let $V: U \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ be a positive harmonic function such that the homology class $\left[\frac{i}{2 \pi} F\right] \in H^{2}(U, \mathbb{R})$ is integral, where $F:=$ $2 \pi i * V$ and $*$ denotes the usual Hodge star on $\mathbb{R}^{3}$.
(2) By the above integrality assumption, $\left[\frac{i}{2 \pi} F\right]$ is the first Chern class of a $U(1)$-bundle $X \rightarrow U$, i.e. there exists a $U(1)$-connection $\Theta \in \Omega^{1}(X, \mathrm{u}(1)=i \mathbb{R})$ on $X$ with curvature $d \Theta=\pi^{*} F$. To simplify the notation, we will consider the real form $\tilde{\Theta}:=\frac{\Theta}{2 \pi i}$ and omit pullbacks $\pi^{*}$.
(3) Define three (real) symplectic forms by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{1}:=-\tilde{\Theta} \wedge d x_{1}+V d x_{2} \wedge d x_{3} \\
& \omega_{2}:=-\tilde{\Theta} \wedge d x_{2}+V d x_{3} \wedge d x_{1} \\
& \omega_{3}:=-\tilde{\Theta} \wedge d x_{3}+V d x_{1} \wedge d x_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

(4) The complex form

$$
\Omega_{1}:=\omega_{2}+i \omega_{3}
$$

can be written as $\Omega_{1}=V \alpha_{1} \wedge d z_{1}$, where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\alpha_{1}:=-\tilde{\Theta} V^{-1}+i d x_{1} \\
z_{1}:=x_{2}+i x_{3}
\end{gathered}
$$

There exists a unique integrable complex structure $I_{1}$ on $X$ for which $\Omega_{1}$ is a holomorphic symplectic form. This structure $I_{1}$ acts by $+i$ on $d z_{1}$ and $\alpha_{1}$ (so in particular $z_{1}: X \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ is an $I_{1}$-holomorphic map).
(5) The other two complex structures $I_{2}, I_{3}$ are obtained by cyclically permuting all of the formulas above. They satisfy $I_{1} I_{2}=I_{3}$ and define a hyperkähler structure with corresponding metric

$$
g=V^{-1} \tilde{\Theta}^{2}+V\|d \tilde{x}\|^{2}
$$

Notation B. 2 (Complex structures). To harmonize the convention

$$
I_{\zeta}=\frac{i(-\zeta+\bar{\zeta}) I_{1}-(\zeta+\bar{\zeta}) I_{2}+\left(1-|\zeta|^{2}\right) I_{3}}{1+|\zeta|^{2}}
$$

from [GMN10] with our stereographic conventions (A.8) for $I, J, K$, we will call

$$
I:=I_{3}, \quad J:=-I_{1}, \quad K:=-I_{2}
$$

B.2. Ooguri-Vafa from Gibbons-Hawking. The Ooguri-Vafa space is obtained by applying a slightly modified version of the Gibbons-Hawking construction with the harmonic function

$$
V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\right):=\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\left(x_{3}+n\right)^{2}}}-c_{n}\right)
$$

where $c_{n} \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ are constants chosen so that the sum converges ${ }^{27}$. By Poisson resummation one can rewrite

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\right)=\underbrace{-\frac{1}{2 \pi} \log \left(\frac{|z|}{|\Lambda|}\right)}_{=: V^{\mathrm{sf}}}+\underbrace{\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z} \backslash\{0\}} e^{2 \pi i n x_{3}} K_{0}(2 \pi|n z|)}_{=: V^{\text {inst }}} \\
& \text { where } z:=z_{3}=x_{1}+i x_{2} \text {, the constant }|\Lambda| \in \mathbb{R}_{>0} \text { depends on the choice of } c_{n} \text {, and } K_{0} \text { is the zeroth } \\
& \text { modified Bessel function of the second kind. }
\end{aligned}
$$

This choice of $V$ is positive on an open set

$$
U=\mathcal{B} \times \mathbb{R} \backslash\{(0,0)\} \times \mathbb{Z}
$$

for some sufficiently small neighbourhood $\mathcal{B} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{2} \cong \mathbb{C}$ of the origin, and satisfies the required integrality condition. The Gibbons-Hawking ansatz therefore produces a hyperkähler $U(1)$-bundle $X \rightarrow U$ as above.

Furthermore, $V$ is invariant under the $\mathbb{Z}$-action $x_{3} \rightarrow x_{3}+n$. This action can be lifted to $X,{ }^{28}$ and taking the quotient gives a $U(1)$-bundle $\widehat{X}$ over

$$
\widehat{U}=\mathcal{B} \times S^{1} \backslash\{(0,0,1)\}
$$

The hyperkähler structure descends to $\widehat{X}$, and smoothly extends over $\mathcal{B} \times S^{1}$ by adding a point - this extension is called the Ooguri-Vafa space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}(\Lambda)$. It can be viewed as a singular torus fibration over $\mathcal{B}$, as shown in Figure 2. The torus fibres are parametrized by the electric angle $\theta_{e}=2 \pi x_{3}$ and a (locally defined) magnetic angle $\theta_{m}$ on the $U(1)$-bundle $\widehat{X}$.
B.3. Explicit metric formulas. For reference in Section 8, we will give some more explicit formulas for the Ooguri-Vafa metric $g^{\text {ov }}$ on the Hitchin section. As we explain in Section 7, under the identification $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{fr}} \cong \mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$, the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ is given by the locus in $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}$ with

- $x_{3} \equiv \frac{1}{2}$ (corresponding to the choice of parabolic weights $\left.m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}\right)$, and
- $\theta_{m} \equiv 0$ (corresponding to the choice of framing).

This will allow us to simplify many of the formulas from above.
The $U(1)$-connection $\Theta$ can be written [GMN10] as $\Theta=i d \theta_{m}+2 \pi i A$ for

$$
\begin{aligned}
A= & \frac{i}{4 \pi}\left(\log \left(\frac{z}{\Lambda}\right)-\log \left(\frac{\bar{z}}{\bar{\Lambda}}\right)\right) d x_{3} \\
& -\frac{1}{4 \pi}\left(\sum_{n \neq 0} \operatorname{sgn}(n) e^{2 \pi i n x_{3}}|z| K_{1}(2 \pi|n z|)\right)\left(\frac{d z}{z}-\frac{d \bar{z}}{\bar{z}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $K_{1}$ is the first modified Bessel function of the second kind. Note that $A$ vanishes when $x_{3} \equiv \frac{1}{2}$.

It follows that on the Hitchin section, the metric (B.7) produced by the Gibbons-Hawking ansatz takes the simple form

$$
\left.g^{\text {ov }}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{b}}}=V\|d z\|^{2}
$$

Similarly, the semiflat metric is given by

$$
\left.g^{\text {ov, } s f}\right|_{\mathcal{B}^{\mathrm{b}}}=V^{\text {sf }}\|d z\|^{2}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{27}$ e.g. one could take $c_{n}=\frac{1}{n+\frac{1}{2}}$
    ${ }^{28}$ There is really a $U(1)$-worth of choice for the lift, which can be combined with the constant $|\Lambda| \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ into the complex cutoff parameter $\Lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$.

where

$$
V^{\mathrm{sf}}=-\frac{1}{2 \pi} \log \left(\frac{|z|}{|\Lambda|}\right)
$$

Note that with the conventions established above, the coordinate $z=x_{2}+i x_{3}$ is holomorphic with respect to the complex structure $I^{\text {ov }}=I_{3}$. One can directly see from the formulas that the metric satisfies

$$
g^{\text {ov,sf }}(\cdot, \cdot)=\operatorname{Re} \Omega_{\zeta=1}^{\text {ov,sf }}\left(\cdot, I^{\text {ov }} \cdot\right)
$$

on $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ (cf. (A.7)).
Under the correspondence $\mathcal{M}^{\text {ov }}(\Lambda=4 i) \cong \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (which associates $z \leftrightarrow-2 i m$ ), we can regard $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }}$ as a polynomial Hitchin section as in Section 8.2, and write

$$
g^{\text {ov,sf }}(\dot{P}, \dot{P})=-\frac{2}{\pi} \log \left(\frac{|m|}{2}\right)|\dot{m}|^{2}
$$

for a variation $\dot{P}$ of $z^{2}+2 m$.

# APPENDIX C. PARABOLIC BUNDLES AND FRAMING 

In this appendix we discuss the relation between compatible frames, eigenframes, and parabolic structures for bundles $(E, \theta, h, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$.
C.1. Parabolic and filtered bundles. We start by reviewing some general definitions involving parabolic and filtered bundles (see e.g. [Sim90, Moc11]). We will use similar notation and conventions as in [Tul19].

Fix a Riemann surface $C$ and a finite subset $D \subseteq C$.
Definition C. 1 (Parabolic vector bundles). Let $\mathbf{c}=\left(c_{p}\right)_{p \in D} \in \mathbb{R}^{D}$. A c-parabolic vector bundle over $(C, D)$ consists of a holomorphic vector bundle $E \rightarrow C$, together with an increasing flag of vector spaces $E_{p, i}$ and increasing sequence of weights $\alpha_{p, i} \in\left(c_{p}-1, c_{p}\right]$ at each $p \in D$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
0=E_{p, 0} \subset E_{p, 1} \subset E_{p, 2} \subset \cdots \subset E_{p, n_{p}}=\left.E\right|_{p} \\
c_{p}-1<\alpha_{p, 1}<\alpha_{p, 2}<\cdots<\alpha_{p, n_{p}} \leq c_{p}
\end{gathered}
$$

Define the multiplicity of the weight $\alpha_{p, i}$ to be $m_{p, i}:=\operatorname{dim} E_{p, i}-\operatorname{dim} E_{p, i-1}$, and the parabolic degree of $E$ by

$$
\operatorname{pdeg} E:=\operatorname{deg} E-\sum_{p \in D} \sum_{i=1}^{n_{p}} m_{p, i} \alpha_{p, i}
$$

Most of the constructions in [Tul19] involve $\frac{1}{2}$-parabolic bundles (i.e. restrict the weights to $\left.\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]\right)$, but we will occasionally use the more general notion.

Definition C. 2 (Parabolic frame). A frame $\left(\eta_{1}, \ldots, \eta_{r}\right)$ for a rank $r$ parabolic vector bundle $E$ near $p$ is compatible with the parabolic structure

$$
0 \subset E_{p, 1} \subset E_{p, 2} \subset \cdots \subset E_{p, n_{p}}=\left.E\right|_{p}
$$

if there is a subsequence $1 \leq k_{1}<k_{2}<\cdots<k_{n_{p}}=r$ such that $\left(\eta_{j}: j \leq k_{i}\right)$ is a frame of $E_{p, i}$ for each $i$.

The flag data of a parabolic bundle can be expressed in terms of increasing filtrations $\mathcal{P}_{*}\left(\left.E\right|_{p}\right)$ indexed by $\left(c_{p}-1, c_{p}\right]$. This can equivalently be formulated without any restrictions on the weights using the notion of a filtered bundle.

Definition C. 3 (Filtered bundles). A filtered bundle over $(C, D)$ consists of a meromorphic vector bundle $E \rightarrow C$ with poles at $D$ (i.e. a locally free finite-rank $\mathcal{O}_{C}(* D)$-module) together with a family $\mathcal{P}_{*} E=\left(\mathcal{P}_{\alpha} E: \alpha \in \mathbb{R}^{D}\right)$ of holomorphic subbundles of $E$ (i.e. locally free $\mathcal{O}_{C}$-submodules) such that:
(i) $\left.\mathcal{P}_{\alpha} E\right|_{C \backslash D}=\left.E\right|_{C \backslash D}$.
(ii) For $p \in D$, the stalk $\left.\mathcal{P}_{\alpha} E\right|_{p}$ depends only on the weight $\alpha_{p}:=\alpha(p) \in \mathbb{R}$. We will write $\mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}} E:=\left.\mathcal{P}_{\alpha} E\right|_{p}$.
(iii) $\mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}} E \subseteq \mathcal{P}_{p, \beta_{p}} E$ if $\alpha_{p} \leq \beta_{p}$, and $\mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}+\varepsilon} E=\mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}} E$ for small $\varepsilon>0$.
(iv) If $w$ is a local coordinate centred at $p \in D$, then $w \mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}} E=\mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}+1} E$.

By property (iii), for each $\mathbf{c} \in \mathbb{R}^{D}$ and $p \in D$ there are finitely many parabolic weights

$$
\left\{\alpha_{p} \in\left(c_{p}-1, c_{p}\right]: \mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}} E \neq \mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}-\varepsilon} E \text { for small } \varepsilon>0\right\}
$$

This defines a corresponding $\mathbf{c}$-parabolic bundle ${ }_{\epsilon} E$, called the $\mathbf{c}$-truncation of $\mathcal{P}_{*} E$. Conversely, any c-parabolic bundle determines a filtered bundle by property (iv). The parabolic degree of $\mathcal{P}_{*} E$ is defined to be the parabolic degree of any of its c-truncations ${ }_{\epsilon} E .{ }^{29}$
Definition C. 4 (Parabolic weight of a section). Any section $\eta$ of the meromorphic bundle $E$ in a neighbourhood of $p$ has an associated parabolic weight

$$
\nu_{p}(\eta):=\min \left\{\alpha_{p}: \eta \in \mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}}\right\}
$$

Remark C. 5 (Growth rate filtration). The harmonic bundles in $\mathcal{H}$ naturally carry a filtered structure. More generally, given any wild harmonic bundle $(E, \theta, h)$ over $C \backslash D$, there is a corresponding filtered bundle $\mathcal{P}_{*}^{h} E$ defined using the growth rates of sections near $D$ with respect to the harmonic metric $h$. Each stalk $\mathcal{P}_{p, \alpha_{p}}^{h} E$ consists of holomorphic sections $s$ in a punctured neighbourhood of $p$ such that

$$
|s|_{h}=\mathcal{O}\left(|w|^{-\alpha_{p}-\varepsilon}\right) \quad \text { for every } \varepsilon>0
$$

We will refer to $\mathcal{P}_{*}^{h} E$ as the growth rate filtration.
The c-truncations of $\mathcal{P}_{*}^{h} E$ are compatible with the Higgs field $\theta$, in the sense that for each $\mathbf{c} \in \mathbb{R}^{D}$ and $p \in D$ there exists a holomorphic frame of $\theta$-eigenvectors near $p$ compatible with the parabolic structure (i.e. with appropriate growth rates) [Moc11].
C.2. Constructing and extending compatible frames. Certain eigenframes can be used to produce a parabolic structure and compatible frame for a bundle in $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$. This is explained in two constructions from [Tul19], which we summarize below.
Construction C. 6 (Elements of $\mathcal{H}$, [Tul19, Lemma 3.1]). For each $m \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ and $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$, the following construction yields a wild harmonic bundle $(E, \theta, h) \in \mathcal{H}$ with the specified parameters:
(1) Start with the trivial rank 2 bundle $E$ over $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}$, equipped with its standard global frame $\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ and Higgs field

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
z^{2}+2 m & 0
\end{array}\right) d z
$$

(2) Choose a holomorphic $\theta$-eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ in a punctured neighbourhood of $\infty$ such that

$$
\eta_{1} \wedge \eta_{2}= \begin{cases}e_{1} \wedge e_{2} & \text { if } m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right) \\ z e_{1} \wedge e_{2} & \text { if } m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}\end{cases}
$$

and use it to extend $E$ over $\infty$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{29}$ Note that replacing $c_{p} \rightarrow c_{p}+1$ increases the degree of ${ }_{\epsilon} E$ by $\operatorname{rank} E$ (by property (iv) in Definition C.3) and increases each weight $\alpha_{p, i}$ by 1 , so $\operatorname{pdeg} \mathcal{P}_{*} E:=\operatorname{pdeg}\left({ }_{\epsilon} E\right)$ is independent of the choice of $\mathbf{c}$.

(3) If $m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)$, assign parabolic weights $+m^{(3)}$ to $\eta_{1}$ and $-m^{(3)}$ to $\eta_{2}$. Otherwise assign $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$ to both $\eta_{1}$ and $\eta_{2}$. This defines a $\frac{1}{2}$-parabolic bundle with the desired parameters $m$ and $m^{(3)}$ and parabolic degree 0 , so the harmonic metric $h$ exists by the general theory of [BB04]. Thus we have an element of $\mathcal{H}$.

Construction C. 7 (Compatible frame from $\theta$-eigenframe, [Tul19, Proposition 3.2]). Given a wild harmonic bundle $(E, \theta, h) \in \mathcal{H}$ (e.g. produced as above), the following construction yields a compatible frame $g$ :
(1) Choose a holomorphic eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ compatible with the parabolic structure, ordered so that $\theta$ is of the framed form

$$
\theta=-H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}-m H \frac{d w}{w}+\text { diagonal holomorphic terms. }
$$

(If $(E, \theta, h)$ was produced using Construction C.6, we can use the same frame $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ as before.) Note that $\eta_{1}$ and $\eta_{2}$ are asymptotically exponentially orthogonal near $w=0$ [Moc11].
(2) Let

$$
\left(v_{1}, v_{2}\right):= \begin{cases}\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right) & \text { if } m^{(3)} \in\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right) \\ \left(\eta_{1}, w \eta_{2}\right) & \text { if } m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}\end{cases}
$$

so that $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$ have respective parabolic weights $+m^{(3)}$ and $-m^{(3)}$.
(3) Let $\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ be the Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization of the frame $\left(v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$ with respect to the harmonic metric $h$, and use it construct a unitary extension of the bundle over $\infty$. Then $g=\left.\left.\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)\right|_{\infty}$ is a unitary frame with respect to which $\theta$ and $\bar{\partial}_{E}$ have the desired forms (2.2) and (2.3).

Together these two constructions produce a framed bundle $(E, \theta, g)$ for any choice of parameters $m$ and $m^{(3)}$. For each such $(E, \theta, g)$, the isomorphism classes $e^{i \theta} \cdot[(E, \theta, g)]=\left[\left(E, \theta, e^{i \frac{g}{2}} \cdot g\right)\right]$ exhaust $\mathfrak{X}^{\operatorname{fr}}\left(m, m^{(3)}\right)$. This gives us a fairly concrete representative for each element in $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$.

By specifying the initial choice of eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$, we can describe the resulting frame $g$ even more explicitly. We will do this in Appendix E. 3 to construct a framed version of the Hitchin section.

We can also go in the other direction, from a compatible frame to an eigenframe.
Lemma C. 8 (Extension to $\theta$-eigenframe).
(1) Given $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$, the frame $g$ admits an extension to an eigenframe $\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}, \tilde{\eta}_{2}\right)$ for $\theta$ near $\infty$.
