(2) Furthermore, the extension can be chosen to be an $S U(2)$-frame with respect to the semiflat metric $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ (see Section 6.1.1), and so that

$$
D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}=d+\frac{m^{(3)}}{2} H\left(\frac{d w}{w}-\frac{d \bar{w}}{\bar{w}}\right)
$$

with respect to the frame near $w=0$.
Proof. (1) First suppose that $(E, \theta, g)$ was produced by orthonormalizing a eigenframe $\left(v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$ as in Construction C.7. Then we can choose the extension $\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}, \tilde{\eta}_{2}\right):=\left(\frac{v_{1}}{\left|v_{1}\right|_{h}}, \frac{v_{2}}{\left|v_{2}\right|_{h}}\right)$; note that it also approaches $g$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ since $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$ are asymptotically exponentially orthogonal. The result also holds for $\left(E, \theta, e^{i \theta} \cdot g\right)$ for any $e^{i \theta} \in U(1)$, using the extension $e^{i \theta} \cdot\left(v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$. But then the general result follows since every isomorphism class in $\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ has a representative of this form.
(2) Follow a similar argument as above, but start with an initial holomorphic eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ such that

$$
h_{\mathrm{sf}}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
|w|^{2 m^{(3)}} & 0 \\
0 & |w|^{-2 m^{(3)}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

near $w=0$. (Such a frame is compatible with the parabolic structure - in fact, this is the model scenario, see e.g. [FMSW22]. It can be obtained by pushing down the corresponding "model frames" for $h_{\mathcal{L}}$ over $\Sigma$.) Choose the extension of $g$ this time by normalizing with respect to $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ instead of $h$, i.e. by taking $\left(\bar{\eta}_{1}, \bar{\eta}_{2}\right):=\left(\frac{\eta_{1}}{\left|\eta_{1}\right| h_{\mathrm{sf}}}, \frac{\eta_{2}}{\left|\eta_{2}\right| h_{\mathrm{sf}}}\right)=\left(|w|^{-m^{(3)}} \eta_{1},|w|^{m^{(3)}} \eta_{2}\right)$. Note that $\left(\bar{\eta}_{1}, \bar{\eta}_{2}\right)$ still approaches $g$ as $w \rightarrow 0$, since $h$ and $h_{\mathrm{sf}}$ are both compatible with the same parabolic structure. By a standard calculation the Chern connection $D_{h_{\mathrm{sf}}}$ is of the specified form.

# APPENDix D. Classical Stokes THEORY 

Stokes theory for irregular connections is typically formulated in terms of meromorphic connections, but we will prefer to work directly with the complex (but not meromorphic) framed connections $\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)$. In this appendix we summarize some of the standard notions and results from the classical theory, and explain how they can be translated to our $C^{\infty}$ setting.
D.1. Holomorphic frames. For each $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ and $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, there is a corresponding framed filtered flat bundle $\left(\mathcal{P}_{*}^{h} \mathcal{E}_{\zeta}, \nabla_{\zeta}, \tau_{*, \zeta}\right)$ as described in [Tul19, Section 3.4.2], where:

- $\mathcal{E}_{\zeta}:=\left(\left.E\right|_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}}, \overline{\partial}_{E}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger}\right)$ is a holomorphic vector bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{\infty\}$.
- $\mathcal{P}_{*}^{h} \mathcal{E}_{\zeta}$ is a filtered bundle over $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$, defined using the growth rate filtration induced by $h$ (see Appendix C. 1 for these definitions).
- $\tau_{a, \zeta}$ is a holomorphic frame of $\mathcal{E}_{\zeta}$ in a neighbourhood of $z=\infty$, with respect to which

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}=d-\left(\zeta^{-1}+\bar{\zeta}\right) H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}+\Lambda(\zeta) \frac{d w}{w}+\operatorname{holo}(1,0) \text { terms }
$$

where

$$
\Lambda(\zeta)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-\zeta^{-1} m+m^{(3)}+\zeta \bar{m}+n_{-}(a) & 0 \\
0 & \zeta^{-1} m-m^{(3)}-\zeta \bar{m}+n_{+}(a)
\end{array}\right)
$$

Here the $n_{ \pm}(a)$ are integers chosen to ensure that the sections of the frame $\tau_{a, \zeta}$ have parabolic weights lying in $(a-1, a] .{ }^{30}$ The frame $\tau_{a, \zeta}$ thereby defines a holomorphic extension of $\mathcal{E}_{\zeta}$ which coincides with $\mathcal{P}_{a}^{h} \mathcal{E}_{\zeta}$.
More explicitly, the compatible holomorphic frame $\tau_{a, \zeta}$ for $\nabla_{\zeta}$ is given by

$$
\tau_{a, \zeta}(w)=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right) \cdot g_{\zeta}(w)|w|^{\left(m^{(3)}+2 \zeta \bar{m}\right) H} w^{N(a)} \exp \left(\frac{\bar{\zeta} H}{2 w^{2}}-\frac{\zeta H}{2 \bar{w}^{2}}\right)
$$

where:

- $\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ is an extension of the original frame $g$ to a neighbourhood of $w=0$ (as in Definition 2.2).
- $g_{\zeta}$ is a gauge transformation in a neighbourhood of $w=0$ that kills the regular $(0,1)$-part of $\bar{\partial}_{E}+\zeta \theta^{\dagger}$ and satisfies $g_{\zeta}(0)=\mathbb{1}$, obtained from [BB04, Section 8].
- $N(a)=\operatorname{diag}\left(n_{-}(a), n_{+}(a)\right)$, where $n_{ \pm}(a)$ is the unique integer such that

$$
n_{ \pm}(a) \mp\left(m^{(3)}+2 \operatorname{Re}(\zeta \bar{m})\right) \in(a-1, a]
$$

We will write $\left(\mathcal{P}_{*} \mathcal{E}, \nabla_{\zeta}, \tau_{*}\right):=\left(\mathcal{P}_{*}^{h} \mathcal{E}_{\zeta}, \nabla_{\zeta}, \tau_{*, \zeta}\right)$ to simplify the notation.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{30}$ [Tul19] calls $n_{-}=n_{1}$ and $n_{+}=n_{2}$.

D.2. Sectorial Stokes data. As above, fix $(E, \theta, g) \in \mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ and $\zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, and consider the associated framed filtered flat bundle $\left(\mathcal{P}, \mathcal{E}, \nabla_{\zeta}, \tau_{*}\right)$ over $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$. We will recall some key facts involving the classical Stokes data of the connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$. A more general summary of the theory can be found in [Tul19, Section 3.4.1], following [Boa01, Boa02, Wit08], but we will just state what is needed for our application.

Choose $a \in \mathbb{R}$ and consider the fixed holomorphic extension $\left(\mathcal{P}_{a} \mathcal{E}, \nabla_{\zeta}, \tau_{a}\right)$. There is a unique formal gauge transformation $\hat{F}_{a}$ such that $\hat{F}_{a}(0)=\mathbb{1}$ and such that the connection has the diagonal form

$$
\nabla_{\zeta}=d-\left(\zeta^{-1}+\bar{\zeta}\right) H \frac{d w}{w^{3}}+\Lambda(\zeta) \frac{d w}{w}
$$

in the formal frame $\tau_{a} \cdot \hat{F}_{a}$ (see e.g. [Boa02, Lemma 1]).
The connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has four anti-Stokes rays $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{4}$ and four Stokes rays, corresponding to directions in the $w$-plane where $-\left(\zeta^{-1}+\bar{\zeta}\right) \frac{1}{w^{2}}$ is real resp. imaginary. (These coincide with the rays defined in Section 2.2.1.) Recall that Sect $_{i}$ denotes the sector bounded by the anti-Stokes rays $r_{i}$ and $r_{i+1}$, and $\overline{\text { Sect }}_{i}$ denotes the extended sector bounded by the adjacent Stokes rays. The following sectorial asymptotic existence theorem (quoted from [Tul19, Theorem 3.6]) is a fundamental classical result.

Proposition D. 1 (Sectorial asymptotic existence, holomorphic version). In a neighbourhood of $w=0$ in each extended sector $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$, there is a unique invertible matrix $\Sigma_{i}$ of holomorphic functions such that the connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has the diagonal form (D.4) in the sectorial frame $\tau_{a} \cdot \Sigma_{i}$.

Furthermore, $\Sigma_{i}=\mathbb{1}+\mathcal{O}(|w|)$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ in $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i} .{ }^{31}$
Thus in each sector $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$, the frame of flat sections $\Phi_{i}$ is explicitly given by

$$
\Phi_{i}=\tau_{a} \cdot \Sigma_{i}\left(\hat{F}_{a}\right) w^{-\Lambda(\zeta)} \exp \left(-\left(\zeta^{-1}+\bar{\zeta}\right) \frac{H}{2 w^{2}}\right)
$$

We will want to work directly with the original frame $g$ instead of $\tau_{a}$. Recall that the Stokes matrix $S_{i}$ is the transition matrix from $\Phi_{i}$ to $\Phi_{i+1}$ on $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i} \cap \overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i+1}$. The sections $\Phi_{i}$ are independent of the choice of $a \in \mathbb{R}$ [Tul19, Section 3.4.3], and hence so are the Stokes matrices $S_{i}$ and the formal monodromy $M_{0}=e^{-2 \pi i \Lambda(\zeta)} .{ }^{32}$ Therefore we can unambiguously speak of the Stokes data of the complex connection $\left(E, \nabla_{\zeta}, g\right)$.

We will also need a translation of Proposition D. 1
Corollary D. 2 (Sectorial asymptotic existence in terms of $g$ ). In a neighbourhood of $w=0$ in each extended sector $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$, there is an invertible matrix $\hat{\Sigma}_{i}$ of smooth functions such that the connection $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has the diagonal form (3.17) in the sectorial frame $g \cdot \hat{\Sigma}_{i}$.

Furthermore, each $\hat{\Sigma}_{i} \rightarrow \mathbb{1}$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ in $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$.
Proof. This follows from the holomorphic result by making an appropriate gauge transformation.
Fix $a \in \mathbb{R}$ and rewrite (D.3) as

$$
\tau_{a, \zeta}(w)=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right) \cdot g_{\zeta}(w) M(w)
$$

where

$$
M(w):=|w|^{\left(m^{(3)}+2 \zeta \bar{w}\right) H} w^{N(a)} \exp \left(\frac{\bar{\zeta} H}{2 w^{2}}-\frac{\zeta H}{2 \bar{w}^{2}}\right)
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{31}$ In fact, more is true: each $\Sigma_{i}$ is asymptotic to the formal series $\hat{F}_{a}$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ in $\overline{\operatorname{Sect}}_{i}$.
    ${ }^{32}$ The $a$-independence of $M_{0}=e^{-2 \pi i \Lambda(\zeta)}$ can be seen directly from (D.2).

It is straightforward to check that $\nabla_{\zeta}$ has the desired diagonal form (3.17) with respect to the frame

$$
\left(\tau \cdot \Sigma_{i}\right) M^{-1}=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right) \cdot \underbrace{g_{\zeta} M \Sigma_{i} M^{-1}}_{=: \Sigma_{i}}
$$

We know that $g_{\zeta} \rightarrow \mathbb{1}$ as $w \rightarrow 0$, so it only remains to check that $M \Sigma_{i} M^{-1} \rightarrow \mathbb{1}$ as $w \rightarrow 0$ in $\widehat{\operatorname{sect}}_{i}$. An almost identical calculation appears in the proof of [Tul19, Lemma 3.5].

In short, since

$$
|M(w)|=|w|^{\left(m^{(3)}+2 \operatorname{Re}(\zeta \bar{\omega})\right) H+N(a)}
$$

the diagonal terms of $M \Sigma_{i} M^{-1}$ are the same as those of $\Sigma_{i}$ (which approach 1), while the offdiagonal terms differ from those of $\Sigma_{i}$ by a factor of magnitude

$$
|w| \pm\left[n_{-}(a)-n_{+}(a)+2\left(m^{(3)}+2 \operatorname{Re}(\zeta \bar{\omega})\right)\right]
$$

The exponent above lies in $(-1,1)$ since it is the difference of two parabolic weights in $(a-1, a]$, but the off-diagonal terms of $\Sigma_{i}$ are $\mathcal{O}(|w|)$, and so the result follows.

# APPENDIX E. PARABOLIC DUALITY AND RELATED CONSTRUCTIONS 

In this appendix we describe some technical constructions involving duality for parabolic and filtered bundles. We will apply this to construct a framed version of the Hitchin section, which will be self-dual in the appropriate sense.
E.1. Filtered duality. There is a natural notion of duality for filtered bundles (see e.g. [Moc22]).

Definition E. 1 (Dual filtered bundle). If $\mathcal{P}_{*} E$ is a filtered bundle over $(C, D)$, then the dual meromorphic bundle $E^{\vee}=\mathcal{H o m}\left(E, \mathcal{O}_{C}(* D)\right)$ has an induced filtered structure

$$
\mathcal{P}_{\alpha}\left(E^{\vee}\right):=\left\{\phi \in E^{\vee}: \phi\left(\mathcal{P}_{\beta} E\right) \subseteq \mathcal{P}_{\beta+\alpha} \mathcal{O}_{C}(* D) \quad \forall \beta \in \mathbb{R}^{D}\right\}
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{P}_{\alpha} \mathcal{O}_{C}(* D)=\mathcal{O}\left(\sum_{p \in D}\left\lfloor\alpha_{p}\right\rfloor p\right)
$$

Remark E. 2 (Dual weights). There is a natural isomorphism of (holomorphic) bundles

$$
\mathcal{P}_{\alpha}\left(E^{\vee}\right) \cong\left(\mathcal{P}_{<-\alpha+1} E\right)^{*}
$$

If $\mathcal{P}_{p, *} E$ has parabolic weights $\left\{\alpha_{p}\right\}$ at $p \in D$ (i.e. indices at which the filtration $\mathcal{P}_{p, *} E$ jumps, not restricted to any subinterval), then $\mathcal{P}_{p, *}\left(E^{\vee}\right)$ has weights $\left\{-\alpha_{p}\right\}$.

On the other hand, given a wild harmonic bundle $(E, \theta, h)$, we can consider the dual harmonic bundle (cf. Section 7.1)

$$
(E, \theta, h)^{*}:=\left(E^{*}, \theta^{t}, h^{*}\right)
$$

This is compatible with Definition E. 1 in the sense that the growth rate filtration induced by $(E, \theta, h)^{*}$ is dual to that induced by $(E, \theta, h)$.

Describing duality on the level of parabolic bundles is slightly more subtle. Motivated by Remark E.2, we make the following (somewhat indirect) definition:

Definition E. 3 (Dual parabolic bundle). If $E$ is a c-parabolic bundle with corresponding filtered bundle $\mathcal{P}_{*} E$, define the dual parabolic bundle $E^{*}$ to be the $(-\mathbf{c}+\mathbf{1})$-truncation of the dual filtered bundle $\mathcal{P}_{*}\left(E^{\vee}\right)$.

Note that under this definition, the dual of a $\frac{1}{2}$-parabolic bundle is again $\frac{1}{2}$-parabolic.
We would like describe the dual flag data more explicitly. There is some asymmetry since the dual weights are truncated to half-open intervals $\left(-c_{p},-c_{p}+1\right]$. If $E$ has parabolic weights $\alpha_{1}<\alpha_{2}<\cdots<\alpha_{n_{p}}$ at $p \in D$, then $E^{*}$ must have weights

$$
\begin{cases}-\alpha_{n_{p}}<-\alpha_{n_{p}-1}<\cdots<-\alpha_{2}<-\alpha_{1} & \text { if } \alpha_{n_{p}} \neq c_{p} \\ -\alpha_{n_{p}-1}<\cdots<-\alpha_{2}<-\alpha_{1}<-c_{p}+1 & \text { if } \alpha_{n_{p}}=c_{p}\end{cases}
$$

It is most natural to think of these weights in terms of corresponding (dual) sections. Suppose $\left.E\right|_{p}$ has flag data

$$
0=E_{p, 0} \subset E_{p, 1} \subset E_{p, 2} \subset \cdots \subset E_{p, n_{p}}=\left.E\right|_{p}
$$

and let $\left(\eta_{1}, \ldots, \eta_{\operatorname{rank} E}\right)$ be a compatible frame. Then $\left(\eta_{\operatorname{rank} E^{\prime}}^{*}, \ldots, \eta_{1}^{*}\right)$ is a compatible frame for the dual flag of annihilators

$$
0=\left(E_{p, n_{p}}\right)^{0} \subset\left(E_{p, n_{p}-1}\right)^{0} \subset\left(E_{p, n_{p}-2}\right)^{0} \subset \cdots \subset\left(E_{p, 0}\right)^{0}=\left(\left.E\right|_{p}\right)^{*}
$$

with corresponding weights $\nu_{p}\left(\eta_{i}^{*}\right)=-\nu_{p}\left(\eta_{i}\right)$. In other words, each subspace $\left(E_{p, i}\right)^{0}$ is naturally associated with the weight $-\alpha_{p, i+1}$. This coincides with the desired dual parabolic structure when $\alpha_{n_{p}} \neq c_{p}$, but if $\alpha_{n_{p}}=c_{p}$ we will need to modify the bundle and flag so that the dual weight $-c_{p}$ lies in $\left(-c_{p},-c_{p}+1\right]$ :

$$
\alpha_{n_{p}}=c_{p} \xrightarrow{\text { dualize }}-c_{p} \xrightarrow{\text { shift weight }}-c_{p}+1
$$

Such a shift can be conveniently phrased in the language of Hecke modifications.
E.2. Hecke modifications and parabolic duality. We begin with a very brief overview of Hecke modifications in general; see [KW07] for more detail. Our main focus will be on their interplay with the parabolic structures described above.

Construction E. 4 (Hecke modification). Let $E$ be a rank $r$ holomorphic vector bundle over $C$, and fix a point $p \in C$. A Hecke modification of $E$ at $p$ of type $\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{r}\right) \in \mathbb{Z}^{r}$ is a new bundle $\tilde{E}$, obtained by the following procedure:
(1) Fix a local coordinate $w$ centred at $p$ and choose a trivialization of $E$ over a sufficiently small disc $\Delta_{p}$ around $p$.
(2) Let $\tilde{E}$ be the new bundle obtained by regluing $\left.E\right|_{\Delta_{p}}$ and $\left.E\right|_{C \backslash\{p\}}$ using the transition map

$$
\operatorname{diag}\left(w^{-n_{1}}, \ldots, w^{-n_{r}}\right)
$$

over the punctured disc $\Delta_{p}^{\times}$.
Such a modification of $E$ changes the degree of the bundle to

$$
\operatorname{deg} \tilde{E}=\operatorname{deg} E+\sum_{i=1}^{r} n_{i}
$$

Note that Hecke modifications of a given type $\left(n_{1}, \ldots, n_{r}\right)$ are not unique: the above construction depends on the choice of trivialization. However, our situation is more rigid, since we will only be interested in modifications that are compatible with the parabolic structure.

Definition E. 5 (Parabolic Hecke modification). If $E$ is a parabolic bundle and $p \in D$, we will say that a Hecke modification at $p$ is parabolic if the sections used to trivialize $E$ over $\Delta_{p}$ are compatible with the parabolic structure at $p$.

Such a modification naturally shifts the parabolic weights associated with the trivializing sections, and in this way defines a new flag at $p$. In particular, if $E$ is the c-truncation of a filtered bundle $\mathcal{P}_{*} E$, then the bundle $\tilde{E}$ obtained by a parabolic Hecke modification of type $\pm(1, \ldots, 1)$ is the $\mathbf{c}^{\prime}$-truncation of $\mathcal{P}_{*} E$, where $c_{p}^{\prime}=c_{p} \pm 1 .{ }^{33}$ More generally one can shift some subset of the parabolic weights in order to produce a new parabolic bundle, as long as all of the new weights lie in suitable half-open intervals. This leads to a procedure for directly obtaining the dual of a parabolic bundle.

Construction E. 6 (Dual parabolic bundle, redux). If $E$ is a c-parabolic bundle with flags

$$
\begin{gathered}
0=E_{p, 0} \subset E_{p, 1} \subset E_{p, 2} \subset \cdots \subset E_{p, n_{p}}=\left.E\right|_{p} \\
c_{p}-1<\alpha_{p, 1}<\alpha_{p, 2}<\cdots<\alpha_{p, n_{p}} \leq c_{p}
\end{gathered}
$$

then the dual parabolic bundle $E^{*}$ is obtained by taking the dual flags

$$
\begin{gathered}
0=\left(E_{p, n_{p}}\right)^{0} \subset\left(E_{p, n_{p}-1}\right)^{0} \subset\left(E_{p, n_{p}-2}\right)^{0} \subset \cdots \subset\left(E_{p, 0}\right)^{0}=\left(\left.E\right|_{p}\right)^{*} \\
-c_{p} \leq-\alpha_{p, n_{p}}<-\alpha_{p, n_{p}-1}<\cdots<-\alpha_{p, 1}<-c_{p}+1
\end{gathered}
$$

and performing a parabolic Hecke modification of type $\underbrace{(1, \ldots, 1}_{m_{p, n_{p}}} 0, \ldots, 0)$ at each point $p \in D$ such that $\alpha_{p, n+p}=c_{p}$.
E.3. Self-dual frames for the Hitchin section. We can construct a frame for the Hitchin section $\mathcal{B}^{\text {fr }} \subseteq \mathfrak{X}^{\text {fr }}$ (Definition 7.15) by following the $m^{(3)}=\frac{1}{2}$ cases of Constructions C. 6 and C.7. ${ }^{34}$ This procedure involves a choice of eigenframe $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$, which we will explicitly specify below.

The eigensections of

$$
\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
z^{2}+2 m & 0
\end{array}\right) d z
$$

are of the form

$$
\eta_{1}=\lambda_{1}\binom{1}{\sqrt{P}} \quad \text { and } \quad \eta_{2}=\lambda_{2}\binom{-1}{\sqrt{P}}
$$

where

$$
P:=z^{2}+2 m
$$

The requirement $\eta_{1} \wedge \eta_{2}=z e_{1} \wedge e_{2}$ in (C.6) is equivalent to

$$
\lambda_{1} \lambda_{2}=\frac{z}{2 \sqrt{P}}
$$

which we can satisfy by taking

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{1}=\lambda_{2} & =\sqrt{\frac{z}{2 \sqrt{P}}} \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(w^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using these choices of normalization, Construction C. 6 defines a parabolic bundle in which both eigensections $\eta_{i}$ have weight $\frac{1}{2}$, as well as a harmonic metric $h$. Then, Construction C. 7 produces a compatible frame $g$ by orthonormalizing $\left(\eta_{1}, w \eta_{2}\right)$ with respect to $h$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{33}$ In this case the Hecke modification construction is essentially a reformulation of properties (i) and (iv) in Definition C.3.
    ${ }^{34}$ The notation in Definition 7.15 is slightly different, with $E=K_{\mathrm{C}}^{-1 / 2} \oplus K_{\mathrm{C}}^{1 / 2}$ and $\theta=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & 1 \\ (z^{2}+2 m) d z^{2} & 0\end{array}\right)$. To be consistent with the notation below, we will fix a trivialization of $E$ using the sections $d z^{ \pm 1 / 2}$.

More generally we can consider the $U(1)$-family of frames $e^{i \vartheta} \cdot g$, which equivalently could have been obtained by starting with the eigenframe $e^{i \vartheta} \cdot\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$, i.e. choosing the normalizations

$$
\lambda_{1}=e^{i \vartheta} \sqrt{\frac{z}{2 \sqrt{P}}} \quad \text { and } \quad \lambda_{2}=e^{-i \vartheta} \sqrt{\frac{z}{2 \sqrt{P}}}
$$

Definition E. 7 (Hitchin section frame). We will choose the frame $g_{0}:=e^{i \pi / 4} \cdot g$ for our construction of the framed Hitchin section.

We will prove that the magnetic angles $\theta_{m}$ and $\theta_{m}^{\text {shift }}$ vanish for this choice of frame by showing that it is "self-dual" in the sense discussed in Section 7.2. More specifically, we will need to know how the frame $e^{i \vartheta} \cdot g$ transforms under duality and the isomorphism

$$
S=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right): E^{*} \xrightarrow{\sim} E
$$

Lemma E. 8 (Dual frame calculation). The frame $e^{i \vartheta} \cdot g=\left(e_{1}, e_{2}\right)$ satisfies

$$
S\left(e^{i \vartheta} \cdot g\right)^{*}=\left(i e^{-2 i \vartheta} \frac{w}{|w|} e_{1},-i e^{2 i \vartheta} \frac{|w|}{w} e_{2}\right)
$$

In particular, for $\vartheta=\frac{\pi}{2}$, the Hitchin section frame $g_{0}$ satisfies

$$
S\left(g_{0}\right)^{*}=\left(\frac{w}{|w|} e_{1}, \frac{|w|}{w} e_{2}\right)
$$

i.e. it is self-dual under the isomorphism $S$ up to a unitary Hecke modification of type 1 (see Definition 7.7).

Proof. It suffices to work with the "approximately orthogonal" frame

$$
\tilde{g}:=\left(\frac{\eta_{1}}{|w|^{-1 / 2}}, \frac{w}{|w|} \frac{\eta_{2}}{|w|^{-1 / 2}}\right)
$$

instead of $g$, since the other Gram-Schmidt terms vanish exponentially as $w \rightarrow 0$. This reduces the claim to a straightforward linear algebra computation.

In general, the coefficients of

$$
\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{1}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\right), \tilde{\lambda}_{2}\left(\frac{-1}{\sqrt{P}}\right)\right)^{*}
$$

are given by the columns of the inverse transpose matrix, namely

$$
\left(\frac{1}{\tilde{\lambda}_{1} \cdot 2 \sqrt{P}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt{P} \\
1
\end{array}\right), \frac{1}{\tilde{\lambda}_{2} \cdot 2 \sqrt{P}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sqrt{P} \\
1
\end{array}\right)\right)
$$

It follows that

$$
S\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{1}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\right), \tilde{\lambda}_{2}\left(\frac{-1}{\sqrt{P}}\right)\right)^{*}=\left(\frac{i}{\tilde{\lambda}_{1} \cdot 2 \sqrt{P}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\right), \frac{-i}{\tilde{\lambda}_{2} \cdot 2 \sqrt{P}}\left(\frac{-1}{\sqrt{P}}\right)\right)
$$

Choosing

$$
\tilde{\lambda}_{1}=\frac{\lambda_{1}}{|w|^{-1 / 2}} \quad \text { and } \quad \tilde{\lambda}_{2}=\frac{w \lambda_{2}}{|w|^{1 / 2}}
$$

to match with $\tilde{g}$ in (E.10) and using the normalization (E.7) for $\lambda_{i}$, we see that the original components of $\tilde{g}$ are respectively multiplied by

$$
\frac{i}{\tilde{\lambda}_{1}^{2} \cdot 2 \sqrt{P}}=i e^{-2 i \vartheta} \frac{w}{|w|} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{-i}{\tilde{\lambda}_{2}^{2} \cdot 2 \sqrt{P}}=-i e^{2 i \vartheta} \frac{|w|}{w}
$$

as required.

abstract:
Gaiotto, Moore, and Neitzke predicted that the hyperk\"ahler Ooguri-Vafa
space $\mathcal{M}^{\rm ov}$ should provide a local model for Hitchin moduli
spaces near the discriminant locus. To this end, Tulli identified
$\mathcal{M}^{\rm ov}$ with a certain space of framed Higgs bundles with an
irregular singularity. We extend this result by identifying the Ooguri-Vafa
holomorphic symplectic form with a regularized version of the Atiyah-Bott form
on the associated space of framed connections. We also prove the analogous
statement for the corresponding semiflat forms. Finally, restricting to the
Hitchin section, we identify a regularized version of Hitchin's $L^2$-metric
with the Ooguri-Vafa metric.
